PARA.TAB: Mr SPEAKER (Hon. Stephen Martin) took the chair at 12.30 p.m., and read prayers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleeland Mr P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority, I present the committee's report entitled Organised criminal paedophile activity, which incorporates a dissenting report, together with the evidence received by the committee.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the House take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: In February 1994, a review of the Commonwealth law enforcement arrangements said that there were allegations about the existence of networks of paedophiles operating in Australia and that the extent of the networks and their activities remained unknown. The review recommended that organised paedophile networks be added to the areas of major organised crime that the National Crime Authority was expected to focus on. The government accepted this recommendation. In December 1994, the committee agreed to conduct an inquiry into the extent to which organised paedophile networks had become established in Australia, and related matters such as the adequacy of police resources and the role of the National Crime Authority in tackling this area of criminal activity.

PARA.TAB: To some extent, the conclusions reached on the scope of organised paedophile activity depend upon the breadth or narrowness of the definitions adopted for such key terms as `paedophile', `child pornography' and `organised networks'. These terms are used with widely varying definitions. For example, dictionaries define a paedophile as an adult who is sexually attracted towards children. Should `children' in this context be limited to prepubescent children or include those up to their mid-teens or even those up to 18?

The committee found no consistent usage on this matter. Moreover, some distinguish between preferential and situational child sex offenders and regard only the former as paedophiles. Preferential offenders are those having a definite sexual preference for children. Situational offenders lack this preference but may offend against a child simply because the child is vulnerable and available at a time when an adult partner is not.

The information presented to the committee was that most sexual offences against children are committed by their relatives and neighbours, who are not paedophiles in the strict sense of the term and do not operate in any organised or networked way. To the extent that two or more paedophiles group together to commit offences, the numbers involved have almost invariably been very small and the groupings very much ad hoc and on a peer-to-peer basis. More commonly, where there are contracts between paedophile offenders, they consist of loose informal networks of peer-to-peer contacts. The committee did not receive any evidence that organised paedophile groups and networks have ever resembled in size, aims, structures, methods or longevity the organised crime groups which provide the main focus for the NCA's work.

The committee did not receive evidence of any commercial production of illegal child pornography in Australia. Most of the current illegal material that undoubtedly is possessed by many paedophiles appears to be made by them, obtained by the informal trading of homemade material amongst paedophiles assisted by informal networking or obtained from overseas. There is no evidence of the organised promotion or arrangement of tours by Australian paedophiles to overseas destinations known to be attractive to them. However, informal networking among paedophiles may assist some tourists going overseas to commit paedophile offences.

In the light of evidence on the nature and extent of organised paedophile activity, the committee found it necessary to make only limited recommendations for change. The committee considered it essential that any focus by law enforcement agencies on organised paedophilia is not at the expense of resources devoted to the majority of cases of child sexual abuse. While, clearly, paedophile networking should not be ignored, an overemphasis on it risks distracting community attention away from the majority of child sex offenders—the lone offenders who are all too frequently members of the same family or household as their victims.

The committee noted that the National Crime Authority is due to complete its own strategic intelligence assessment of organised paedophile activity early in 1996. Mr Sherman, the authority chairperson, told the committee in August that if the authority's assessment matched the committee's he did not propose that the National Crime Authority stay around in that area creating a role for itself. The committee endorsed this view. It considered that, unless criminal paedophile activity can be shown to be organised in fairly extensive and sophisticated ways that span state-territory boundaries, there is no justification for bringing the National Crime Authority's particular expertise and powers to bear. The specialist units in state and territory police forces have experience, facilities and expertise in investigating child sexual assault that the NCA does not have.

In coming to this view, the committee recognised that there was scope for improvement in the way that the various police forces work together to deal with paedophile offenders. Police told the committee that cooperation amongst their forces was generally good. However, they agreed that there could be improvements. For example, the Australian Federal Police told the committee that the single most important issue in this area was the need for timely and effective exchange of information between forces. Accordingly, the committee recommended that the Australasian Police Ministers Council examine how this might best be achieved. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Filing Mr P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the tabling of this report by the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority. I will continue on from the remarks of the chairman, the honourable member for McEwen (Mr Cleeland), because he had reached an important area in relation to the detection of child sex tourists overseas—in particular, the revelations in relation to the detection of child sex tourists under the legislation that was passed by this parliament about two years ago. Until the hearing of that evidence from the Australian Federal Police, there had not been one single prosecution of an Australian child sex tourist for that offence.

PARA.TAB: We were interested during the hearings to learn more about this. We heard from Commander Schramm of the Australian Federal Police, who made the point that the Thai police force has a total manpower of 300,000 personnel, yet there are only 10 Thai police officers working full time on paedophilia or paedophile related offences. That set the priority to a certain extent for the exercises involving the police liaison officers who are stationed in Thailand.With regard to the arrangements between the Thai police and the Australian Federal Police, recommendation (v) reads:

SPEECH.PARA: the Government takes steps to improve the arrangements . . . with a view to improving the detection and prosecution of Australian child sex tourists.
Recommendation (vi) reads:

the Government take steps to ensure that all its personnel working overseas in countries believed to be attractive to visiting Australian paedophiles are made aware that any information that they happen to come across about the illegal activities of such paedophiles should be reported to the Australian Federal Police. The Committee further recommends that similar steps be taken in relation to the personnel of non-government aid and other organisations funded in whole or in part by the Australian Government.
Recommendation (vii) reads:

the Government seek treaty relationships with the Cambodian and other South-East Asian Governments to assist in the detection and obtaining of evidence to enable the prosecution of Australians committing child-sex offences in those countries.

During the committee's hearings we heard evidence in Melbourne from representatives of World Vision of some dissatisfaction with the response they had received regarding complaints or information they had passed on to the Australian Federal Police. Likewise, from the Australian Federal Police Association we heard evidence that there was disquiet within the Australian Federal Police at the time of the allegations giving rise to those concerns—namely, allegations of child sex activity by Australians in Cambodia—that the Australian Federal Police had not undertaken on-site investigations at the time.

PARA.TAB: Those concerns bear investigation by those who have that particular responsibility. The committee saw fit to make the recommendations I have just mentioned in order to try to overcome the difficulties that are being encountered in relation to child sex tourism. I note there has now been one prosecution under the child sex tourism legislation. As a consequence, we hope that with the improved relations between the Australian Federal Police, law enforcement agencies and overseas law enforcement agencies these particular circumstances will improve.

The other matter of concern was evidence from the Australian Customs Service that they have virtually little to no opportunity of being able to detect child sex pornography that comes in on CD-ROMs. In other words, they do not have the resources or the wherewithal to be able to detect that type of material as it comes into Australia. As a consequence, we find that child sex pornography that arrives in Australia either on the Internet or on CDs, in the baggage of or with particular passengers, is virtually unable to be detected unless somebody can be identified as possessing it in a form identified as child sex pornography.

That is obviously a concern. There are software packages that are available now to detect these things much earlier. Recommendation (iii) points out that the Minister for Justice should take steps to ensure that Australian law enforcement agencies contribute to and draw on the expertise and software tools of overseas law enforcement agencies.

PARA.TAB: That the House take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Committee

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Price The Hon L.R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade I present the committee's report entitled Australia's relations with Thailand, together with the minutes of proceedings and evidence received by the committee.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the House take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: In the past, the joint standing committee has undertaken three inquiries into Australia's relations with countries in our immediate region. The report I have just tabled is the latest in this series and takes its place with the 1989 report on countries of the South Pacific, the 1991 report on relations with Papua New Guinea and the report on relations with Indonesia, tabled in 1993. This report then could be seen as a broadening of the committee's focus. While Thailand is not as close geographically to this country as PNG is, for example, as a mainland state in South-East Asia and an important member of both ASEAN and APEC Thailand is an important country for Australia.

PARA.TAB: Australia's contacts with Thailand before the Second World War were not great but the relationship between the two peoples was given form and meaning because of the presence of Australian prisoners of war on the Burma-Thailand railway from 1942. It was suggested to the committee that post-1945 the bilateral relationship was at its peak but has since been allowed to decline somewhat.

This report makes 57 recommendations in a wide variety of areas and it is the committee's hope that they will add to the relationship. Having said that, I should add that members did not believe there were any problems between Australia and Thailand. I would like to congratulate the subcommittee chairman, the member for Reid (Mr Ferguson), whose interest in foreign affairs is well known, the subcommittee members and the secretariat.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to endorse the remarks made by the Chairman of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, the honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price), and welcome the opportunity to add my comments on this report, which covers the most significant aspects of Australia's relations with Thailand. Because of the limited time available, I would like to focus on what I regard as a vital aspect of the inquiry—the need to maintain and strengthen Australia's relationship with Thailand through a better knowledge and understanding of the Thai culture, history and language and the pivotal role played by the National Thai Studies Centre in this regard. Despite the increasing importance of and opportunities for Australian investment in South-East Asia, there is an acute shortage of Australians who have a sufficiently well developed grasp of Asian languages, cultures and business methods.

PARA.TAB: Thailand not only plays a major economic and political role and has one of the fastest growing economies in South-East Asia but also is one of Australia's fastest growing export markets. This report examines the importance of Thai studies to the process of strengthening Australian-Thai relations and reviews the arrangements for teaching Thai studies in Australian educational institutions. It also highlights the consequences of the decision in March 1994 by the Council of Australian Governments to give priority to the study of only four Asian languages, not including Thai, in Australian schools.

The usefulness and relevance of Thai studies for Australians wishing to pursue business interests in Thailand are obvious, but business interests are not the only consideration. Greater availability of and participation in Thai studies will undoubtedly provide enormous benefits and advantages in regard to all facets of Australian relations with Thailand. That is why it is so important to ensure relatively small demand programs, such as Thai studies, remain viable. Funding support for these programs tends to be short term or project based rather than recurrent. Because they do not enjoy the same level of enrolment as some other Asian languages, they become very vulnerable if longer term funding support through the Commonwealth, state and territory education systems is not available to them.

Evidence from groups and individuals involved in the field of Asian or Thai studies and organisations such as the Australia-Thailand Business Council consistently argued for greater coordination of support at Commonwealth level to ensure that the limited funding available was being spent effectively. The committee heard differing views on preferred options for achieving long-term viability for Thai studies programs. However, some form of rationalisation in the number of secondary and tertiary academic institutions promoting Thai studies was a consistent theme. The need to encourage institutions with a proven record of successfully establishing links with the business community and other sources of sponsorship was also recognised as a significant factor, as was the advantage of locating teaching institutions close to large catchment areas capable of generating greater demand for Thai studies.

During the committee's visit to Thailand in November 1994 the delegation learned of the high regard in which the work of the National Thai Studies Centre is held in that country and of the relatively low levels of financial support provided by the Commonwealth government and the Australian National University. Established in 1991 with `seed' funding from the Department of Employment, Education and Training, the NTSC performs a range of functions in addition to conducting an undergraduate course in Thai studies. For example, it also sponsors the annual Thailand update conferences and promotes the rationalisation of Thai language teaching through Australia. In fact, the NTSC is the only academic and public information centre in the world which is located outside but dedicated to contemporary studies of Thailand.

It is not generally appreciated that to some extent the NTSC operates as a de facto Australia-Thailand council. It is involved in non-language activities such as cultural exchanges, visits by prominent Thai nationals and production of current awareness publications. In this regard it fulfils a similar role to the bodies such as the Australia-China Council and the Australia-Indonesia Institute, which, unlike the NTSC, enjoyed guaranteed long-term funding and staffing support under the auspices of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. Recognising these aspects of the NTSC's responsibilities and the relatively precarious nature of its funding support, the committee has reiterated its concerns expressed in the report of the visit to Thailand last year that uncertain funding levels threaten the continued existence of the centre and consolidation of its achievements.

Commonwealth funding for the NTSC over the next three years is unfortunately being curtailed and will cease altogether in 1997-98. Accordingly, we have again recommended that DEET examine the role of the NTSC and the funding support provided to ensure that it continues to operate under conditions no less favourable than those which have applied to date.

Finally, I would like to express my support for the conclusions and recommendations in this report and to urge the government to respond positively to the many suggested strategies for maintaining and enhancing the Australian-Thai relationship, a relationship which will provide significant benefits for both nations.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report on Australia's relations with Thailand is of significance. It is the latest in a series which began in 1989 with the tabling of a report on Australia's relations with the countries of the South Pacific. Since then, the committee's reports have examined our relations with Papua New Guinea and Indonesia. Given Thailand's important position in South-East Asia, its economic dynamism, our mutual attachment to openness and a pluralist democracy, and the wartime contacts between the two peoples, it was particularly appropriate to have examined this relationship.

PARA.TAB: I would like to comment on a number of aspects of this report, including industrial relations; Australia's development assistance to Thailand; the sale of Australian education to Thailand; the importance of alumni associations in Thailand for the future of the relationship; and, briefly, the work of the Thai-Australian association. In making these comments today, I would like to make one thing emphatically clear: this report does not set out to pass judgment on Thailand in any area. The relationship is too important and too good to be jeopardised by provocative statements or intrusive behaviour. Nevertheless, there are areas where Australia may, because of the longstanding relationship and a degree of expertise, be able to provide assistance. Occupational safety and fair labour standards are one area.

Thailand has commendable legislation in many fields, but implementation is faced with extremely swift industrialisation. The fire in the Hong Kong owned Kader toy factory in May 1993 was a dramatic indication of difficulties. The issues of sprinklers, fire exits and the presence of flammable material in stairs received international coverage. It is reported that 188 people died in the fire and that a further 469 were injured trying to escape.

Thailand last signed a convention of the International Labour Organisation in 1967. Its record in this area is comparable with all other South-East Asian nations. The committee has recommended that Thailand be encouraged to sign and ratify ILO conventions as a matter of priority and that Australia offers its assistance to Thailand in the development of laws which are in accordance with the ILO conventions. If Thailand, and other South-East Asian countries for that matter, can be assisted in this process, there will be nationally supported standards which can be used as ways of improving working conditions. A worrying aspect in the region is the use of child labour, and this is one area where the application of ILO conventions would be of value.

There is a specific industrial relations project which is worth mentioning briefly. Since February 1993, our development assistance program has funded a program called Australian support for ILO objectives in Asia, or ASILO. It provides advice and expertise to assist labour ministries, employer organisations and trade unions in a number of countries, including Thailand. Thailand has voluntarily involved itself in many ILO projects in recent years.

Phase 1 of this program will finish in December and phase 2 is planned to begin in 1996. It will last for four years. The committee has recommended its implementation, especially the emphasis on training in Australia. This is the sort of positive contribution that Australia can make to assist Thailand to remedy the defects in the training and education aspects of its industrial safety structure.

Australian involvement in this field is not limited to this sort of project. By the end of 1995 a tripartite working party, headed by the redoubtable honourable member for Holt (Mr Duffy), will have reported on labour standards in the Asia-Pacific region. The other members of this working party are the President of the ACTU; the National Chief Executive of the Australian Chamber of Manufactures, Mr Allan Handberg; the Director of Marketing and Industrial Policy of the New South Wales Chamber of Manufactures, Ms Narelle Kennedy; and Mr Alan Oxley of International Trade Strategies.

The terms of reference for this working party are very broad. While I will not bore honourable members by reading them out, it is clear that they do not seek to blame or single out particular countries for deficiencies in labour standards. Rather, they seek to emphasise the nature and effectiveness of current measures and those which could be taken to address these standards.

We believe that Australia's reputation overseas is important and that this country is judged by the reputation that our companies have in other countries. In this context, it was reassuring to hear from the Thai trade union leaders who have been appointed to Thailand's Senate that we have a positive reputation as employers compared with some other investing nations.

Australian development assistance to Thailand amounted to some $44.9 million in the last financial year. Some of these funds were spent on behalf of organisations such as the Department of Industrial Relations through the ASILO program to which I have just referred. Other programs are funded through bodies such as the Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research, or ACIAR.

While the committee was supportive of our development assistance program to Thailand, it believes this program should be directed towards assisting in the solution of its problems. These include the underdevelopment of the north and north-east of the country, income and opportunity differences between Bangkok and the provinces, poverty alleviation and dealing with major HIV-AIDS problems.

Thailand has made great economic progress over the last few years. It has introduced a development assistance program for its own neighbours. Its problems will not go away, so we are not suggesting the establishment of its program should lead to the cancellation of our projects. The committee does believe, however, that there should be an examination of Thailand's needs for development assistance.

Australia has a significant educational connection with Thailand which earns revenue for various institutions. In December 1994 the Australian International Education Foundation was established to advise on the promotion of international education and training, and exchanges and recruitment of international students. During the inquiry, some concerns were expressed about the foundation's operations. The committee has therefore recommended a review of its effectiveness after the first year of its existence.

Thais have been studying here since the Colombo Plan of the 1950s. Most seem to enjoy their time here and have positive memories and associations. There is therefore a reservoir of goodwill towards Australia among a group of people in Thailand which is now becoming quite important in that country.

During the inquiry we took a good deal of evidence which indicated that the Thais enjoy participating in alumni associations. It was also clear that Australia has, until recently, put too little effort into such bodies in Thailand, although particular institutions do have active chapters.

The committee felt that it was unfortunate that this goodwill was not harnessed effectively. At the same time, we were conscious that administering an alumni scheme through the embassy would involve resources, which are scarce enough without additional programs to administer. We feel that alumni associations are vital ways of retaining Australian connections. Therefore, assessments need to be made of the staffing and other consequences of creating and maintaining an effective network in Thailand. We have therefore recommended a review of current arrangements for the support given to estimate the resources needed to maintain contact with graduates of Australian universities and to introduce an effective system as soon as practicable.

The Australian Defence Force has trained a significant number of Royal Thai Armed Forces personnel in this country. We have recommended that the Department of Defence also examine ways of building and maintaining an effective network in Thailand.

It is not possible for a report like this to reflect all the evidence, written and verbal, which was received during the inquiry. Nevertheless, the committee is grateful to those organisations and individuals who sent in submission and gave evidence. Without these contributions, this report would not have been produced. Similarly, the committee is thankful for the opportunity provided by the government of Thailand to have extensive discussions with their ministers, with advisers and with individuals and organisations. That part of the inquiry was certainly fundamental to its outcome.

One organisation I would particularly like to mention is the Thai-Australian Association of New South Wales. Their submission provided a considerable amount of information about their activities, which include a language school for children and young people which is the largest Thai school in Sydney. Each year for the past 12 years the association has run a Loy Krathong celebration, which attracts significant interest. This association has now been operating for over 35 years and is a key Thai community body in the state of New South Wales. Without its contribution, made with minimal government funding, connections with the Thai community would be much less effective. May their work prosper.

As always, the committee members owe a debt to the secretariat staff for their work on the report. Margaret Cahill, Peter McLay, Lesley Cowen, Tracy Bartrim, Joanne Towner and Patrick Regan all did their bit to put it together, and we thank them. I commend the report to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted that the federal parliament is receiving this report. To my mind, Thailand is important both as a nation within the ASEAN group and as our neighbour and also because of the countries which are its neighbours. Thailand's relations with Burma, Thailand's relations with Cambodia and Thailand's relations with Laos are matters of great importance in this region. It is important for the government and for all Australian parliamentarians to recognise the continued significance of understanding and developing our relationship with Thailand to the maximum.

PARA.TAB: The recommendations in this report are addressed to that end. There are only two that I want to identify. One concerns the funding of the National Thai Studies Centre at the ANU. It is absolutely critical that Thai language be maintained, not only at the ANU but at other universities. I would hope that at secondary and tertiary levels Thai studies can be maintained.

The other concerns the Australian-Thailand Chamber of Commerce in Bangkok, with which I was very impressed when we met them on our visit in 1994. It seems to me, however, that there is a difference between the political and commercial relationship. It is always important for us in Australia to remember that those in the business world who are on site in a country sometimes are not aware of the priorities and emphasis that Australia's relations with a particular country require. At the same time, if we are going to expand our relationship with a country we do rely very much on those who live and work there—in Thailand, in this instance. I commend many of them for the way in which they are committed to our relationship at a commercial and a personal level.

A great deal of the credit for this report goes to the subcommittee chairman, the honourable member for Reid (Mr Ferguson); to the chairman of the main committee, the honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price); and to Patrick Regan and each of the members of the staff of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. It is a worthwhile report. I very much commend its recommendations to the government. I think that, unless we can maintain a new emphasis on the relationship with Thailand, Australia will be the loser.

TALK.START.PARA: —I endorse very much the remarks that previous speakers, especially the honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price), have made on the report of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. Australia and Thailand enjoy a good relationship. As Australia continues to see a role within Asia, this relationship will continue. There is a tremendous amount of goodwill in Thailand towards Australia.

PARA.TAB: I was part of the delegation that went to Thailand, and I have visited that country on a number of occasions. I have always been impressed with the amount of goodwill that exists in Thailand towards Australia. The committee believes that great opportunities exist in Thailand for Australian business, technology and expertise.

But, as there are these opportunities, I hope that Australian businesses operating in Thailand will observe the correct industrial relations law. It would not be good for firms to go from Australia, where they are forced by law to adhere to certain industrial relations law, to Thailand and exploit the situation there. Australian firms operating in Thailand have a responsibility to operate—especially when it comes to occupational health and safety—as they would in Australia.

Next year, 1996, is a very important year in Thailand. In June it will be the Golden Jubilee of His Majesty the King's accession to the throne. Indeed, the first recommendation that the committee made is that the Australian government appropriately recognise this. It is important that our longstanding relationship with Thailand and the goodwill that has existed between the two countries be recognised. Just as many countries contributed to our celebrations in 1988, it is important that this most significant event in Thailand be appropriately recognised in Australia.

One issue that the committee dealt with, which I would like to comment on, is piracies in the waters not only off Thailand but in the area of South-East Asia. I believe that Australia could do more to assist Thailand to combat piracy in South-East Asian waters. I note that AMSA regards this as a matter just for the International Maritime Organisation and has said that it has no part in Australian-Thai relations.

I think it does have a part, because piracy is on quite a significant increase and it does pose a danger to Australian shipping. As it is a crime against humanity, it is regarded seriously under international law. I believe all nations have an obligation to assist in stamping out piracy. I do not think it is enough for us to expect the nations of South-East Asia to deal with this problem on their own. I think we can be of considerable assistance and we should do more to assist in stamping out piracy in this part of the world.

Other speakers have alluded to the good relationship between Australia and Thailand. Good relationships are like family relationships: they do not just happen; they need working on. We cannot ignore the relationship and just expect it to continue. We will have our hiccups every so often in the relationship but, hopefully, the relationship is mature enough to sustain that.

I think there are great benefits to be accrued from both countries. We can assist the Thais and indeed they can assist us. One of the ways we can better expand relationships is through cultural exchanges. I have long felt that politics, political debate and trade are all very important in bringing revenue to the countries concerned, but there is often so much that can be gained through cultural exchanges and cultural visits between the two countries. I would like to see an increase in that area of our relationship.

Like others, I would like to pay tribute to the secretarial staff of the main committee, but especially to the secretariat of the subcommittee. Patrick Regan, who acted as the secretary throughout, did a sterling job and is to be commended. I think this report will become an important work for study for those interested in Australia's relationship with Thailand, one of our most important neighbours. I commend the report to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the member for Chifley wish to move a motion in connection with the report to enable it to be debated on a future occasion?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Price The Hon L.R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the House take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

PARA.TAB: Bill presented by Mr Howard.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Sydney Airport Curfew Amendment Bill, which I have just presented to the House, is similar to a bill that was enacted into law by the parliament some weeks ago, with one important addition—that is, the bill I have just presented to the parliament includes a provision to reopen the east-west runway at Sydney airport. Of course that particular provision and that commitment goes to the nub of the continuing debate surrounding the operation of Sydney airport.

PARA.TAB: The House will remember that some months ago I presented a private member's bill to entrench into law the curfew that had operated at Sydney airport for many years. The government initially decided not to support that bill but, rather, to refer it to the Morris committee. I foreshadowed an amendment proposing the reopening of the east-west runway. The Morris committee returned the bill with a recommendation that some changes be made to the curfew hours, accommodating what are known as shoulder flights. That measure, with the support of the opposition but minus the provision in relation to the east-west runway, was then passed by this House and by the other place.

As a result of an opposition, not a government, initiative, the existing curfew at Sydney airport has now been entrenched in law, and that is a point that needs to be recorded. Despite the government having been in office for 13 years and despite all the rhetoric about sensible policies for Sydney airport, it took an opposition initiative through a private member's bill to incorporate and entrench into law the curfew arrangements at Sydney airport. But, more important than that, the measure now presented to the parliament proposes that the east-west runway be reopened. That is the colloquial description of resuming what might loosely be called `normal' operations of the east-west runway.

In the past couple of months this debate about sharing the burden of noise at Sydney airport has continued very strongly rather than abated. It has continued very strongly because the case argued by those who are now carrying all of the noise burden is a just case and their case has been supported in the past couple of months from three very significant sources.

The House will recall that the argument of the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) is that it is unsafe to reopen the east-west runway. That proposition has been directly repudiated by three absolutely impeccable sources. The first of those was a Mr Bell, a safety consultant, who was engaged by the Labor government several years ago to give advice on safety matters. He said that—far from the operation of the east-west runway in company with one of the north-south runways being unsafe—the danger of accidents from operating the two parallel runways was greater than the use of intersecting runways.

The second was from Mr Pollard, the recently appointed head of Airservices Australia, who, in an inaugural interview from America on the AM program, said that intersecting runways operated all over the world and there was absolutely no safety problem with them.

The third and most significant was the evidence given by United States Aviation Consultancy before the Senate committee. In that committee hearing, Flight Transportation Associates said that there was absolutely no evidence that operating intersecting runways was in any way less safe than operating parallel runways. In fact, some of the evidence presented indicated that there was greater safety in the operation of intersecting runways in the circumstances at Sydney than in the operation of the parallel runway.

So you have three sources, the government safety consultant, the new head of Airservices and Flight Transportation Associates, once again demolishing the Brereton argument, demolishing the government's argument and proving yet again what a blatant political fit-up the closure of the east-west runway has always been and what disgraceful discrimination it represents for the residents under the north-south flight path out of Sydney airport.
Bill read a first time.

PARA.TAB: That the House:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)calls on the Trade Practices Commission to finalise its longwinded decisions which are currently affecting 4500 newsagents across Australia;
(2)draws attention to the Trade Practices Commission that the goodwill built up by these family businesses is often their life savings; and
(3)calls on the Trade Practices Commission to ensure that its recommendations will not reduce the service provided by these family businesses.
I hope that this motion will have bipartisan support. The motion is self-explanatory. It goes to the issue of the newsagency system and the way distribution operates throughout the country.

PARA.TAB: Let me provide some background to this matter. In 1979 the authorisation of newsagency systems was supported by the Fraser government and the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs at the time, the Hon. Wal Fife. It is fair to say that this was not the preferred system of the Trade Practices Commission. In its 1979 draft determination on a request for authorisation by New South Wales publishers in 1978, the commission proposed to refuse authorisation on the basis that the anti-competitive elements of the system did `not result in any benefit to the public'.

The Fraser government was quoted in the newspapers as saying that the widespread availability of newspapers and magazines and the low cost home delivery service were the principal public benefit arising from the system. As a result of the intervention of the Fraser government, the authorisation process went ahead. In 1982, the Trade Practices Commission granted the Victorian authorisation based on considerations similar to those applying in New South Wales. As a result, we have had a system in place for a number of years that has worked very successfully in the distribution of newspapers throughout this country.

In the late 1980s and into the early 1990s, the Trade Practices Commission looked at this issue, releasing a discussion paper on it with a view to possibly revisiting the whole process of distribution and authorisation. On 3 August 1993 the commission brought down a determination. As part of that determination, the Trade Practices Commission said that it had:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . authorised this arrangement, which may otherwise be in breach of the competition law, because the commission believes the public benefits of a low-cost, guaranteed and timely service to readers outweighs the anti-competitive effects of a delivery monopoly.

As a result, the Trade Practices Tribunal in November 1994 came out with a response, setting aside the authorisation. The tribunal said that the commission's decision would have the effect of patching up a system that was ripe for change.

PARA.TAB: As a consequence, hundreds—not tens but hundreds—of people who operate newsagencies around this country and who have been trying to sell them for very valid reasons, including health concerns, financial difficulties and family breakdowns, find that they cannot sell their newsagencies. For example, in Victoria, a newsagency worth over $900,000 was sold for somewhere in the order of $500,000. That is a pretty reasonably sized newsagency when you compare it with others and the price tags they have on them.

The fact of the matter is that people who are in business—these are small business people, the people we should be supporting—are being affected by the lack of quick decisions and determinations through the tribunal approval system. We should be looking to people like newsagents to lead a recovery in this country rather than handicapping and creating difficulties for them. I would like to read from a letter sent to me by an 80-year-old gentleman in my electorate, raising the issue of newsagencies with me. The letter is self-explanatory. He says:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Mr Atkinson,
I am writing to you because I am worried that the home delivery service I enjoy from my local newsagency might be closed down if decisions in Canberra result in so-called "deregulation".

I am 80 years old, I am mostly stuck at home and I don't have the energy I once had to walk miles for a newspaper. I asked for home delivery for exactly this reason. If I had to walk to get a paper, I'd either run out of breath half way or it would take so long that I reckon I'd decide it just wasn't worth the effort every day.

People might say `what would someone my age care about the news anyway'. I don't care how old I am, I still want to know what's going on in the world. Even if I can't read every word of every story in the paper, I like to keep in touch.

If I couldn't get The Sun delivered to my home every day, I'd end up like most people. I'd get my news from the TV or the radio. Well, I think TV is great if all you want is a summary, you love animal stories, you're mad on sport and you care what the weather's going to be tomorrow (as if they're ever right). Radio is even worse, out of five minutes news, one or two minutes are sport and weather. I might be old-fashioned, but if I want to know the weather I just look outside. I want the sort of news and comment that Terry McCrann gives.

Please don't let these people in Canberra destroy a service that I value and which gives so much enjoyment for so little cost. I've already seen what happened to home deliveries of milk and bread, they're "gone with the wind". The banks have been complete mongrels since they were "deregulated"; it seems service is a thing of the past. I would not like to see newspaper deliveries go the same way.

I do not want to get into arguments about the banks or other issues related to that, but let me just say to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that there is a problem with this process. When you look at the newsagency system and the way in which it is structured, and I have spoken to a number of these people now, you find they are prepared to get out and provide a service to the handicapped, to those with difficulties or to those who are sick in our communities. In fact, a number of newsagents actually go out on a regular basis and collect their money from these people because the people cannot get to the newsagencies.

PARA.TAB: I think we need to look a lot more closely at this process as there are something like 4,500 newsagents in this country. The system of distribution that we have at the moment works. These people are contracted to have the newspapers delivered on to the doorsteps of people by 6.45 in the morning. That is not an easy task. You could describe newspapers as perishable—they are probably more perishable than tomatoes—because by midday a newspaper is out of date and you have afternoon newspapers coming in. So it is important to get these papers delivered quickly. When you have to get them out by truck from the centre where they are produced, from the offices of the Herald-Sun or the Age, to the newsagents, it is a pretty decent-sized job to distribute them to 4,500 newsagents around the country. When you add to that the 25,000 subagents around the country, one might ask, `How do they do it?' The answer is, `By providing the sort of service that is provided at the moment.'

Newsagents are able to put together a range of newspapers so they can deliver them in one hit, which means we are getting a financial advantage in the delivery process. If we allow the 7-Elevens or some of the convenience stores such as Shell shops or other shops at petrol stations to have this service, I would be interested to see whether they would be prepared to carry the full range of papers that newsagents carry. Would they be prepared to carry, for example, the Independent, Quadrant, Simply Living or the Social Alternatives newspapers? There are lots of questions that could be asked here. I think the simple answer is that they want to get into it to earn the big quid out of the big volume newspapers. But, when it comes to providing a service across the board, not on your nelly—you won't see it, Mr Deputy Speaker.

I am asking people in Australia, particularly members of this House, to get behind the newsagents. Sure, they might have concerns about the monopolistic approach to it, but they are getting a delivery on time and at a charge they will not get anywhere else. As Mr Johnson, the 80-year-old man said, newspapers will go the same way as bread and milk if we let this fall over.

I for one get the newspaper delivered in the morning. I am quite happy to sit in my pyjamas reading it with a cup of coffee. As sure as hell, I do not want to go to the shop to collect it before I have my cup of coffee. I think small business in this country, particularly newsagencies, needs to be supported. (Time expired)
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Jenkins)—Is the motion seconded?

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion and reserve my right to speak later.

—I am pleased to support the member for Isaacs (Mr Atkinson). He is on the right track. Often, on that side of the House they are not on the right track; but on this matter he is certainly on the right track. I am sure that not one person in the gallery would disagree with the comments he has made.

PARA.TAB: I have attended Labor Party meetings for 34 years; served as an alderman for 15 years, including the three during which I was mayor; and been a member of the federal parliament for 11 years. During that time I have had drawn to my attention a couple of million problems and complaints from all around Australia. I have received complaints about banking, dogs, feral cats, potholed streets, teachers, doctors, lawyers, chemists, policemen, car salesmen, Australia Post, Telstra, hospitals, the taxation department, bus companies, railways, aeroplane noise, petrol prices, politicians—and even mothers-in-law. But surprise, surprise: not once have I heard a complaint about the system used for the distribution of newspapers and magazines.

I had my own complaint once with a newsagent; he used to fail to deliver my newspaper in time for me to read it while I was having breakfast. But that was a complaint due to individual weakness; it was not a complaint about a distribution system which works beautifully.

So there we have it, members: a system which works brilliantly—and the commission wants to change it. Never in the history of humankind has there been a more stupid repudiation of the long treasured maxim, `if she ain't broke, don't fix it.' We have a system which is as near to perfection as any ever devised: a system which ensures an efficient and low cost home delivery of newspapers and magazines. Why the hell would we want to change it?

The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission—that is, the old Trade Practices Commission—chaired still by Professor Allan Fels, has quite clearly become too obsessed with abstract competition theory. It has become overexuberant in its desire to initiate a better deal for consumers. The commission is barking up the wrong tree. Instead of reducing prices for consumers, it is all set to put in place changes which will be quite detrimental to consumers. Instead of bringing in a better system for the sale and delivery of newspapers and magazines, the commission will, through revoking or modifying the current authorisations, leave newsagency and public arrangements in turmoil, in total disarray.

I am not going in to bat for newsagents or publishers; I am not going in to bat for the general public. I say: let the public decide—not the commission. Let the public decide the type of change and the pace of change which is to occur.

We all know that changes to newsagency arrangements have been taking place for some time. We all know that many retailing operations now carry a wide range of material which previously was carried only by newsagents, and that newsagents themselves have broadened their sales of non-traditional goods and services. However, these changes are occurring at an acceptable pace—a pace resulting from consumer tastes and habits.

The commission, in trying to direct consumer demand, is acting unacceptably; it would be far wiser to go with the flow. The commission has no reason to pat itself on the back over the disorder which has flowed from changes to the authorisation system in Canberra. Direct delivery of the Canberra Times has had a catastrophic effect on Canberra's 60 or so newsagencies. Consumers are receiving a small reduction in the cost of their newspaper, but the Canberra Times practice is bulldozing small businesses throughout the national capital.

The method of delivery of the Canberra Times is having a detrimental effect not just on newsagencies but on other businesses in shopping centres which used to have a newsagency. Many suburban shopping centres are in serious decline because of the loss of their newsagency. One would have thought that the local newspaper would be supporting local businesses, not damaging them. Once again—surprise, surprise.

Despite direct delivery by the Canberra Times, the circulation of that paper has shown no increase—absolutely zilch increase. What has happened in Canberra will happen in other cities, in regional centres throughout Australia and in country towns in particular if the commission changes the system in New South Wales, Victoria and Queensland. The pursuit of abstract competition theory will end up destroying the small businesses which operate in shopping centres. Imagine the situation as these big monopoly businesses take over. I read, I think, in the Sunday paper Alan Jones—I do not always agree with Alan Jones; as a matter of fact, very rarely—say that, if this madness continues, the little guy will be squeezed out. A shopping centre which now might have 20 shops will have Woolworths at one end, Coles at the other end and nothing in between. That is where we are heading if some of these mad principles of rationalisation are put into practice.

When this situation eventuates, as it undoubtedly will, unless Allan Fels and his commission see good commonsense, we will not be able to buy those magazines which many of us seek to buy because the only publications that Woolworths, Coles and the big establishments will take are those which have a great demand, and whose sales turn over quickly. If you have an interest which may not be shared by an overwhelming majority of Australians, you will not be able to get those small publications which you can currently get from your local newsagents. That to me would be a great shame because we would be discouraging the widest possible availability of information. The coverage of information and critical comment are vital in a democratic society such as Australia. Rather than allowing the commission to abolish public benefits, we should be insisting that they be maintained because we know one thing: the open market is dictated by the pursuit of profits. We just will not get these smaller publications through the open market system.

Many home delivery customers, as the honourable member for Isaacs mentioned, are housebound due to old age, failing health, disability, illness, or something of that nature. As the member for Isaacs said, they are not going to be able to walk to the corner shop, they have not got a car in which they can shoot off to the supermarket and they need their home delivery. If newsagents and the home delivery system are not allowed to continue, people will be denied access to that information. The commission wants to see the loss of home delivery in areas which are simply uneconomic to service. This is absolute madness. It is significant that all speakers today from different sides of the political fence are concerned about social factors and not economic theory. No doubt the commission would favour the abolition of Australia Post mail deliveries. People in the Hunter do not want to see the loss of their newsagents and home delivery. I am sure the constituents of other electorates throughout Australia feel the same way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nugent Mr P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to second this motion today. I commend the member for Isaacs (Mr Atkinson) for its introduction. There are a couple of remarks made by the previous speaker, the member for Hunter (Mr Fitzgibbon)—although he and I often disagree on many issues—that I agree with. I have a similar view about Alan Jones but, more importantly, he made a comment about Canberra. My understanding from my colleague the honourable member for Canberra (Mr Smyth), who sits on my left, is that where the distribution has been affected in this town it has had a flow-on effect not only to the newsagents but also to many of the other businesses in the shopping strips because foot traffic is not being generated to the newsagencies and other businesses suffer as well.

PARA.TAB: The motion that is before us calls on the TPC to finalise its review in this area. It draws attention to the importance of the goodwill built up in the family businesses and it calls on the commission to ensure that its recommendations will not reduce service provided by those businesses. One of the things the newsagents themselves have done, as I understand it, has been to organise a parachute drop out the front today to deliver some 25,000 petition signatures to this parliament. I think it is important that we take every means possible to draw to the attention of the nation this particular issue, which is very important.

There are slightly different rules, as I understand it, between states. In Victoria we have had a couple of reviews—in 1982 and again in 1983. Now we have this current review by the TPC or what is now called the ACCC. The essence of the argument, as I understand it, is that publishers agree to deliver only to certain authorised newsagents in prescribed territories who, in turn, use subagents. The proposal being looked at is that there should be no guaranteed territories.

In the brief time I have I would like to read from a letter I received from one of my local newsagents Mountain Gate in my electorate, covering the eastern suburbs of Melbourne. My local newsagent says:

For over 100 years newsagents have played a vital role in the social and commercial fabric of the local community. In an era of giant supermarkets and chain stores, we are one of the last remaining bastions of family owned and operated retail businesses, offering traditional friendly and personal service to our customers.

SPEECH.PARA: He goes on to talk about the matters that previous speakers have raised; the importance of home delivery; the fact that it costs about 50c a week, or 8c or 9c a day, to get your papers delivered; and the number of people who are affected. There are social as well as economic implications. I think it is important that we understand the vital role local newsagencies play in our community.

PARA.TAB: What the TPC is trying to tell us is that the current arrangements are outdated; that others, such as convenience stores, should have the same treatment; that newsagents often operate to disadvantage some of the subagents and they need some competition; and that there is no evidence overseas to show that exclusive territory gives a particular consumer benefit. Let me say that, if other things were changed by this government in terms of making small business more profitable, then maybe you could run that rationalist line. But the coalition has a very clear perspective on where it stands on this position: to support the continuation of the current system of distribution for newspapers and magazines with one accredited newsagent for a particular territory.

We believe this system provides a significant public benefit in its provision of a low-cost efficient home delivery service for daily morning newspapers as well as facilitating the widespread availability of a broad range of publications. The coalition recognises that successful small business enterprises such as newsagencies are the base from which our national recovery must be built.

As I say, it is important that newsagents have an opportunity to protect their investment. Many of them—for example, my local newsagent in his letter, which is too lengthy for me to read in the time I have—talk about the investment not only in people, family and skills but also in the new technology, the new equipment, they have introduced with the expectation that under the present system it will bear fruit. To take that out from under them is incorrect. It does not provide the right service for the community. It is something which I would object to, as would most of my colleagues in this House. I very strongly commend the motion to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —I commend the honourable member for Isaacs (Mr Atkinson) for the motion now before the House. I, like many members on both sides of the House, have been contacted by our local newsagents with their concerns at what the TPC might do in this area. In the course of those discussions, many interesting perspectives have been demonstrated to us by those newsagents and family businesses, perspectives which many of us would have not understood in this area. I will not canvass all the arguments that have been raised here by honourable members before me. But, when we look at these sorts of issues, we see that there are inherent dangers in a competition policy that does not pay due attention to the benefits that customers will receive from any changes to existing policy and, indeed, any impact on the structure of small business in this country—in this case, the newsagents.

PARA.TAB: During my contribution here today, I would like to add a few words on the effects that any adverse TPC ruling might have on customers and on local economies. As far as customers are concerned, I think it is fair to say that the newsagents' network in this country provides very good customer service. There are very few businesses in business today that are as able to home deliver in such a cost-efficient manner as newsagents are.

But, more importantly, newsagencies tend to be a focus of social activity in local shopping centres as well as a focus of economic activity. When you talk to newsagents, they tell you about people who make their one daily trip down to the newsagents to have their social contact for the day and to chew over the problems of the district with the newsagent. For those people who invariably walk to the newsagents—and they are older people—there is also a considerable health and welfare benefit that flows from the fact that there is a familiar face in the shopping centre, that they do have to walk to get there, and the social discourse that takes place.

As far as the newsagents are concerned, they have purchased their businesses on the premise that certain structures might endure. We all know that things do not last forever; nevertheless, these people have invested their life savings in businesses that really rely on the existing network arrangements. It is very important that these sorts of factors are taken into account by the TPC in its deliberations.

I now move to elements of the local economy. I have been informed by newsagents in my electorate of Corio that there are some 33 newsagencies in Geelong and surrounding districts, and 31 one of those are located in strip centres—in very localised shopping districts. I do not think we ought to underestimate the impact that an adverse TPC ruling will have not only on the newsagents concerned but also on the ancillary businesses that occupy these shopping centres. Apart from the supermarket, the newsagent is the one other critical business that does attract people down to the strip. Not everybody who goes out every day buys food but, if they are into a ritual, they invariably do buy a newspaper, and some of their spending occurs in the other businesses in the centre.

In the Geelong region the newsagents employ 356 people, a sizeable business if you take it collectively. When we look at regional economies, we find that there is unlikely to be employment growth in the public sector and there will not be substantial employment growth in the big private companies. The only other area of growth is in small businesses like the newsagents. As you can see from the figures that I have quoted, they are significant employers in the Geelong region. I commend the motion to the House. (Time expired)

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. N.B. Reid)—The time allotted for this debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Monday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cobb Mr M.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this Parliament:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)acknowledges that many country towns have either no doctor or an inadequate number of doctors to service their needs despite making every effort to attract doctors to their towns;

(2)believes that, despite initiatives undertaken to make rural medicine more attractive to both undergraduates and graduates, the acute shortage of country doctors remains and will continue for at least some years;

(3)recognises that Australian citizens who have been trained overseas and who meet the necessary Australian qualifications and examination standards be given preference to be registered to practise in country areas where already registered Australian doctors cannot be attracted to fill positions of shortage;

(4)recommends that in normal circumstances no overseas doctors be given temporary residence permits to fill positions of doctor shortage in Australia in preference to willing Australian citizens who have appropriate qualifications; and

(5)calls on the Government to re-examine and renegotiate the arrangement whereby unlimited numbers of surplus New Zealand doctors are registered to work in Australia unless they are prepared to work in areas of shortage, especially while Australian university entrance numbers have to be cut to accommodate this inflow.

I particularly want to highlight in this debate the lack of medical doctors in many country towns, particularly remote area towns, and also put forward a possible solution to overcome the short-term shortage of these doctors.

PARA.TAB: All of us in this parliament would appreciate what is happening in country towns and the difficulty we have in getting doctors. Doctor shortages arise in one town, which with a great deal of effort are solved, then the shortage bobs up in another town. It seems to be an ongoing problem which is getting worse. In fact, in some towns of some size in my electorate there is no doctor at all.

I will start by quoting some background figures. Over the last 10 years we have had an increase of 12,000 doctors in Australia in total. The latest figures for the end of the 1994-95 financial year show that there were 39,812 doctors in Australia, which is roughly one doctor per 450 of the population—a very high level indeed. Some would say we have an excess of doctors in this country, but we have a maldistribution of those doctors. We have an oversupply overall, but we particularly have an oversupply in the city areas and a dearth in country areas. I think that needs to be stated.

We also probably appreciate the reasons why doctors do not like going to country areas. In many cases they are on their own and do not have backup, particularly from big hospitals, as they do in the cities. They find it very difficult to get relief from the constant 24-hour work when they are on call all the time. They find it very difficult to get locums so that they can get holidays. In many cases they have little or no peer support for the responsible work that they are doing.

Insurance costs are driving obstetricians out of country towns. Doctors' families do not like living in these towns because the spouses of the doctors are often professionals themselves and they cannot find jobs. Also, it is believed, though I do not believe it is always the case, they can make more money in the city areas. Of course, the dedicated doctors that do go to country towns now find that when all this is thrown in they burn out after two or three years and leave the town and the town cannot get a replacement doctor.

I know that in recent times a national rural health strategy has been put in place, which has given money incentives for doctors to practise in rural areas. Professional support, support for the families, training for the doctors, relief for the doctors and also an upgrading of facilities and equipment are also being offered. While that is welcome, sadly it is not solving the problem, certainly not in the short term, though I believe it will have some impact in the medium to long term. The success of that program, welcome though it is, is quite limited. Of course, on top of that, many shires are looking to expand the Newcastle university model and also to offer things like scholarships to students from rural areas to go to university to become doctors in the hope that they will be more inclined to come back to country areas.

In the meantime in areas of need, particularly remote areas, we still have this shortage of doctors. Towns can advertise, at great expense, until they are blue in the face. I know that Trangie, a little town in my electorate, spent $10,000, which is a lot of money for that town, advertising for a doctor before it got one. Fewer and fewer numbers of Australian doctors are going to these towns. It is an enormous problem overall. Some towns in my electorate do not have a doctor at all.

My electorate, based on Dubbo and Broken Hill, is the largest in New South Wales, taking in 40 per cent of the state. A number of towns in my electorate are in dire need of medical services. I will just run through some of the towns to give the House some idea of the problem. Dubbo has a population of nearly 38,000 people and has 43 doctors. On the Australian average of one doctor to approximately every 500 people, Dubbo should have 76 doctors. Parkes has a population of 10,000 people and has seven general practitioners when it probably should have 20 doctors if it had the Australian average. Forbes is a town with a population of 8,500 people and is in dire need of more doctors.

Broken Hill has a population of about 23,000 people and has 16 doctors when it should have well in excess of 30. Cobar has a population of 5,500 people and was down to one doctor at one stage. However, Cobar now has three doctors following a massive effort by the council to attract two further doctors to the town. However, on the Australian average the town should have 11 doctors. Condobolin, which was down to one doctor, now has two doctors and, hopefully, another one will be starting next month. With a population of 3,500 people Condobolin probably should have seven doctors.

Lake Cargelligo has a population of about 1,250 people and has just secured another doctor—welcome news—because the sole doctor in the town was suffering from burn-out and was just about to chuck it in. Bourke and its surrounds has a population of 4,300 people and has three general practitioners when it should have eight. Nyngan, with a population of 2,500 people, has two general practitioners when it should have five. Narromine has a population of 3,500 people and has three general practitioners when it should have seven. Brewarrina has a population of 1,500—2,200 when you take in the whole shire because it covers a vast area—and has only one doctor. The town is in some danger of losing the doctor and will end up with none when it should have three or four.

Warren has a shire population of 3,000 and has only two GPs when it should have six. Wilcannia is a town of 1,000 people, 85 per cent of whom are Aborigines, and does not have a doctor at all. The town has not had a doctor for years when it should have at least two doctors. Wilcannia, White Cliffs, Ivanhoe, Tibooburra and Menindee have no doctors and can only be serviced by the Royal Flying Doctor Service. I am very grateful for that service.

That is a pen portrait of my electorate. No doubt other country members could tell a similar story. When Australian doctors will not go to these towns the federal government will allow doctors from overseas into the country on temporary visas for periods of one or two years to fill these areas of need. That is very welcome and it has worked reasonably well. I know of the role those people have played with the Royal Flying Doctor Service in my own electorate in filling those positions.

We have something like 700 Australian citizens who have received medical training overseas but who cannot obtain registration in this country. It seems odd to me that doctors who are Australian citizens, who speak English well and who, in most cases, meet the necessary Australian qualifications, cannot be registered here in preference to foreign doctors. It seems to be a crazy situation, particularly when many of these people are willing, if registered, to go out to these remote towns and practise. They would be willing to sign on the dotted line, or whatever it takes, and undertake to stay there for five years, 10 years, or more. I believe the government should give preference to those people.

New Zealand doctors are pouring into this country as a result of the oversupply in their own country. They have no restriction placed upon them whatsoever. Those doctors are going to urban areas rather than to remote country areas. This is another area which urgently needs looking at. I stress to the government that it should be looking to register overseas trained doctors who are Australian citizens and who meet the Australian qualifications so that they can go out and practise in country areas where they are desperately needed.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. N.B. Reid)—Is the motion seconded?

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

—All Australians should have equity of access to medical services, but they don't. Rural doctors now face the greatest maldistribution of the medical work force ever experienced in peacetime Australia. Rural communities of up to 3,000 people have not had a general practitioner for two or three years and there are more than 500 vacancies in rural practice. I saw a cartoon drawing the other day which showed a road sign on a road which meandered through a country village. The road sign read, `Last GP for 2,000 kilometres.'

PARA.TAB: No-one would disagree that the maldistribution of medical practitioners in Australia is tragic and intolerable, but one would be wrong to believe that the problem is one of recent origin. Rural communities have become doctorless increasingly over the past 50 years and coalition governments did nothing to reverse the trend. Now the coalition, particularly the National Party, is trying to gain political advantage from the shortage of family medical services in rural Australia. It is working on the principle that country people have short memories and will believe that the shortage of rural GPs has developed only since 1983 and as a result of the policies of the dreadful Labor Party. In fact, the opposite is true, as I will point out later.

New South Wales Farmers Association Vice-President, John Cobb—possibly a relative of the National Party's Mr Michael Cobb, the member for Parkes, who moved the motion which is before the House—has called for a dramatic shift in government policy to alleviate the shameful shortage of doctors in rural areas. I know the dramatic shift envisaged by Mr John Cobb is not intended to take us back to the days of Menzies, Fraser and company when there were no policies and zilch expenditure to correct the shortage of medical services in sparsely isolated areas.

The two Mr Cobbs are not alone in their concern about the unequal distribution of Australia's medical work force. Three or four million Australians, including this speaker, are equally concerned. People who have the greatest understanding of this problem and know just how complicated it is will agree that a solution will be more speedily achieved if political parties work in charitable cooperation rather than try to score cheap political points.

In this folder—for all to see—is a host of research publications addressing the shortage of medical services in rural areas. All this research was undertaken during a period of Labor government. I do not want to play the political game so I will make this my last partisan point: these publications cover policy, projects and expenditure to attract doctors to rural practice. Go to any library—go to every library—and you will find no evidence of comparable policy, projects and expenditure undertaken by coalition governments.

The reasons why doctors are reluctant to practise in the bush are well documented. But how to get them to practise in rural communities is tremendously complex and cannot be answered adequately in the short time available. Members will know that very few school leavers from country areas gain entry to medical school. So city graduates do their internship in major hospitals in the city and do not set up their shingle in unfamiliar rural environments. Doctors can earn more money in the city with more patients, lower medical defence insurance premiums, a better chance of mum getting a job, better access to parents and relatives, better educational opportunities for the kids and more leisure and family time for the doctor.

Most city GPs do no procedural work and lack the confidence and technical competence to do anaesthetics, obstetrics and surgery. In Australia we have doctors trained in New Zealand and other countries as well as full fee-paying overseas students graduating from Australian medical schools. Mr Cobb and others suggest that such people could somehow be bonded to serve the qualifying period in country practice. But such schemes have not worked, will not work and cannot work because in this country civil conscription and discriminatory practices are not acceptable.

We find that overseas trained doctors who come to Australia say they will go to country areas and become accredited but they stay in the country only a short while. They want to drift back to the cities where their own people congregate. It sounds all right, but it does not work. The best we can do, as we have learned from the USA and Canada, in tackling this problem is develop more flexible and innovative selection, training and working arrangements, and employ strategies to increase the number of rural based GPs and specialists.

We are doing all the above things, and more, and we are doing them darned well, particularly since the 1992 budget when $25 million annually was allocated to the rural incentives program to improve the access of rural Australians to general practice services. We are using affirmative action pathways to get more rural students into medical schools. Until 1991 or 1992 virtually nothing was done but now a Labor government has concentrated its efforts on trying to get medical services into rural Australia.

In association with medical professional bodies we have designed special training programs in rural medicine. People with medical skills, from all universities in all states, are cooperating splendidly. Pilot programs are being run. Medical students are spending more time in rural areas as part of their training. RMOs are being seconded to positions in rural areas. Technology is being introduced to reduce professional isolation of rural doctors. Specialist training places are being established in major rural centres across Australia, and pilot schemes for specialist medical services delivery are being established in rural and remote areas.

Funding from bodies such as the rural incentives program has transformed the focus on rural and remote area health and the imbalance in the distribution of the medical work force is being better addressed than ever before. The media report that Mr John Cobb and the National Farmers Federation have welcomed many of the schemes being implemented. They realise, as we all should realise, that 1991-92 was not so many years ago. This solution to the problem of the lack of medical service in remote Australia will not be solved quickly. The neglect which went on for so many years will take time to overcome. It will take a long time and it will cost a motza. This government is determined to pursue every possible strategy so all Australians will have equity of access to health services.

We are moving as fast as is humanly possible; we are spending a fortune trying to get doctors in rural areas. The strategies that we have adopted are as a result of widespread consultation. Everyone who knows the seriousness and complexity of the problem is applauding this government for its efforts to make sure that people in rural Australia get the access to and equity in health services that they deserve.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the motion of the member for Parkes (Mr Cobb), and I congratulate and thank him for bringing this extremely important matter to the notice of the federal parliament. As the member for Parkes has pointed out, the dearth of doctors and other health professionals is certainly endemic to most parts of rural Australia.

PARA.TAB: I was interested in the contribution of the member for Hunter (Mr Fitzgibbon).
