It is obvious that he has an understanding of the shortage because he lives in a rural area, but I point out to him that the present government has been in office for 13 years now. He mentioned 1991-92, at which time Labor had been in government for 10 years. During that period, the situation had grown worse. So it certainly took a long while for the government to realise that there was a problem in rural Australia.

I welcome the establishment of the national rural health strategy by the federal government. I know it will take time to implement. Even with this strategy in place, I think we are still going to have major problems. I think governments really have to make some strong decisions if they are going to provide proper health care by health professionals in rural areas.

In my many years in the federal parliament, health care has been one of the most pressing problems in the Riverina electorate. Although some recent positive moves have been made to try to overcome the problem in the long term, I have my doubts about the outcomes. The member for Parkes mentioned a number of towns in his electorate in which there is a shortage of doctors, and I could do the same for my electorate. I will not go over that, except to say that the situation gets worse day by day.

The problem is extremely complex. One of the impediments to progress is that under the present health care regime a medical practitioner can nail his shingle up just about anywhere in urban Australia and make a reasonable living. The member for Hunter alluded to that. Why, then, would a health professional leave the coast and the surf, the Opera House and theatre, his or her fellow professionals and their backup tertiary learning institutions, and their opportunity to keep up with the latest health and medical developments, to move to rural Australia where he or she can expect to tend patients with every known malady for 24 hours a day, nearly 365 days a year, with hardly any backup or support? Considering that most health professionals are married to professionals, moving to rural Australia also means finding a position in a rural area so that the partner can also obtain work in their own profession.

It is not just a matter of remuneration, because most health professional positions now vacant have excellent remuneration packages but still no takers are available. There has been a call for overseas doctors to fill the gap. Many rural areas are totally dependent on doctors who have come from overseas, who are doing excellent work. There are complex issues about overseas qualifications, and these can be worked out by examinations for competency. I do not believe this to be the longer term answer when we already have a surplus of doctors in Australia.

One doctor formerly from overseas, Dr Ganesha Thambipillay, known affectionately as Dr Pillay, has earned for himself a wonderful reputation at the Griffith Base Hospital as a dedicated paediatrician; however, he has recently announced that he will be leaving Griffith. When he came to Griffith in 1987 there were no paediatric services, nor a special care nursery. Along with the community, he has developed these services but has paid the price of turning into a workaholic, working 24 hours a day and seven days a week. Some time ago he said that he felt he needed a break because he feared he would burn out and be of little use to the community. He went on to say that there was no way one person could handle the workload and that there was no support available to him.

Dr Pillay is moving to Wagga Wagga, a larger centre in which to practise, where he will have support from other paediatricians. He will be an asset to that community, but will leave Griffith and district in a very unfortunate situation, particularly those parents of children who have terminal illnesses. The interesting thing about Wagga Wagga is that this large centre—it is certainly a nice place to live—is itself short of at least seven general practitioners. Of course, in the smaller towns where there is only one doctor, once the doctor goes the pharmacy goes and then other infrastructure is lost to the town also.

The Riverina is short of therapists of all kinds. We do not have one resident psychiatrist for well over 100,000 residents and do not look like obtaining the services of one. There are tremendous pressures on the community in that area. Most would know that if you need psychological help you often need it immediately.

I could go on about the subject, but time does not permit. I just remind the government of the fact that, if it wishes to drag its feet on the matter of providing an adequate number of health professionals to rural Australia, it will be acting against the best interests of those people in rural Australia who still provide two out of every three of Australia's export dollars. If governments wish these people to keep producing that wealth, there is an obligation on them to support these people. One of their prime needs is the provision of an adequate number of health professionals for their health care needs.

I welcome the national rural health strategy. I hope the involvement of this organisation and the moves put in place by the government do bring about an increase in the number of doctors and other health professionals available to rural Australia.

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. N.B. Reid)—Order! The time allotted for this debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Monday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dodd Mr P.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this House:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)calls on the Commonwealth Government to initiate a code of conduct for Australian corporations operating overseas, especially in developing countries;
(2)is concerned with the continuing pollution of the Ok Tedi and Fly Rivers and the potential pollution of the waters of Torres Strait;
(3)urges the Commonwealth Government to put the maximum pressure on BHP to take all the necessary steps to prevent future pollution of PNG waters and the Torres Strait;
(4)notes that the continuance of uncontaminated waters is essential to the health and lifestyle of the people of the Torres Strait; and
(5)calls for the continuing monitoring of pollution and contamination of sea life in the Torres Strait.

In bringing this motion before the House, I am raising a matter of obvious concern to my constituents in Far North Queensland, and in particular the Torres Strait. These matters should be of concern to all Australians and all members of this House. Unfortunately, the activities of the Big Australian, BHP, have brought shame on the nation. There is clearly a need for a code of conduct for Australian based transnational corporations operating outside Australia, especially in the developing world. I welcome the government's initiatives in this regard and the fact that the Environment Protection Agency is convening a process, together with the ACF and the Minerals Council of Australia, to determine general environmental standards in this regard. I understand that my colleague the honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Tanner) will discuss further that aspect of the motion.

PARA.TAB: The sorry saga of Ok Tedi has been in the media for some time. It is a battle that involves the landowners, their solicitors Slater and Gordon, BHP and the Papua New Guinean government. Unfortunately, there has been little media attention given to the potential effect of continuing the contamination of the waters of the Torres Strait as well as other waters off the Papua New Guinea coast.

The Ok Tedi-Fly River system, where it meets the Gulf of Papua, discharges at the rate of 6,000 cubic metres per second or nine times that of the Murray-Darling river system before it was dammed. To state that a non-polluted, non-contaminated Torres Strait is vital to the future health and wellbeing of the people of the Torres Strait is to state the obvious. A baseline study funded by the Australian government through the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority was inconclusive about the level of contamination, but any Torres Strait Islander will supply you with anecdotal evidence about what they believe to be the contamination of vital seafood in the Torres Strait.

Each day, the Ok Tedi mine processes 80,000 tonnes of ore from which copper is extracted. As the average copper content of the ore is only 0.7, 40,000 tonnes a day is discharged as tailings. The tailings contain low concentrations of heavy metals such as cadmium, lead and zinc. As only 85 per cent of the copper is extracted, there are also significant quantities of unextracted copper. The baseline study cautiously concluded that `the concentration of arsenic, cadmium, copper, selenium and zinc in the edible portion, particularly in liver and kidney tissues, of some foods consumed by Torres Strait Islanders repeatedly appear at larger doses to or above the National Health and Medical Research Council's maximum permitted concentration for seafoods'. These foods include Murray Island sardine, green turtle and dugong. Their conclusion—it is very conservative—is that the metals arsenic, cadmium and selenium are not believed to be associated with the Fly River discharge to any appreciable degree but that copper may be.

What is not in doubt is that the Ok Tedi mine has caused pollution to the Ok Tedi and Fly rivers. It has also caused damage to what is estimated to be 30 square kilometres of forests and gardens in Papua New Guinea. There also seems to be no doubt that some of the heavy metals have made their way into the vital food chain of the Torres Strait. That is why my motion before the House talks about the need for a further study and the constant monitoring of this situation.

There is also no doubt that the Ok Tedi mine provides vital export earnings for Papua New Guinea. They are in need of foreign exchange and, of course, the mine provides employment but the question is at what cost to both the people of Papua New Guinea and my constituents in the Torres Strait, who gain no economic benefit from the mine.

The Victorian Supreme Court has held that it does not have jurisdiction to order BHP to construct a viable tailings dam at the Ok Tedi mine site. There is no doubt that the building of a dam would be a difficult proposition. The mine owners from the beginning argued against building such a dam. On the insistence of the Papua New Guinean government construction of a tailings dam was commenced in 1983, only one year before mining was to commence. In 1984, before the mine was even started—and I am sure before construction was even started—a landslide smothered the site and collapsed the dam. It was then abandoned.

The then general manager of what was then OTML—now the mine is owned by BHP—Mr Irwin Newman said, `The landslip setback was partly the company's fault because no intensive geological tests were carried out before the work got under way.' He also said, to his great shame I suggest, `There comes a point where you can't keep throwing money at a project.' So the tailings dam was abandoned and negotiated in its place was an agreement with the Papua New Guinean government to allow it to dump tailings directly into the Ok Tedi and Fly River system. That is the situation today.

Right from the beginning, the Ok Tedi mine was exempt from Papua New Guinea's environmental legislation. In February 1992 the international water tribunal stated that BHP `should thoroughly investigate the possibility of safe storage and treatment of wastes'. That has not happened. The controversial legislation before the Papua New Guinean parliament included a commitment from the Papua New Guinean government to undertake an independent study into the viability of a tailings dam.

There is another provision in that original legislation which says that compensation to Papua New Guinean landowners can stop if the dam is built. Under that legislation, a tailings dam remains an option for BHP. BHP has undertaken an expensive media campaign in Australia. I would suggest that it is money misspent; it would be better spent in finding a solution to this problem.

I acknowledge the work of the Australian Conservation Foundation in this matter, in particular Dr Helen Rosenbaum and Mr Michael Krockenberger who presented a report in November 1993 which first brought this matter to the public's notice in the way of a comprehensive report. At the time the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) passed a letter from the ACF to the then Prime Minister of PNG, there was some action promised but nothing happened.

With due respect to the honourable member for Melbourne, who will be seconding my motion, I ask: would there be a question of cost if the pollution was in the Yarra River instead of the Fly and Ok Tedi rivers, or would it be too hard or too costly to stop or at least mitigate pollution if the dam was outside of Melbourne or outside of Sydney? These are legitimate questions that my constituents can ask.

This is no light matter. The continuing pollution of the Torres Strait threatens the health and wellbeing of my constituents. There are already enormous health problems in the Torres Strait. The level of diabetes in the Torres Strait is far higher than in any other part of Australia, apart from some Aboriginal communities. Therefore, seafood is vital to the wellbeing of the people of the Torres Strait. This motion is very important in that regard. We must continue to monitor the situation. BHP and the Papua New Guinean government, if they are good neighbours of Australia, must do something about the potential and continuing pollution of the Torres Strait and Far North Queensland.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Newell)—Is the motion seconded?

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

—The member for Leichhardt (Mr Dodd) seemed to be backing the horse both ways: on the one hand, he said that there was some pollution in the Torres Strait area and, on the other hand, he conceded that the Ok Tedi mine was helpful to the New Guinean economy. It is easy for this parliament to have a go at multinational companies, even if they are Australian. It is easy to characterise the Ok Tedi issue as a case of a large Australian company exploiting the people of a developing country.

PARA.TAB: The reality is that BHP and the Ok Tedi mining company have done more for the Western Province of Papua New Guinea than 1,000 Slater and Gordons, 60 Minutes programs or Richard Carletons. I wonder what Slater and Gordon are going to get out of their whole argument. It is paternalistic and patronising for Australian public opinion, without knowing the full facts, to be telling the New Guinean government how best to regulate companies operating within their own borders.

Australia's imposing a code of conduct on BHP operations is no different from the cultural superiority of British colonialists who thought they knew what was best for the natives of underdeveloped countries. This motion raises the issue of whether Australian parliaments ought to be telling other governments how their local industries should be regulated.

BHP has investments in India, Vietnam and South America where local governments have welcomed the benefits of their involvement, their expertise and their capital. These countries have investment opportunities which they cannot fully utilise. They need the investment, capital and expertise that BHP can provide. BHP must be a good corporate citizen since it operates both Australia-wide and internationally. It does not need Australian codes of conduct in order to ensure it behaves responsibly in developing countries. I note that Shell International Petroleum Company Pty Ltd is having some difficulties in Nigeria. All companies operating internationally in future will operate under a sensible code of conduct. I ask: would Australians prefer that there be no Ok Tedi mine in Papua New Guinea?

The company accepts that there are environmental effects from the discharge of sediments into the Ok Tedi River, and the member for Leichhardt made that point. However, BHP claims that there are no toxic substances flowing into the river. The environmental effects of the discharges are temporary and things will quickly return to their pre-mine state shortly after the mine ceases production. A tailings dam is not feasible, and the member for Leichhardt concedes that point. The company has spent enormous amounts of money trying to get a tailings dam in position. The company and the PNG government have made every effort to ensure that the mine provides local people with some permanent benefits long after the mine runs out.

I turn to the environmental issues which the member for Leichhardt is so worried about. It is important to bear in mind that there are environmental effects in the Ok Tedi and Fly river systems. These effects are reversible and no toxic substances are discharged into the rivers. That is the key element: they will return to their pre-mine state because of the climatic effect. The area of the mine is unique because of the steep slopes; extremely high rainfall, which is measured in feet rather than inches; and regular seismic earthquake activity. It is a very difficult part of the world in which to work, and I think the honourable member for Leichhardt concedes that point. There is real geological instability; there are occasional landslides; and, as I said, it is very difficult terrain.

The Ok Tedi mine decided to build a tailings dam in 1993, on which $70 million was spent, and the dam foundations collapsed due to a landslide. The environmental impact of a collapsed tailings dam is far more drastic and hazardous than any ordinary discharge of mining residue into the river system. Since the collapse of the dam in 1984, no fewer than 120 independent studies have been undertaken to find a way to store waste material, but no acceptable means has been found to date. I challenge the member for Leichhardt to refute that position when the company has taken every responsible effort to solve the problem.

Thus the mine, with the permission of the PNG government, discharges sediment into the Ok Tedi River. But the government sets down limits on the amount of sediment which the mine can contribute to the river system. The limit, known as the acceptable particulate level, is 940 milligrams per litre. Typically, the mine's contribution is half the acceptable limit.

It must be remembered that the Fly River carries about 88 million tonnes of natural sediment each year, which is very high by any international standard. That is the key point to some of this argument: there is a lot of natural sediment that moves down the river with the high rainfall. That rather colours the argument that some commentators have made on this particular mine. So we have an unstable natural environment, which causes a large amount of geological activity, and high levels of sediment flowing down the river system.

It is true that the fish numbers in the Ok Tedi River and the upper Fly River have decreased. However, this is reversible, and fish stocks are expected to return to their pre-mining levels very quickly after the mine ceases production. No toxic substances are discharged into the Ok Tedi or Fly rivers. Ok Tedi Mining reports to the government on a weekly basis. What better monitoring program would you want than that? The company's environmental department has 35 staff, three research vessels, helicopters and world-class sampling laboratories. Also, there is a system of external peer review by specialist consultants.

Let us have a look at some of the facts of the Ok Tedi Mining operation. Currently, Ok Tedi Mining is owned 60 per cent by BHP, 20 per cent by Metal Mining Corporation and 20 per cent by the host government, the PNG government. It owns a part of this operation, so it is particularly interested in the outcome. The copper deposit, as members would be aware, was discovered in 1968 and a mining lease was granted to Ok Tedi Mining Pty Ltd in 1981.

A former member of the PNG government from Western Province made the point to me in a presentation that, prior to the commencement of the Ok Tedi mine, Western Province was the most disadvantaged part of Papua New Guinea. So those people from the local area were very keen to see this development take place because of the economic benefits that would flow to their area. They were very pleased to see BHP put up capital in a very risky environment, both in a monetary sense and in a climatic sense.

BHP had to take all the risks, taking into account all those factors. It also faced the uncertainty of world copper prices, as our own Australian producers have done here in the copper mines. Ok Tedi provided the Western Province with a major industry and gave PNG another major mine after Bougainville, just after it had achieved independence. Copper production began in 1987, with BHP as the managing shareholder. The development of the mine has taken eight years and has cost $1.4 billion. That point has been overlooked by the member for Leichhardt opposite. BHP has invested a large sum of money in a fairly risky venture and has been prepared to proceed.

Ok Tedi accounts for some 20 per cent of PNG's total export income. To put this into perspective, 20 per cent of Australia's export income is made up of gold, coal and wool exports. To close down the Ok Tedi mining operation in Papua New Guinea would be equivalent to removing coal, gold and wool from the Australian economy. What member in this parliament would contemplate that sort of action here because of the sorts of arguments that are being run?

Ok Tedi employs nearly 2,000 people; 90 per cent of the work force are New Guinean, citizens. In 1990, Ok Tedi Mining created the Lower Ok Tedi-Fly River Development Trust to provide community assistance and business development to the 107 village communities along the Fly River. We have heard a lot of public comment on the disadvantaged communities. However, they have benefited considerably from the $19.3 million that has been contributed to this trust. Direct payments are made to the villagers, who determine their own community development needs.

Thus the trust has paid for the construction of community halls, classrooms, health care centres, roads and rain water storage tanks. Business initiatives have included commercial fishing and the rubber processing factory. Without Ok Tedi, that part of New Guinea would not have these developments and improvements in their standard of living.

In conclusion, it is easy to criticise the multinational companies for their performance in developing countries but much more difficult to actually assist the local people to develop a self-sufficient future. We have a situation where the company is actually helping the people on the ground to develop their own industry in their own area and improve their standard of living. The people of Papua New Guinea need the capital and the mining expertise of a major company like BHP to make the Ok Tedi mine profitable. They need BHP's help.

The PNG government is very unhappy with paternalistic and patronising Australians telling them how to run their operations in very difficult conditions and how to regulate their companies. I think they are even more upset that legal suggestions are emanating from Australia as to how we might upset the PNG government's operation which creates real wealth and improves the standard of living of New Guinean naturalised citizens.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have much pleasure in seconding the motion moved by the honourable member for Leichhardt (Mr Dodd), and I would like to thank the honourable member for Corangamite (Mr McArthur) for reading out the latest press release from BHP for us in the parliament today. I would like to add a couple of points on the factual matters there that I do not think he canvassed.

PARA.TAB: One is that approximately 58 million tonnes of waste is discharged into the Ok Tedi every year by the mine. Assuming that his figures are correct on natural sediment in the Fly River, about 40 million of that 58 million tonnes reaches the Fly River. So something in the vicinity of a 50 per cent increase in the level of sediment reaches the river system and 18 million tonnes approximately is estimated to stay within the Ok Tedi itself. The residence of the sediment is estimated to be roughly 15 years and, contrary to what the honourable member for Corangamite said, as outlined by my friend the honourable member for Leichhardt, there are toxic substances, namely heavy metals, in the discharges which would inevitably be there and, of course, are there in some significant amounts because of the sheer volume of the discharge from the mine.

It is very clear that the mine has caused severe pollution problems: additional turbidity and particularly a loss of fish resources; and for those in many areas downstream a loss of the use of the amenity of water resource and the like. The significance of this can be seen by the fact that the impact is being seen by people as far-flung as the residents of the electorate of the honourable member for Leichhardt. That also indicates that, even though it is predominantly an issue for Papua New Guinea, it is also an issue for Australia. Australian citizens as well as Papua New Guinean citizens are being affected by the mine. The impact in Australia may be relatively limited compared with the impact in Papua New Guinea, nonetheless it still is an Australian issue.

It is true to say that BHP has expended a certain amount of money providing schools, health facilities and the like for some people in the area. But for BHP to proceed along this path is to get very close to an arrogant and almost colonialist assumption that that justifies any behaviour by a large company which, ultimately, is bigger than Papua New Guinea. BHP, as an entity, is bigger than Papua New Guinea and is able to exert that economic power in such a way that it—not the Papua New Guinean government—drives the terms on which the mine exists and operates. Yes, we have to acknowledge that BHP does do some good things, but we need to keep in mind that it does so from a very powerful negotiating position.

Given the point of view put forward by the honourable member for Corangamite, we have to ask why then 71 land-holders representing roughly 30,000 villagers are taking legal proceedings against BHP in the Victorian Supreme Court and rejecting the settlement that the Papua New Guinean government offered of $110 million. Despite the fact that all sorts of tactics have been pursued by BHP to try to separate the villagers from their legal representatives, Slater and Gordon, they are still persisting in their position. We need to ask why they are taking this position. The answer is: because their interests have been irrevocably damaged by what is going on there.

This raises very difficult issues. The honourable member for Corangamite is quite right: it would not be appropriate for us to adopt a neo-colonialist attitude of going in to tell the sovereign government of another country how it should conduct its affairs. Equally, the obverse of this position is just as reprehensible. We are told, for example, that a tailings dam is too expensive, impossible or whatever. In reality, this is code for: if we had a tailings dam, because of the individual circumstances, it would make the product of the mine uneconomic—we would not be able to sell it on the world market.

Because it competes with other copper producers and gold producers, this creates a situation where a Dutch auction occurs on environmental issues, human rights issues and the like right across the country. If you have a relatively weak government which is unable to enforce those sorts of issues, then the market drives down the price and the market drives down consideration given to such matters. So these are things to which we do have a responsibility to give consideration and more and more, as the world internationalises economically and Australians invest more and more overseas, we are going to confront those issues.

There is CRA in Bougainville, Shell in the Ogonis area of Nigeria, BHP and others in Chile, and the list goes on. Australians will be more and more involved and, if we just rely on the local law, that is a moral and economic cop-out. Are we prepared, for example, to see Australian investment in a racist society, in something similar to the old South Africa, or in economies that use child labour widely, or are we going to take some sort of moral stand?

I applaud the initiatives of the government, and also the involvement of the Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities, of which I am a member, in pursuing the issue of a code of conduct for Australian companies overseas. No, we should not be seeking to apply Australian law overseas, but there is a middle path, which means that there is some potential for us to influence how our companies behave and how they put forward Australia's good name overseas, and how they impact on the position of other people in countries such as Papua New Guinea. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —It seems to me that there are two core issues we are talking about in regard to this motion. One is the impact of activity in Papua New Guinea, and any obligations or whatever there are in terms of our and BHP's responsibilities there and the actions of Australia and Australians in that connection; and, secondly, the flow-on impact on Australia, that is, the Torres Strait islands, of what may be happening in PNG. I think it important that we understand there are those two fundamentally connected but different elements.

PARA.TAB: The motion talks about a code of conduct, concern about pollution at Ok Tedi, pressuring BHP to prevent future pollution, the impact on the Torres Strait islands and that it is essential to ensure there is a continued clean environment. It also talks about monitoring the waters in the Torres Strait area on an ongoing basis. I would have to say that I agree with most of the matters raised in the motion. Whether you have been to Ok Tedi or not, you would only have had to have seen the 60 Minutes or Four Corners programs, or seen the evidence that BHP themselves present at briefings, to understand there is pollution there and that those in the company themselves acknowledge it. The PNG government acknowledges it; there is really no doubt about that.

Some of what we see on television and in the newspapers is undoubtedly sensationalised and some of it is not very objective. But there is no doubt there is a fundamental pollution problem and we have to decide what we want to do about that. It seems to me that BHP has started to understand the problems and has started to react. We have seen that in some of the advertisements that it has run recently; we have seen it in some of the briefings of parliamentarians that have taken place.

At the nub of it, of course, is the classic argument about economic benefit versus the environment, which seems to me to crop up in so many areas of activity today. As my colleague the honourable member for Corangamite (Mr McArthur) said so correctly, this mine represents 20 per cent, one-fifth, of the PNG economy, and it has brought some benefits to a relatively small number of people. It is critical for that nation's future development. We cannot get away from the fact that obviously that will affect the decisions that are made in respect of BHP's activities at Ok Tedi.

I certainly support part (2) of the motion which talks about the concern regarding the continuing pollution of the Fly River and monitoring in the Torres Strait. I support part (3) of the motion, that BHP must do everything possible to make sure they do the right thing and that they try in fact to prevent or minimise any damage, if humanly possible. I support part (4) of the motion, noting the potential impact on the Torres Strait. The information I have seen I do not think suggests that the impact on the seas in the Torres Strait is as severe as the honourable member for Leichhardt (Mr Dodd) was suggesting, but it seems to me that is addressed in part (5) of the motion that says yes, we should be doing ongoing monitoring. We need to see whether there is a problem and, if so, take stronger action.

There are a number of outstanding questions. There is the question of PNG's sovereign power and the question of whether it is appropriate for Slater and Gordon to bring these matters to an Australian court. There is the question of whether in fact lawyers are taking advantage of the local people or whether politicians in PNG are taking advantage of the local people. Often it is a moot point, I would have to say.

There are undoubtedly terrible technical problems at the site. It is not easy to mine in that area. An attempt was made to build a tailings dam and it went. I understand that those sorts of things happen quite frequently right across that part of PNG.

In terms of the first part of the motion, the code of conduct for Australian companies, I have no problem in principle with looking to Australian companies acting in a good corporate international citizenship way overseas, and a code of conduct helps. But I do not accept that you do that in isolation. If BHP have those sorts of restrictions and difficulties put on them and they have to withdraw, somebody else will come in. It will not help PNG, it will not help the local people, and it will not cure the pollution problem. It seems to me that where the motion is deficient is that it should not be calling just for a code for Australian companies; it should be calling for the Australian government to negotiate on the international scene for those sorts of codes to apply to all multinational companies.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time allotted for this debate has expired and the debate is adjourned. The resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Monday. The consideration of private members business chosen by the Selection Committee has been completed. It being almost but not quite 2.45 p.m., I will therefore call on statements by members.

—The situation in Sri Lanka concerning the Tamil population is of great concern to all fair-minded people. In my electorate of Lowe I have a large number of Tamils, and I recently addressed a rally of over 300 Tamils at Burwood Park in Sydney. I pledged to these people that I would raise this issue in parliament. I call upon this government, if any request is made of the Australian government by the Sri Lankan government or any other international non-government organisation for either food, medicine, clothing or shelter, to stand ready to give whatever aid is required. I believe there must be a political, not a military, solution to this problem. Given the past and therefore the lack of trust, I understand the Tamils' desire to have the international community act as an honest broker in these negotiations. I believe the Tamils have the right to self-determination, whether it be their own country or their own administration of their territory or whatever workable solution can be properly achieved.

PARA.TAB: The Tamil population in Australia also feel that reporting of the fighting is one-sided. They are, therefore, keen to see that their side of the story not be lost in media reporting. We are all aware that this present round of fighting was provoked by the Tamils breaking the cease-fire. They have their excuses for this, such as milk not getting through to the Tamil territory, but they are now paying a terrible price for this action. In war, truth is the first casualty but innocent victims the next. I call on the Australian government to help in whatever way it can to bring about a negotiated settlement for the Tamils and Sri Lanka.

TALK.START.PARA: —We see the remarkable situation today where a former Prime Minister has returned to his former profession as the chief advocate for the ACTU in supporting the so-called equal work for equal pay principle. I am suggesting that we get equal work for equal pay. The former Prime Minister should be looking very carefully at the case involving the ACTU, which is now facing a major problem regarding its long-term existence. As Secretary Kelty said: `If we do not win this argument, 200 years of trade unionism goes down the drain.' So the former Prime Minister is now riding up on his white charger yet again to try to solve a national problem.

PARA.TAB: What a remarkable situation we have—the ACTU, with the help of the government, holding up the whole nation across the waterfront, the mining industry and any other industry they can involve, to bring about their particular point of view, that of maintaining unionism in Australia. Quite simply, the CRA company wish to implement enterprise bargaining, which is a policy of the present government, instead of award wages. That is their position. They have done that with most of their work force. Yet the government are complaining that their own policy has been implemented, that there are only 73 trade union members left out of the total work force and that that is a terrible thing. So the old Prime Minister comes back. He gets this job and he will be on the white charger yet again—(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not think I would see the day in the 1990s when we would still be debating—after 94 years of federalism and over 100 years, not quite 200 years, of trade union activity in Australia—whether collective bargaining was a legitimate form of bargaining for workers in this country. Don't you worry about the former Prime Minister, Mr Speaker; worry about the principle of this issue.

PARA.TAB: In this day and age, it is quite obvious that the coalition still want to grasp defeat from the jaws of victory at the next federal election. After 94 years they are still trying to win elections on bashing workers and bashing trade unions. With the help of CRA, which obviously funds the Liberal Party to a great extent, they are trying to decimate trade unionism and abolish trade unionism. They are doing it through this grubby dispute that we have seen come to a head in Weipa.

In the Industrial Relations Commission this week, I am sure there will be a positive outcome and a sensible outcome, no matter who the advocate might be for the ACTU. I am sure the rights of workers to get equal pay for work of equal value and the rights of trade unions to collectively bargain on behalf of their membership will be upheld because that is only commonsense and logic. Unfortunately, if the coalition want to continue bashing workers and making industrial relations the election issue—which I cannot believe is true—then they will lose another election. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abbott Mr A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the light of the advocacy of free trade by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) at Osaka this week, it is important to bring to the House's attention an official survey, which was sent to one of my constituents, dealing with the possibility of the establishment of an Australian trading cartel. This survey being conducted by the respected firm KPMG Management Consulting has a covering letter which reads:

PARA.TAB: Your responses will . . . form part of a study commissioned by Austrade on the feasibility of establishing an Australian trading entity. We are particularly interested in clarifying whether you would sell your product to an Australian owned enterprise, which specialised in sourcing and distributing products to Japan and other difficult markets.

SPEECH.PARA: A lot of Australian companies understandably complain about trading with Japan. They say it is very unfair that that system pits one person against many. Maybe there is some sense in having an Australian trade cartel, but it hardly squares with the government's free trade credentials. It completely undermines the claims by the Prime Minister to be a champion of free trade. I ask: is this yet another case of the government saying one thing and doing another?

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to enter this debate in relation to the dispute that began in Weipa in my electorate. I want to make one point that I do not think has been made enough: workers in Weipa do not have a choice between contracts and going on the award. Any new start in Weipa is simply offered one choice—to sign up or not get a job. That is a very clear point that ought to be made.
—Contract or the sack.

—As my friend said, contract or the sack. This situation has been engendered by CRA for a long time. It is a disgrace that CRA has stated that workers on award have less value than workers on contract. That is an insult to workers who have given many years of service to CRA. There was a time in Weipa when any criticism of CRA would be howled down. Unfortunately, that is not the situation today. I certainly lay the blame totally in the hands of CRA.

—No matter how often local ALP right-wing opportunists or our architectural aficionado P.J. Keating expresses indignation about Jeff Kennett's crooked City Link, it remains an indisputable fact that the Prime Minister's own government will provide tax concessions for infrastructure bonds floated to fund this tollway. In plain English, this means the federal government will use taxpayers' money, in the interests of scoring a vote down in Victoria, to fund a project the Prime Minister wants to deceitfully claim he is opposed to. It is a complete and utter lie and a contemptible act for ALP members to claim that ALP policy in Victoria is at odds with Jeff Kennett's City Link.

PARA.TAB: Despite pre-election guarantees to remove tolls on the M6, New South Wales Labor Premier Bob Carr could not break his promises fast enough once elected. And you can back it in that, if the Victorian ALP were elected—which it has no chance of doing, regrettably—it would do exactly the same. Why wouldn't it? Peter Batchelor, the ALP's transport spokesman, makes no bones about the fact that the ALP supports freeway widening. But, if you ask him about the $1 billion funding hole, he will just tell you to trust him. He would, wouldn't he?

If you have a look at the key elements of Melbourne Access 2000, the very policy that the ALP is running with, it says `improvements to the Tullamarine freeway'. While it does not use the term `widening', `improvements' is a euphemism for widening. These improvements will include a third inbound lane south of Brunswick Road—that is an extra one—extra lanes between Bell Street and the Calder Freeway; and extra lanes all over the place. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today to bring to the attention of the House an achievement by a firm in my current electorate. Bilcon Engineering Pty Ltd is a small firm with some 57 employees. Last week the company was awarded an Australian Quality Award for exceptional work in the field of quality in the development of the company. The current managing director, Stella Axarlis—a quite amazing woman—took over the company in 1990 at a time when the firm was facing closure after operating for some 50 years.

PARA.TAB: Since 1990 the company has come good. The achievements of Bilcon since that time include a turnaround in profitability of over 220 per cent, almost 30 per cent growth in turnover, 107 per cent employment growth, sustained automotive market share while diversifying outside the industry, thorough evaluation of supplier products and services, improved customer services to identify customer needs and expectations, increased productivity efficiency, and a high level of investment in technology and information systems.

Last Friday I was at Bilcon Engineering for a congratulatory barbecue with the employees. I think the firm can best be summed up as family. It is a family that is not related, but a family that works together in an exceptional fashion and creates quality engineering products for the local area. I would like to congratulate the team at Bilcon Engineering for the exceptional work that they have done. I am sure they will go on to do the same in the future. It is a success story and those involved have made the success for themselves. They have embraced quality management in a significant fashion. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Australian government instrumentalities such as Telstra, the Australian Tourist Commission, and so on, currently book all their international media advertising in other countries. By booking and placing media advertising in those countries through foreign advertising agencies and representation companies, the entire budget—which can be millions of dollars—remains in other countries; whereas, if the particular campaign was booked through Australian representatives and advertising agencies, around 25 per cent of those export dollars would remain in Australia for further investment. Some of the Australian advertising agencies selected by the government have overseas offices and have booked their advertising through those offices, meaning 100 per cent of the money is lost to other countries. Buy Australian indeed!

PARA.TAB: Even though, in some cases, overseas agencies can assist with local knowledge, the advertising placement should still come from Australia and from Australia's representatives. Local knowledge is not a factor in the case of the Australian Tourism Authority whose media advertising for Indonesia is booked via Hong Kong. Hong Kong is almost as distant from Jakarta as is Sydney or Melbourne, so there is no advantage to book advertising via Hong Kong or Singapore—particularly when media buying expertise in Australia is generally superior to that in other parts of the world. Proof of this was when Mitchell and Partners were appointed by the Indonesian government to buy all the media for its tourism authority, but at least they ensured that 30 per cent of the money remained in the country by utilising local agencies.

What does the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Walker) say in response to this? The above instrumentalities that I have mentioned are not required to arrange their advertising through the government's central advertising system. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak briefly about unintended consequences. We all remember that some time ago we could walk past a pharmacy in a major shopping centre and we would see a big sign announcing `Come in and you can have a free eye test'. Consequently, kids with perfect eyesight—20/20 vision—used to go in, sign a Medicare form and have their eyes tested. That was overservicing and unnecessary expenditure.

PARA.TAB: I have a lady in my electorate who, 11 months ago, had an eye infection and received treatment. Three months later she had a stroke and she had to have her eyes attended to again. The eye doctor said to her, `Come back in three months time and have your eyes checked out again.' The third time she received a knock-back from Medicare. No-one would see that as being a just decision. I ask the minister to have a look at the situation in the hope that these anomalies can be removed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Filing Mr P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on behalf of Ms Jill Brown and the people who are opposed to the development of the Old Swan Brewery who now find themselves in a position where they are obliged to pay enormous legal costs following the unsuccessful court challenge against the granting of liquor licences to the developer of the Old Swan Brewery who also happened to be a substantial donor to the Australian Labor Party back in the glorious 1980s. In her letter she writes:

SPEECH.PARA: We are not in any position to raise what now amounts to the $8,000.00 for the church, plus $18,000.00 for the Perth businessman, both who so generously assisted us by loaning these sums of money so that we could pay the court costs immediately and avoid the kind of action that John Roberts might have taken to extract that money from us.
This is a letter to Mr Court, the Premier. It continues:

I appeal to you again Mr Court for your help, in view of the fact that had Carmen Lawrence and Jim McGinty not taken the action they took, contrary to promises they made in the past, none of us would be in this horrible and stressful situation. It seems that the previous government were able to alter the rules as it suited them regardless of the interests of the public who both elect them into office and pay their wages. (I hope the electorate learn the lesson, but am afraid there may be too many `true believers' in Fremantle who have `no recollection' when it comes to vote!)

We also observe that Carmen Lawrence was prepared to use vast amounts of taxpayers money in fighting her appearance before the Marks Royal Commission, for purely selfish reasons in attempting to avoid the inevitable and what I considered correct outcome of that enquiry.

We are all honest concerned and caring people, mostly over 50 years of age, mostly surviving on some kind of pension. We acted in the publics interest that has been evident over many years, we had over 90 signatures on petitions from doctors alone who opposed the re-development . . .

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Shadow Minister for Employment, Training and Family Services

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to speak about a visit to the Paterson electorate last week by the shadow minister for employment, training and family services.
—Who's he?

—No-one knows. Dr Gloom, I believe. He was accompanied by the imported Liberal candidate for the seat of Paterson. According to the invitation that went out to a cocktail party, the focus was on youth, training and families. Of course, the $20 per head was payable to campaign funds. The press reported on this visit. The shadow minister had a lot to say about training programs, and of course most of it was critical.

PARA.TAB: How many training centres did this little circus visit? None. They could have gone to see Australia's largest group apprentice trainer, the Hunter Valley Training Co., and seen how Working Nation is training our youth and getting them jobs. They could have visited the TAFE college in Maitland, which is a centre of excellence in training people for hospitality. They could even have visited Maitland Training, formerly skillshare, which has trained 90 per cent of the work force of the East Maitland Bowling Club that is currently spending $3 million on expansion. They could also have called in at Mai-Well, which is a centre of excellence Australia-wide for training for supported workers. They did none of these things. Yet they were able to put out a press statement criticising the government's training program. I guess that's what happens when you don't have a local candidate. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am prompted to speak during 90-second statements in retaliation against a statement made earlier by the member for Macarthur (Mr Haviland) who suggested in some strange way that the opposition were prepared to deny workers, particularly in the Weipa situation, the right to collective bargaining. The reality is that the opposition do not stand to deny workers anything other than to claim their right to individual bargaining and to independent agreements, as well as the right to collective bargaining.

PARA.TAB: The member for Macarthur suggested in some strange way that we are keen to see workers exploited. He forgets that, in common with members on the other side of the House, we too represent workers and are parents with children in the work force. As a parent whose children have been exploited in sundry and assorted vocations, I can be as indignant as the government when I see that exploitation occurring.

What I seek to ensure is that workers have the same right to individual enterprise bargaining as they have had to collective bargaining. I did not, for example, find the member for Macarthur as outspoken when in the past unions were prepared to call for benefits for union members only and that those benefits should not flow on to other workers. Now, when he sees the role is reversed, he claims some sort of monopoly on the right to speak up for the workers of Australia. As a parent of children who are themselves in the work force, I would get as indignant as he about any indication of exploitation he is ever able to raise.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 3 p.m., in accordance with standing order 106A the time for members' statements is concluded.

—I inform the House that the Prime Minister will be absent from question time today. Mr Keating is in Japan on government business. I will answer questions today on his behalf. I also inform the House that the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, Mr Tickner, is absent also and, in his absence, questions will be answered by the Minister for Social Security.

—My question is to the Acting Prime Minister. If individual staff salary packages include different rewards such as bonuses for greater individual efforts, how can such agreements violate the principle of equal work of equal value for equal pay? How can the government claim that those on salary packages with different performance criteria and more flexible working arrangements should be treated the same as those on the award? Why is the government opposed to better pay for better work?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The government has always accepted that there will be in certain arrangements from time to time pay differentials. In general terms, it goes to the skill with which the workers apply themselves to their work. What we have never accepted is the notion that there ought not be equal pay for equal work and that people standing alongside each other, doing the same job essentially, should receive very substantial pay differentials. It has, of course, always been the position of the opposition that they should. The Leader of the Opposition was questioned on this matter some time ago by a journalist. The journalist's question to the Leader of the Opposition was as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: So, Mr Howard, you would have a picture where on a production line or behind a counter you'd have two workers: one with award conditions and another with a contract—and there would be great variations.
The journalist asked again, to make sure he got it absolutely right:
Great variations in pay and conditions?
Mr Howard: That is absolutely right.

He said that, just in case the point was not taken. The point the government believes—and it has expressed this view over the last few days in relation to the industrial dispute before the IRC—is that where the same tasks are being performed there ought to be an equality of pay between the people performing those tasks.

TALK.START.PARA: —We all agree with that.

—That is not your position. You like to try to think that is your position now, as you shift and change with the wind, but the fact of the matter is that you have made your position quite clear. The whole substance of the way in which you have intervened with your public comments in this dispute is that basically what you want to do is see workers stripped of their right to collective bargaining. You want to see them discouraged from taking up that right, by their being massively and severely discriminated against in their employment. The notion that you would have people essentially working alongside each other doing the same tasks, having applied to them some little differential in some arrangement related to a contract as opposed to the award, producing a $7,000 to $20,000 difference in annual income, is a joke.

—I inform the House that we have present in the gallery this afternoon members of a parliamentary delegation from the Philippines. On behalf of the House, I extend a very warm welcome to our visitors.

PARA.TAB: Honourable members—Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and the Minister for Trade. Can the minister advise what the APEC meetings in Osaka achieved? What benefits can Australia expect to gain from APEC trade liberalisation?

—Australia can be very proud of and pleased with the result obtained in Osaka with the agreement on the action agenda put forward by APEC foreign and trade ministers. Notably, the work done by Senators McMullan and Gareth Evans in that regard deserves commendation. It was agreed to by leaders and sets out a unique trade policy framework which gives real substance to the Bogor vision of free and open trade and investment in our region by 2010 for developed countries and by 2020 for developing economies.

PARA.TAB: That is a unique framework because it does not rely on the traditional GATT style give and take negotiation. The final goals have been set. It is now up to individual members to prepare their own plans. The first stage of those plans will be reached by the end of next year when members submit their action plans.

The process will not be purely unilateral, either. The action agenda includes agreement on a range of general principles that will guide APEC liberalisation, plus a process of consultation and review. It includes, very importantly, the principle of comprehensive coverage. That means for Australia that agriculture will be part of the process. That is an issue which is of key importance, including to those opposite.

The notion of flexibility is also written into the action agenda, but it will be exercised within the time frames of the Bogor declaration. We are very pleased with the wording on comparability, giving members confidence that their own liberalisation plans under APEC will be matched by the efforts of others. In other words, this is going to be a level playing field that we are achieving. The critical commitment in Bogor to the end dates of 2010 and 2020 for achieving free and open trade has been reaffirmed.

While those trade liberalisation objectives have grabbed the headlines, there are other distinct and very important aspects of the action agenda, such as trade facilitation and economic cooperation, that will have a very considerable impact on the region's development. With its breadth and depth, the action agenda is a testament to the growing economic integration of the region and it will be seen as a major advance in its economic development.

We have done some modelling, which suggests that APEC trade liberalisation and facilitation will provide a very significant boost to economic growth in the region and, importantly, in Australia itself. In the Australian economy, real income is expected to increase by 6.8 per cent, or $A40 billion, as a result of free trade when all the effects flow through. Of that total, trade liberalisation will deliver a 4.3 per cent, or $A25 billion, increase in real income, while trade facilitation will deliver a further 2.5 per cent, or $A15 billion. That economic growth will mean employment growth of the order of 500,000 new jobs over the course of the liberalisation period.

Tangible benefits in the near term through trade facilitation will include simplification and harmonisation of customs procedures, the speeding up of trade flows and the building of private sector confidence through greater transparency across the region, facilitation through competition policy, rules of origin, dispute mediation, deregulation and mobility of business people.

Finally, for the region as a whole, Bogor's liberalisation and facilitation agenda is expected to increase income by around $993 billion, or 3.8 per cent, when all the combined effects flow through. That represents more than the current size of the Australian and South Korean economies combined, more than 10 times the size of the Malaysian economy and more than 1 1/2 times the current size of the Chinese economy. Those benefits will accrue to all APEC economies with developing APEC economies benefiting the most.

I conclude by saying that the Japanese government is to be congratulated on the results of Osaka. The work which Australia has put into that, including by the Prime Minister and Senators Gareth Evans and McMullan, was crucial to that. The Prime Minister will be making a full statement on Osaka when he returns.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Acting Prime Minister. Is it a fact that employers may enter into staff salary packages with employees where over-award remuneration is linked to individual performance? If so, will you now publicly acknowledge that the packages CRA has with the majority of its employees are authorised and supported by your policies?

—Well before we made any changes to the industrial relations system—it has always been a part of the industrial relations system since time immemorial—employees had the capacity from time to time to enter into individual contracts. There is no question about that. It has always been there. It was there before we changed the industrial laws. It has been a constant feature of our industrial system since time immemorial.

PARA.TAB: What we regard as entirely inappropriate is a second set of workers doing the same type of work alongside people already performing those tasks—that they should receive, firstly, a set of conditions which means that there is a pay differential between them of something like $17,000 to $20,000. That is admitted. Secondly, we have always believed—we believe that the Industrial Relations Act upholds it—that there ought to be a capacity for workers, if they so choose, to collectively bargain and have that recognised and engaged by any of the companies concerned. That has not occurred until the intervention of the Prime Minister as far as these workers are concerned. It has not occurred in this instance until that time.

The third thing that we have always supported very strongly is the capacity of workers to be represented by trade unions. The simple fact of the matter is that, whatever way you intend to dress it up, what is being applied here, within the constraints of the existing operation, is an effort by CRA to try to drive the unions out of its work force via establishing discriminatory arrangements between two sets of workers. Precisely that issue is being tested at the moment before the IRC because of the initiatives of the Minister for Industrial Relations.

You always let the cat out of the bag by whom you support. You are trying to say, `We have actually changed our position. We said that we could see the two working alongside each other and doing the same tasks and effectively being discriminated against.' You now try to deny and obfuscate that position, though you have made those statements repeatedly. It is like those statements where you say your position is that people in contract arrangements should not suffer a diminution of wages. You now say, `No. We have never said or implied that.' You have said it repeatedly and you say it in private all over the place, as the press gallery knows. Whether you say it now openly and publicly is another matter, but they are your intentions.

You reveal your intentions by your attitude on this dispute, which is not to support the capacity of workers to collectively bargain or produce an equality of outcomes when the same work is being done by people essentially pursuing the same activity at the same level of responsibility. Your attitude is not to go in to bat on that. It is to go in to bat to defend whatever discriminatory practices are in place at the moment and to emphasise the capacity to get workers into individual contracts.

You tip your hand every time and reveal that the occasional medicine of an industrial relations system that is relatively open, as our industrial relations system is, is your daily breakfast. That is the type of legislation that you would want to put in place, if it were ever capable of being implemented and if you ever managed to get yourselves into government.

There is another ingredient in all this which is absolutely critical and a major differential between the point where this situation is now and where you would be. We believe in a strong Industrial Relations Commission with a capacity to intervene in the national interest and, if necessary, make either minimum rates awards or paid rates awards. That is our position. It is not yours. Your position is to gut the IRC. If you were confronted with this problem in office, you would be left without a capacity to bring in an independent arbitrator to act in the national interest to bring these matters to a conclusion as is being done at the moment. You would be left flummoxing, giving your opinions on this and that activity of the company and how sinful the unions were, and nothing else.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. Can the minister advise the House of the effects of the government's family policies on the welfare of Australian children?

—I thank the honourable member for her question. I know that she has a very keen interest in this area of policy. As I have pointed out to the House on a number of occasions before, a great deal has been achieved by this government in assisting families, particularly with assistance targeted at low income families, including low income working families. I will remind the House of some key statistics. The real value of the additional family payment is up 76 per cent for children under 13. It is up by 147 per cent for children between the ages of 13 and 15. The breadth of coverage of the additional family payment for low income working households has increased enormously. There has been an elevenfold increase. Around 300,000 working families are now receiving the AFP.

PARA.TAB: The maximum level of rent assistance has increased by between 80 per cent and 140 per cent in real terms and been extended to low income working families. A further $5 increase per fortnight is due to come in in March. We have also seen the introduction of the additional parenting allowance, targeted again at low income families where one person is staying at home looking after the children. Again, substantial real increases are associated with that. So the picture is very clear that the real value of that assistance to families has been improved very considerably under this government.

A second thrust, apart from increasing the value of this assistance, has been to try to ensure that the assistance gets into the hands of the primary carer—that is, the person who has the day-to-day responsibility of looking after the children. That has led to a number of structural changes in payments over the years. The most recent example is the replacement of the dependent spouse rebate with HACCA and then the parenting allowance for families with children. That has brought about a redistribution of income within the family.

A previous instance of where this government went down that route was in early 1993 with the so-called families integration where we split the payments so the family payments and the rent assistance components were explicitly directed to the primary carer. What was the effect of that split? That was not a measure that increased total outlays but it did bring about this redistribution within the family.

Some very interesting research work and evaluation have just been completed by my department on the impact of that redistribution. It shows that as a result of that redistribution to the primary carer, not as a result of any increase, in 29 per cent of families there has been a significant increase in the amount actually spent on the children. So that is a very significant result which shows the wisdom and efficacy of our policy of getting assistance into the hands of the primary carer.

This of course is another area of policy where we hear a lot of rhetoric from the opposition. We have heard nothing specific. We have heard references to income splitting, different variants of income splitting and so-called family taxation, all of which are highly regressive in their impact, all of which serve to increase work force disincentives for women and all of which are thoroughly regressive in social policy terms. This government's record in family assistance and the further measures we have announced in the budget demonstrate that our record is pretty solid and creditable, which contrasts with the policy vacuum on the opposition's side.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Resources. I draw the minister's attention to the widespread use of staff salary arrangements in the resources industry, including the large work forces at Mount Tom Price, Robe River and the North-West Shelf. In light of the strike at Weipa, does the minister now condemn these salary arrangements or does he recognise their importance in improving labour relations and the international competitiveness of Australia's resource industries?

—I thank the member for his question. One thing that will always separate this side of the House from that side of the House is our belief in a fair day's pay for a fair day's work and the right of equal pay for equal work. I visited a large range of projects where there was a total non-union work force by agreement such as, say, Hamersley Iron in the north of Western Australia.

PARA.TAB: The current dispute in Weipa is because the whole work force does not want to go to that condition. Therefore, it should be able to get equal pay for equal work. That is what the dispute is about in CRA and in Weipa. The honourable member knows that. It is a financial inducement to break down the work force.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the coal strike?

—The honourable member interjects about the coal strike, and I will take up that interjection. We have spent a lot of time this year trying to reform the Australian coal industry. When industrial relations are raised, it is I who raises the industrial relations issue because we have had a remarkably good record in recent times.

PARA.TAB: The fact is that CRA, which operates a number of coalmines, has already tried to get some of those coalminers onto contracts. There is great reluctance in the United Mine Workers Union, which is a section of the CFMEU, because that industry is an extraordinarily dangerous one. The honourable member for Gippsland knows this fact because we went to the Moura memorial together, which was a very moving occasion, and we saw the difficulties and the dangers associated with the coal industry.

There is an enormous amount of mateship within the industry. It is about teamwork. The work force thinks that the union has a capacity to represent them, and they do not believe in individual contracts. What we are saying is that the matter should be resolved between the union and management. We think that today there should not be a national coal strike. The ACTU recommended that it not take place. I think that recommendation should be followed by the CFMEU, and hopefully that matter will be resolved today.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Housing and Regional Development. I refer to the accord signed with local government last week. Can the minister tell the House: what is the significance of the signing of that accord?

—I thank the honourable member for Macquarie for her question. She referred to an assembly last week of local governments which was held for the second year. It included something like 800 delegates representing most, if not all, local government units in Australia. It was a very significant meeting, firstly, because of the accord that was signed at that meeting and, secondly, because of the inability on the part of both the shadow spokesperson and the Leader of the Opposition to say a single word of policy substance at this very important and very representative meeting.

PARA.TAB: Last Wednesday the Prime Minister signed off this historic agreement which recognises a partnership between the Commonwealth and local government in an agreed reform agenda. Together we are tackling the major reform issues: enterprise bargaining; reform of business regulations; fast-track planning and building approvals; road construction and maintenance; access to emerging information technology; and social justice for indigenous Australians. Each of these issues is a first order issue and is very important in terms of efficiency and fairness at the local or community scale.

Underpinning this relationship is a commitment by this government to constitutional recognition of local government, a sound financial relationship which is subject to regular review and a recently announced local government development program of $48 million over the next four years which will provide a stable funding stream for local government initiatives. Against this backdrop, let me paint the response of the opposition. Some 800 delegates at the convention were eager to hear the opposition's policy on local government. It was the last chance for the opposition effectively to air its policy to such a large and representative gathering of local government before the next election.
Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order!
—What does the shadow spokesperson, my colleague Mr Bruce Scott, have to say?
—You will know soon enough.
—The member for Maranoa!

—He said that he would not be releasing his policy because `it's like good wine; it's still maturing'. This old bottle under the stairs still has the cork in it. The opposition, having absolutely no policy ideas, fails at this conference to spell out any directions whatever. All we have from the Leader of the Opposition is vague philosophical meandering in which he repeats the fact that there are three tiers of government—very clever—and that, ultimately, if you are going to have constitutional recognition of local government, you have got to get the permission of the states. So, effectively, any suggestion that local government has any integrity, any autonomy, any status, any stature or anything at all which would provide the opposition with any reason to make a policy announcement simply does not exist.

PARA.TAB: They sent Bruce Scott along, but he had nothing to say, except a bit about old wine. The Leader of the Opposition made a speech at that conference, which delegates gave up their lunch to attend, and he failed to say a single word of substance in the course of that speech. Whatever you say about local government, they are not fools; they are not going to be trivialised; and they are not going to forget the fact that the Leader of the Opposition had absolutely nothing to say. He is a joke.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Acting Prime Minister. Is it not a fact that in 1989 the man who has just been recycled to rescue the Prime Minister from his embarrassment—
—Order! Members on my right!
—You know all about recycling.
—The member for Paterson, in particular!

—Is it not a fact that in 1989 the then government marshalled all of the resources of the Commonwealth—the Royal Australian Air Force, the ACTU and a whole lot of other instruments of the Commonwealth—to deny a trade union, namely, the Australian Federation of Air Pilots, the rights of collective bargaining? Is it not a fact that it drove every last one of those pilots into an individual contract and exerted all of its power before the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission to deny them the right of collective bargaining? What has happened between now and then to convert the pro-contract passion of 1989 to the anti-contract passion of 1995?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —What has happened since then is for you to decide, but somehow or other you do not stand by your position where you said:

ANSWER.PARA: JOURNALIST: So Mr Howard, you could have a picture where on a production line or behind a counter you'd have two workers, one with award conditions and another one with a contract, and there would be great variations?
JOURNALIST: Great variations in pay and conditions?
What happened in 1989 was that we then had a very much more centralised wage fixing set of arrangements.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members—Ha, ha!

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

—We did have at that point of time, and it delivered these things. It delivered record growth rates in this country, twice the growth rates you had. It delivered on top of that a rate of job increase twice that which applied when you were in office. It also produced a level of industrial peace that this country had not enjoyed under yourselves, reducing the level of industrial disputation to where it remains today—at approximately 10 to 15 per cent of what it was in the period that you happened to be in office.

PARA.TAB: The set of arrangements that was put in place then dealt with the capacity to sustain that system. The set of arrangements that applies now deals with the capacity to sustain the contemporary system in a way that allows considerable flexibility but also equal justice. It ill behoves a company or anyone else in this system to get into a situation where they move beyond the capacity to deliver on a collective bargain or move beyond the capacity of a group of individuals to be represented by a union if they so choose by putting in place in front of them practical impediments to the achievement of that and then active discrimination when they assume it. Those are the issues that are entailed here.

It is a dispute which, in terms of the record of this country's industrial relations system since you left office, is an aberration. It is an aberration in this system. Under you—as you in private freely acknowledge and admit and as those who are your economic analysts say would be a definite feature, were you to be in government, of your first 18 months—as I said before, there would be daily fear.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Social Security aware of reports about the role of pensioners in reducing national debt? Are pensioners responsible for Australia's national debt?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baldwin The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable members would recall that a few weeks ago the Leader of the Opposition made a speech to ACOSS on social policy. This was to be one of the much touted, much vaunted headland speeches—or wasteland speeches, as I prefer to call them—in which he was going to outline his directions in various areas.

PARA.TAB: In so far as there was any substance at all, the speech consisted of a series of negatives, a listing of things that he claimed that he would not do—a rather carefully formulated listing of things he would not do, by the way. For example, he would not slash $10 billion off the social wage. He left open the possibility that he would slash some figure less than $10 billion off the social wage, but he would not slash $10 billion off the social wage. So we have this continuing policy vacuum from the opposition. From their record we can make judgments on what they would do: pension allowances and payments to low income people all fell, or slipped behind indexation during his period of tenure as Treasurer and during the period of the previous government. So we do know some things.

But the other source of information about what the opposition may do and their actual underlying attitudes to social policy questions come from utterances from some members of their back benches and statements, in fact, from some of their frontbenchers in their more unguarded moments. Honourable members will recall the statement by the Leader of the National Party extolling the virtues of the Thai system where the families are expected to look after old age people rather than have a public pension scheme.
