But the most recent example of this was a statement by the honourable member for Lilley's Liberal opponent. In a letter to a local paper, she said:

A major element in consumer spending is purchasing by people who receive their income from government in salaries, pensions, doles and allowances. So put it all together and we find that Mr Keating's economic growth signifies ever-increasing indebtedness.

ANSWER.PARA: What are we intended to infer from that? What is being implied here is that people on low incomes, people who rely on these benefits, including pensioners, are in some sense responsible for the country's national debt. That is the sort of attitude that comes out time and again from the opposition.

PARA.TAB: The reality is that under this government we established a social safety net which, according to a recent study by a group of academics at the ANU, is one of the most efficient in the world in two respects: firstly, of a group of 10 OECD countries that were studied it is the most efficient in getting the assistance to those who need it and not making payments to those who do not need it—in other words, in targeting efficiency it was easily the most efficient social safety net of the group of 10 countries studied—and, secondly, in administrative efficiency it is the second most efficient in administrative expenditures as a proportion of program outlays. The only other country of the group that had a better ratio in that respect was Norway.

So in those two key respects we have a very efficient social safety net in this country. Notwithstanding the fact that we pay out less than many other countries on these payments, simply because of its greater efficiency we have a system which is comparably effective at preventing poverty. Yet we get this sort of nonsense from the member for Lilley's opponent somehow suggesting that people, pensioners and others who depend on these payments, are to be held responsible for our national debt. It is outrageous and scandalous and it really does reveal the true set of attitudes that underlie the thinking of the coalition on these issues.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Minister for Human Services and Health

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Human Services and Health. Now that the Marks royal commission has found that you have been untruthful about your knowledge and involvement in the Easton affair, is it your position that lying when holding high public office does not matter?
—Why don't you ask Dean Brown that?
—Order! Those on my right!

—Or do you assert that those who gave contradictory evidence to you in the royal commission, including your former cabinet colleagues Ian Taylor, Jim McGinty, Eric Ripper, Geoff Gallop, Keith Wilson, Pam Beggs, Judyth Watson and John Kobelke are liars, and that your former staff members Zoltan Kovacs, Bob Willoughby and Marcelle Anderson are also liars?
—I have made it clear right from the outset when it was first mooted that there might be an inquiry of this kind—and others too who have looked at it—that it was clearly a political exercise—
—By you.
—Order!

—Order! Those on my left and right! The minister will wait for a moment. It is not as if it was unexpected the minister would be given a question at least on this today. She will be given the opportunity to be heard in silence. Just relax.
—And you are going—
—She has just started and I will adjudicate, not you.

—A political exercise, as I say, designed by the Liberal Party at both state and federal levels, despite denials from the Leader of the Opposition. And it has been recognised as a political exercise by a great many people, including, for example, the Anglican Archbishop of Perth who called it `politically contrived' and the Uniting Church moderator who described it as `a political assassination tool'. These are people independent of politics who see it clearly for what it is: it was conceived in malice; it was established for improper purposes.
—And what was your attitude?
—The member for O'Connor!

—The royal commission is, and indeed was itself, an abuse of executive power. To accept its findings, or to take any action in relation to them, would be to condone that abuse of executive power. Mr Speaker, that is something that I have indicated, and the Prime Minister has also indicated, that we do not intend to do. Its conduct was, and its conclusions are, gravely flawed. The commissioner himself indicated that his terms of reference were restrictive and, indeed, unclear. At one stage the commissioner himself indicated, speaking to my counsel, `If you don't know what it is about, you will have to work it out for yourself.' So the commissioner himself was not prepared to say clearly what the commission was all about. Mr Speaker, it is very clear that the report lacked procedural fairness.
—Look at those behind you.
—The member for Mayo!

—The report was highly contentious and virtually devoid of any rigorous analysis of evidence. The commissioner himself said during hearings that he was not accustomed to making decisions on half the evidence, yet he has clearly done precisely that in his findings.
—What evidence should he have called?
—Order!

—To accept such findings in any form would further lower the standards of royal commissions, which have reached new lows with this royal commission. The commissioner himself said the findings would be open to doubt, and they certainly are.

PARA.TAB: I think it is worth saying, and reminding members here, that royal commissions are not judicial; they are not independent of government; they are tools of the executive, without the constraints and safeguards that normally apply in judicial proceedings. I think it is also worth repeating, Mr Speaker, that for the two days before the commission began its hearings, as I understand it, counsel assisting and others were briefed for two days by Court's dirt team, by his political operatives, the people who have been shown to have been active for nearly three years—

TALK.START.PARA: —She talks about the dirt team—the Labor members?
—The member for Mayo!

—solely concerned with seeking to discredit the former government. Mr Speaker, I think it also needs to be repeated that royal commissions are normally reserved for matters of extreme gravity, usually illegality, and in this case that has not been the case. It is very important, from my point of view, to recognise here that you have two people, Marks and Vanstone, who would purport to act as prosecutor, judge and jury, without the normal safeguards that apply in these cases, by exposing that cabinet that I was part of—and, indeed, by precedent, all others—to succeeding governments going back and investigating what they may or may not have said in cabinet. By exposing parliamentarians to intimidation by the executive, they have opened a Pandora's box, and I for one am not going to stand up and allow that precedent to become part of political action in Australia.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Justice. Would the minister inform the House what the government is doing to prevent money laundering, particularly organised crime laundering their profits through financial institutions?
—I thank the honourable member for the question. Of course, money laundering is a component now of international organised crime, and it is part of a sophisticated—
—Did you read the Adelaide Advertiser today and what it reported?
—Mr Speaker, it might help if the opposition at least had some kind of interest in the proceedings of the House.
—It might help the House if the minister gets to his answer.

—One of the important things about the international globalisation of crime is that it does bring to account those who wish to hide the proceeds of crime and who wish to avoid tax. Organised crime and money laundering do go hand-in-hand. This government's response to the threat posed by money laundering included the creation in 1989 of Austrac, the Australian Transaction Reports and Analysis Centre. That monitors some 20,000 transactions every day and has some 12 million transactions on its database. It has 80 staff and, under the direction of director Bill Coad, its job is to analyse financial transaction data and to identify criminal activity, including money laundering and white-collar crime and drug trafficking.

PARA.TAB: One of the key techniques that is used is the scheme by which banks and other institutions are required to report suspicious transactions to Austrac. One recent example is a person sending funds overseas through numerous bank branches in a suspicious fashion. Police checks revealed the use of false names and addresses. Subsequently a police operation resulted in charges and the seizure of a large quantity of heroin. There have been many other notable success stories. Included in those are 26 people being charged with more than 550 offences arising from a conspiracy to defraud the states and the Commonwealth by evading the payment of tobacco licensing fees. Over $30 million in tax assessments have been issued. A suspect transaction report provided key information concerning fraud in negotiable instruments and conviction of the offender and a long custodial sentence followed. A suspect transaction report from a financial institution identifying a false name account led to the arrest of a person operating as an unregistered tax agent forging signatures and falsifying claims. That person was jailed for several years.

One of the things that Austrac has picked up on in recent times is the growing evidence that some solicitors are laundering money by placing cash in trust accounts to hide ownership of that money. For example, following identification of a series of unusual transactions, an investigation discovered that nearly three-quarters of a million dollars had been channelled through a solicitor's trust account. Charges have been laid in that matter. What we have done as a government has been to respond to that threat by requiring that solicitors ought report cash transactions of over $10,000, thereby bringing solicitors into line with other professionals. There will, of course, be no obligation to report merely suspicious transactions because of the reason of the solicitors' obligations to their clients in that regard. The actual operation of any cash transaction over $10,000 will now need to be reported following the legislative response that the government proposes.

We are not merely seen as successful in Australia; internationally the government has been successful in having a high profile. Australia has a leading role internationally in the fight against money laundering. The G-7 nations set up the Financial Action Task Force in 1989 to fight international money laundering. The task force was chaired by the current National Crime Authority head, Tom Sherman, in 1992-93. Australia funds the Task Force Asia Secretariat from our confiscated assets trust fund. Bill Coad, who is head of Austrac, recently was invited by the United States Office of National Drug Control Policy to speak on financial crime at a key international crime conference. That invitation, too, is an international recognition of our success, particularly Austrac's innovative use of technology to effectively analyse the huge volumes of material and financial information that it possesses. I understand that later today there will be a tabling of Austrac's annual report. I would commend its contents to members of the House, particularly to the honourable member who asked the question, and who has an ongoing interest in this area, for what I think is one of Australia's great successes in this area.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Minister for Human Services and Health

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Human Services and Health. I remind her that, on the evidence of her former Labor cabinet colleagues Jim McGinty, Eric Ripper, Geoff Gallop, Keith Wilson, Pam Beggs, Judyth Watson, and John Kobelke, and on the evidence of Labor staffers Zoltan Kovacs and Bob Willoughby, she was found to have lied about the Easton petition. Since you have been found to have lied by the royal commission, why should the public ever trust your word again and, as the Prime Minister considers lying no disqualification for office in his government, what reason is there to think that any other minister in the government is more honest than you are?

—As I said earlier, and I will repeat it because I think it needs to be, this was a commission constituted for a clearly political purpose, and the conclusions reached in the commission's report and the way it was conducted bear witness to that. They have exactly the same character as the original intention. Some people have tried to suggest that, because it was a royal commission, it somehow enjoys special status. It does not; it depends entirely on how these matters are conducted.

PARA.TAB: The commissioner himself said the terms of reference were selective. There was no attempt made to examine the role of Liberal Party members in presenting matters to the parliament; no attempt, and indeed an explicit refusal, to deal with certain inconsistencies in the current Premier's evidence—all of those matters were set aside. The commissioner himself at an early stage at least appeared to recognise that that was problematic. Let me tell him it is. While the commission might be a royal commission in the sense that it was constituted as a so-called properly constituted inquiry, it shares some of the same characteristics with many others. Senator Robert Ray in the other place indicated earlier that, when you have an inquiry that has this characteristic, you do not accept its conclusions any more than you would with, say, the Spanish inquisition or the McCarthyist purges.

One of the things that I want to make clear in all of this is that I am just as entitled, as is anyone in this House, to judge the commission and its findings in the same way as it saw fit to judge me. I find that there was no analysis or argument in the royal commission report. Findings are simply baldly asserted without reference to the evidence. A lot of evidence is simply ignored if it is inconvenient or if it does not fit the line that they picked up in the first two days—the line of the Court government, the `government of hate' as it is described by political commentators.There was no analysis or argument. The contradictions in evidence were unreconciled. The only interpretation that is ever offered if people agree with me is that they have motive for doing so—

TALK.START.PARA: —No, they are not. What did he say about Don Russell?
—Order! I warn the member for O'Connor.
—Or that they are in some way not to be trusted, or they are simply ignored. It is an extraordinary effort. Some evidence is simply set aside altogether from people equally—
—Have you read it?
—Yes—equally competent to say what occurred at the time.
—Have you read the evidence?
—Order! I warn the member for Mayo.

—If it fits into the preconceptions that clearly existed at the time, the evidence is accepted; if not, set aside. There is a clear reliance on hearsay right throughout the report. So I find that it is a seriously flawed document—I find that it is, and I am not the only one to do so.
—What a joke!
—Order! Those on my left!

—I would hope that members opposite understand that the people in the Australian community understand what this exercise is all about, and they are increasingly expressing that view whenever they are asked. This was taken after the royal commission. That is just for your vision. There you go. They don't believe you.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —The minister will resume her seat. Those on my left will put those away.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members—What about her!

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I have said to the minister that she will resume her seat. Those on my left also know better. The member for Stirling who distributed those before question time started today also knows better, and should.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs. Is the minister aware of reports of a proposal to cancel construction of the My Thuan bridge across the Mekong? Is it the intention of the government to proceed with that bridge? What would be the effect on the relationship between Vietnam and Australia if the bridge contract were to be cancelled? What are the implications for Australian exports and jobs?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bilney The Hon G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think the coalition's foreign affairs spokesman actually said that the coalition, if in the unfortunate event that it came to government, would cancel construction of the My Thuan bridge, but he did say that the project would be `reviewed'. But given that he has described this project as `inappropriate', `extravagant' and a `cynically timed exercise', I really would not fancy the chances of it seeing the light of the day if the member for Mayo ever had a say in this matter.

PARA.TAB: When the Prime Minister and I announced on 15 November that the governments of Australia and of Vietnam had decided to proceed with construction of the My Thuan bridge, which is the largest infrastructure project ever financed under the Australian aid program, the shadow minister fired off one of his usual `get your mouth in gear but don't worry about the mind' responses. He was at his absolutely ill-informed and patronising best when he said:

ANSWER.PARA: The decision to build a second bridge across the Mekong is an inappropriate use of Australian aid money and a cynically timed exercise designed to lock up the aid budget long after Labor is gone.

Where has he been? Just how much attention has he been paying to the Australian aid program? Does he know, for example, that Australia's assistance in building this bridge was requested by the government of Vietnam as its highest infrastructure priority? Why is it such a high priority? The reason is the huge benefits that it is going to bring to the area. At the moment one has to cross the Mekong delta on a ferry. Fifteen million people live there. Around half of the country's rice is produced there. To take that to its market is a key project.

PARA.TAB: It is a joint project. Vietnam is contributing around $28 million to the cost. Vietnam, of all countries, has no interest in building monuments, as the shadow minister called them, which are useless. On the question of the timing of the decision, does the shadow minister not know that this decision is the culmination of a well-established timetable which has been going on since 1993 with pre-feasibility and feasibility studies? Perhaps he does not know that because, when the general secretary of the Vietnamese communist party was in Australia meeting with people as disreputable as John Prescott—that rabblerouser—and the Prime Minister, the Leader of the Opposition would not meet him.

It is hardly surprising that the coalition would have no idea about Vietnamese priorities for the development of their country and absolutely no compunction about putting at risk Australia's relations with a country in which we are the sixth largest investor. Vietnam is a country where companies like BHP are carrying on important aspects of their business.

The member for Mayo also implied that other aspects of our aid program could suffer as a result of our commitment to building this bridge. He is as ignorant on that aspect as he is on the aid program in general. The fact is that Australia will continue to have a balanced, effective mix of aid activities in Vietnam in which we will continue to devote real attention to health aspects, natural resource development, education and training. We will also continue to fund a non-governmental program which at last count currently involved some 29 separate projects. Even at the height of expenditure on the bridge program—which will be $18.5 million in 1999—the project will account for only about 20 per cent of the expected Australian aid flow to Vietnam.

The member asked about the implication for exports and jobs. As most members of this House know—perhaps with the exception of the shadow minister—our aid program is all about Australian aid. It is about Australian companies benefiting from infrastructure projects like the Mekong bridge. It is about Australian farmers who deliver the wheat and rice and who benefit when we deliver food aid overseas. The shadow minister's ill-considered statement on the Mekong bridge will certainly not be welcomed by the wide range of Australian companies that are active throughout Asia in the delivery of Australia's development aid. In fact, those companies have warmly welcomed the announcement we made the other day. Let me quote from the press release from the MTIA representing the manufacturing, engineering and construction industry:

ANSWER.PARA: MTIA welcomes today's joint statement by the Prime Minister and the Minister for Development Cooperation. . . Tendering for the construction of the My Thuan bridge will be restricted to Australian companies, providing a high profile opportunity for Australia to demonstrate our world competitive expertise in construction, not just in Vietnam, but to other markets in the region. . . If Australia is to achieve sustained improvements in domestic living standards and job opportunities, it is vital that we increase the level of value added production, particularly of elaborately transformed manufactures and accelerate growth in value added exports.
What about the Australian International Projects Group which said:

The government's decision to partially fund the Mekong bridge in southern Vietnam is an excellent example of how Australia's aid program can not only advance the economic and social development of an aid recipient country but serve also to foster industry development in Australia.

I can understand why the shadow minister talks all through this, because it is embarrassing to him. Let us try Australia's peak engineering body, the Association of Consulting Engineers, which accused the shadow minister of having `a blinkered vision'. The association said:

If the coalition is serious about providing opportunities for one of our country's most valuable exports, our technological skills, it must commit itself to a sound program of funding and not be content to score political points.

The opposition simply does not realise that the aid program, as well as delivering essential development assistance to countries in our region, helps in a mighty way to create export markets for Australian goods and to create jobs for Australian companies and Australian workers. We are doing that in a way which makes most Australians feel very proud of what we are doing overseas. It is very sad that all one has seen from the opposition on aid is negatives. They have not come out with a policy. Before the last election they said that they would slash $200 million out of our aid budget. That is the last thing they said. That will not help our relations with Vietnam; it will not help our region's development; it will not help exports; and it will not help jobs.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Minister for Human Services and Health

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Human Services and Health. I ask the minister: isn't it a fact that while ever you remain a minister you are living proof that the Keating government has no standards? Were the Herald-Sun and the West Australian right with their headlines saying, `She lied'? Was the editorial of the Herald-Sun right when it said, `Decency would normally dictate that she steps down as a minister of the Crown'? If being proved to be a liar is not enough, what would you have to do for you to realise you should stand down now? Finally, I ask: isn't it a fact that not only are you prepared to use the Family Court affairs of an innocent individual for your own political purposes, but also you are now prepared to put yourself over the interests of all your Labor colleagues behind you?

—There is no end to the malice to come from the opposite side. What I was pointing out earlier was that the commission itself is flawed and was flawed right from the outset. If you want to talk about Family Court matters being raised, why did the terms of reference of the commission not include how that was first done, who did it and under what circumstances? The answers to those questions would seriously have embarrassed the present Premier. The terms of reference did not allow any examination either of whether or not Mr Court had made statements inside and outside the parliament that were inconsistent with what he said before the royal commission. That matter was not addressed at all by the royal commission.

PARA.TAB: Reading out the headline and holding it up like that may have given members opposite a few moments of entertainment, but what it shows is that in Western Australia, despite six months of effort and the expenditure of taxpayers' funds for Liberal Party propaganda—this was given a heavy emphasis by the West Australian—the people of Western Australia are very cynical about two things.

The first concerns the motivation and findings of the report. A great many people simply do not accept them. When they hear condemnation of me coming from the mouths of the Leader of the Opposition and the likes of the member for Stirling and others, who are part of the party of hate—the government and the opposition of hate—they are very cynical indeed. They ask what standpoint the Leader of the Opposition, who would not even be clear about what discussions, if any, he had had with Premier Court about this matter, can possibly have. How can we listen to somebody who before the last election when he had an opportunity to inform the people about the state of the economy as a government minister chose to mislead them very directly and deliberately?

How can we as a community, how can the voters in Western Australia and how can anybody listen to you talk about standards? It simply doesn't wash. You may choose to condemn me; some editorials may condemn me. But I can stand up and say that I have always behaved in ways that are consistent with my office. When I hear criticism from members opposite, I ask two things: what is the nature of the criticism and what is the advantage to the opposition in continuing this campaign? I think that whatever advantage they may have gained—and I would concede that there is some—is fast running out because now they are being seen as malicious, vindictive and unprincipled.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Human Services and Health and relates to a serious matter involving her ministerial portfolio. What measures is the government taking to increase the supply of specialist medical officers in rural areas?

—I thank the member for Calare for his question. I know that he, too, has been working hard to ensure there are more doctors practising in his rural electorate and others around the country. There is clearly an undersupply of specialists in rural areas and we have been addressing this problem. Despite the opposition's interest in other matters, we have been getting on with the job.

PARA.TAB: As many members will know since they represent country electorates—particularly members on our side of the House—a lot of Australians have to travel long distances before they can get access to specialist services. That places a lot of stress on local GPs who have to manage some very difficult cases in the absence of specialist back-up. So we have implemented a number of initiatives to assist, including some $2.1 million which I announced today to boost specialist services. We have a major GP program but this will assist in the provision of specialist services; indeed, 14 new training specialist posts around Australia. The thinking behind it is that, if you train people in the country and they become accustomed to the lifestyle, they are more likely to return there and to practise.

I am particularly pleased to inform the member for Calare that $140,000 has been provided to the Central-West Health Service in Orange for an obstetrics and gynaecology training position, something that is much needed. Through this initiative of the 14 training posts, there will be positions in a number of specialties—ophthalmology, surgery, internal medicine and radiation oncology. They will be established in Townsville, Cairns, Kalgoorlie, Bunbury, Swan Hill, Wagga Wagga and Alice Springs. In addition, there are psychiatric training posts to be established in Broken Hill, Alice Springs and Mount Isa, because we know there has been poor access to psychiatric services. Part of the mental health strategy is to improve that.

Through the means I have just announced, some 40 additional specialists will enter the work force over the next four years who will have had unique training in country areas. Part of that training will be to provide outreach services to Aboriginal communities in the remote parts of Australia. I am sure that members understand we cannot compel practitioners to work in the country, but we can certainly assist them to have a better knowledge of it and to provide their services through this means.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

—Mr Speaker, I refer to the hiring next week of the Great Hall to the Moonie organisation called the Family Federation for Unification and World Peace Australia, registered as an Australian company early this month. I do not wish to go into the controversies that surround this organisation other than to point out that there is sufficient literature in the Parliamentary Library to describe its origins and philosophies, and business and political activities. My question is: who is responsible for hiring out the Great Hall; is some assessment made of the bona fides of applicants and, if not, is it available to all and any fringe groups that might apply; and would the League of Rights be acceptable?

—In respect of the general issue that the honourable member has raised, I can say that an organisation misrepresented itself to the President, officers of this parliament and me in respect of wanting to hire out the Great Hall for a function. When that misrepresentation was discovered, the original granting of approval was withdrawn. It was clearly outside what had been established over a long period as acceptable guidelines. With respect to the detail of the three parts of the question you put to me, I will be happy to get a response and get back to you.
