—Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate ministers:

PETITION.TITLE: Marriage
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows that:

We believe that the traditional Christian view of the family unit excludes anything other than a male and female, living in a lawful marriage relationship, along with their children, and that it is necessary for this to be restated by our political leaders.
We reaffirm our belief in the traditional Christian view of marriage as God's holy institution in which male and female become one flesh. (Genesis 2.24; Matthew 19.5,6)

We reaffirm that God is the author of marriage, and has restricted it to the union of male with female and that such marriage between male and female is commended in Scripture as honourable among all. (Ephesians 5.15-23)
We reaffirm that such marriage between male and female is ordained for life-long companionship, help and comfort which husband and wife ought to have of each other. (Romans 7.2,3)

We reaffirm that children are a heritage of the Lord and should be nurtured in a Godly home, and that human society can be strong and happy only where the marriage bond is held in honour. (Psalm 127.3)

We reaffirm that incestuous marriages can never be made lawful by the law of any man or government, or the consent of parties, so as to allow those people to live together as married couples. (Mark 6.18; Leviticus 18.6-28)

We reaffirm that, according to Biblical law, it is forbidden for a male to practise sexual intercourse with another male, or for a female with a female, and that since this is an abomination before the Lord, such is a prohibited relationship for marriage. (Leviticus 18.22; 20.13)
We believe the entire stability and well being of our society depends on maintaining this traditional Christian view of marriage and family (Leviticus 20.15-16; 18.23-24)
Your Petitioners ask that the House of Representatives should call on the Government to:
(A) Preserve completely intact the exclusiveness of marriage as being one male and one female.
(B) That the definition of a prohibited relationship in the Marriage Act 1961, Part III 23(2) be amended with the addition of a new clause (c) so that it reads as follows:
(2) Marriages of parties within a prohibited relationship are marriages:
(a) between a person and an ancestor or descendant of the person; or
(b) between a brother and a sister (whether of the whole blood or the half blood); or
(c) between a male and a male or between a female and a female.
Your petitioners humbly pray.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mrs Easson (from five citizens), Mr Tim Fischer (from 61 citizens) and Mr Hicks (from 36 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Family Law Act
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House the need for changes to the Family Law Act of Australia and to the child support scheme.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House enact the following changes.

PETITION.PARA: (1)That the existing Family Law Act be scrapped and replaced by a more simplified version together with the minimum of rules and regulations necessary.

(2)That the Family Court be replaced by a Tribunal and that all matters resulting from divorce and family breakdown be heard before, and determined by a panel; the panel to be made up of persons qualified in matters arising from family breakdown.
(3)That legal professionals be barred from appearing before the Tribunal resulting in vast savings to the disputing parties.
(4)That a modified fault clause be re-introduced to Family Law primarily designed to discourage adultery and to stop rewarding adulterers at the expense of deserted and innocent parties.
(5)That the Child Support Agency be scrapped and replaced by an appropriate administrative procedure within the Tribunal.
(6)That apart from cases of exceptional circumstances parental-child access become the inalienable right of all parents.

(7)That alternative counselling, (Government funded) be made available through the Churches and that much more emphasis be placed on mediation in resolving disputes prior to the commencement of legal proceedings.

PETITION.TITLE: Bears
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain residents of the State of Western Australia draws to the attention of the House that approximately 8,000 bears are being kept in cages in China for the purpose of extracting bile for medical purposes and that the cages are so small the bears cannot move, which results in some of them going mad. It is further brought to the attention of the House that the Chinese plan to increase the number of bears, for these purposes, to 40,000.
Your petitioners therefore respectfully ask the House of Representatives to object most strongly to this horrendous and tragic practice and ask that steps be taken to stop it immediately.

PETITION.TITLE: Compact Discs
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the Speaker, and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.

PARA.TAB: The following citizens of Australia remind the House of the 1990 Prices Surveillance Authority findings that Australians pay up to 40 per cent more for compact discs than overseas consumers.
Your petitioners therefore request that the House takes action along the lines recommended by the PSA and allows parallel importing of compact discs to reduce costs to Australian consumers.

PETITION.TITLE: Water Supply
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned expresses opposition to the transfer of control and ownership of Australian public utilities. We oppose any moves to hand over publicly owned water management to overseas companies, in particular French interests.

Your petitioners request the House of Representatives to exercise its legislative powers through the Foreign Investment Review Board or use its external powers to prevent the transfer of Australian control of its water system.

PETITION.TITLE: Postal Agency: Killarney Vale
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament assembled.
The petition of the citizens respectfully showeth:

The lack of a post office agency in the shopping centre of Killarney Vale is causing inconvenience for citizens and retailers. Since the departure of the former post office many citizens have had to travel out of their preferred shopping area to avail themselves of postal facilities.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your honourable House move to support our application to install a post office agency in Killarney Vale Pharmacy, 138 Wyong Road, Killarney Vale to meet the needs of shoppers and retailers.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: ABC: 7.30 Report
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of certain residents of the State of Queensland, draw to the attention of the House that we wish to have the Queensland 7.30pm Report currently shown on the ABC, retained.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to use their best offices to cause the ABC to continue to produce that Queensland State based 7.30 Report.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare Office: Toukley, Norah Head and Noraville
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain electors of the Division of Shortland draws to the attention of the House that residents of Toukley, Norah Head and Noraville have been seriously disadvantaged by the closure of the Toukley Medicare/Medibank office.
Your petitioners request the House to require the Health Insurance Commission to re-establish a Medicare/Medibank service in Toukley NSW.

PETITION.TITLE: Private Health Insurance Cover
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.
We the undersigned citizens of Australia draw to the attention of the House:

PARA.TAB: The failure of the Federal Government to properly address the problem of the high costs of private health insurance cover;
Highlight that these costs are forcing more people to abandon private health insurance, and in doing so is placing greater pressure on an already over-burdened public hospital system.

PETITION.PARA: And your petitioners in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Landmines
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives:

PARA.TAB: This petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that many countries, which have been the scene of conflict, are infested with tens of millions of landmines/anti-personnel mines which were not removed after hostilities ceased.

PETITION.PARA: that although the military effectiveness of landmines/anti-personnel mines is open to question they do continue to kill and maim civilian men, women and children long after the conflict has ended
that the infestation prevents people returning to their homes and livelihoods and renders vast areas of land unusable for any purpose

PARA.TAB: Your petitioners request the House to:
(1)Support the campaign to ban the production, stockpiling, sale and use of landmines/anti-personnel mines.
(2)Support the establishment of an international fund to pay for clearance operations with contributions from the producers and sellers of landmines/anti-personnel mines.
(3)Support the establishment of a fund for rehabilitation work with victims and co-operative rehabilitation programs.
(4)Urge the international community to support these endeavours.

PETITION.TITLE: Division of Richmond
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain electors in the Division of Richmond draws to the attention of the House the appalling delays in completing construction of the Chinderah By-Pass and the approaches to the new Barney's Point Bridge at Banora Point. Completion date has now been pushed back to mid 1997 for the Chinderah By-Pass.

This slow-down has resulted in unreasonable traffic delays in negotiating the existing inadequate bridge and approaches, an increasingly high accident rate; inconvenience, pollution and adverse effects on residents and businesses due to extended and continuing construction work over more than two years.
We ask the House to urgently consider making Federal funding available in order to complete the project and have the bridge and approaches open for traffic by mid 1996 at the latest.

PETITION.TITLE: Audio Tapes and Compact Discs
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that music containing lyrics that are sexually explicit, physically violent and promote the use and abuse of drugs are freely available to children of any age at most record stores.

Your petitioners therefore request the House to apply a classification similar to the classifications used on Films and Videos on all such Audio Tapes and Compact Discs and to place a restriction on the sale of music containing such lyrics to minors.
Question proposed:
That grievances be noted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vaile Mr M.A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is certainly a pleasure this afternoon to be able to address the parliament on a very important issue that has been playing on the minds of a lot of my constituents for a number of years and is something that I have taken a personal interest in: the structure of the petroleum industry in Australia, the way that the industry is conducted and run, and the involvement of the government of Australia in parts of that industry with the regulation of prices for the wholesale price of petroleum and also with regulations for the setting of freight differentials. There are a number of other associated issues which are forming points of contention at the moment.

PARA.TAB: I draw the House's attention to two reports that have been done in the last 18 months on the petroleum industry. The first, the Industry Commission report into petroleum products, was undertaken at the instigation of the government. This report was handed to the government on 5 July 1994. Interestingly, the government response came out on 21 September 1995—well and truly over 12 months afterwards. I think that is a bit of an indictment on the government's interest in this particular issue. At about the same time this year, a report was put together in fairly quick fashion in New South Wales, at the instigation of the New South Wales government, titled the Parry report.

The Parry report was probably a bit more concise and understanding of the real issues that face consumers and small business people, particularly in regional Australia, with the costing and the structure of the industry. There are a number of very similar recommendations in both these reports which the government has basically chosen to ignore or not to act upon. It raises the question why. There are as many constituencies detrimentally affected by the way the industry is run at the moment represented by government members as there are represented by coalition members.

This matter is continually raised by members of the government yet they have chosen to do nothing. They have acknowledged the recommendations in these reports but have chosen to do nothing. I will read a couple of the more salient recommendations from the Industry Commission report, which was presented, as I say, to the Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear) on 5 July 1994. The very first recommendation states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Commonwealth should withdraw the Ministerial Directions and terminate the existing price surveillance arrangements in relation to petroleum products.

That is very important. That means: remove the Prices Surveillance Authority from the whole equation of establishing the rack price, or the wholesale price, and from the outmoded, outdated, antiquated process of setting the freight differentials around Australia. The other interesting recommendation states:

The Commonwealth Government should encourage the Australian Petroleum Agents and Distributors Association, the Transport Workers Union and the oil majors to accelerate the withdrawal of the Laidley Agreement by negotiation. Failing progress in that direction, the Government should consider legislation to eliminate those provisions in the Agreement that have the effect of restricting competition.

The Laidley agreement is a very restrictive industrial agreement. Those two key issues were highlighted in the recommendations that the Industry Commission put in its report to the minister. Interestingly, those same issues arose in the Parry report, which was done for the New South Wales government, because at the time of the New South Wales election early in 1995 petrol prices were, and still are, a very hot issue around regional New South Wales.

PARA.TAB: The Parry report is the result of one of the very few promises that the now Premier Bob Carr managed to keep. He said he would instigate a review of petrol prices in regional New South Wales, and he did. In the report Professor Parry again highlighted the same problems with the same recommendations that were highlighted in the Industry Commission report—they being in recommendation 2 of the Parry report, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: In the absence of any more substantial deregulation of PSA set charges, at least the PSA freight charge be removed subject to competitive access to terminals and depots by approved freight transporters, actual freight charges to be subject to market forces.

In one recommendation the Parry report has focused on some of the key problems in the petroleum industry at the moment, including the intervention of the PSA and ministerial directions. Interestingly enough, some of the briefings to which I have been a party have highlighted the artificial way in which the wholesale price of motor spirit in Australia is set.

PARA.TAB: One oil company representative was asked what relativity there was between the wholesale price of fuel as set by the Prices Surveillance Authority—it used to be about 69c a litre and, at the end of last week, it went up to over 70c a litre, which is an increase of over 1c a litre—and the price set by the oil companies. In answer to that question, the representative said, `The Prices Surveillance Authority sets the wholesale price of fuel. That's what we, the oil companies, charge.' Further to that, he said that the oil companies do not know what it costs them to produce a litre of motor spirit which is ready to go onto the market, which is a bit hard to believe. But the point is that the PSA sets a ceiling and everybody charges accordingly.

In this day and age of the Hilmer reforms, both the Industry Commission report and the Parry report are recommending the elimination of that intervention, particularly by the Prices Surveillance Authority as far as the freight costs are concerned. It is so antiquated. In my electorate, there is a difference of almost 2c a litre in freight charges between two towns—Port Macquarie and Wauchope—which are probably about 22 kilometres apart. The cost of freight in the smaller centre, Wauchope, is 2c a litre cheaper than in Port Macquarie, which is on the coast. When questioned as to why there is a price differential, the Prices Surveillance Authority said, `Well, isn't Wauchope on the rail line?' Wauchope is on the north coast rail line. There is your answer: because Wauchope is on the rail line and it is closer, the freight costs are cheaper. But every single litre of motor spirit that comes into my electorate is transported by road; it has got nothing to with rail freight anymore. Yet the people in Port Macquarie are being penalised by almost 2c a litre because they are not on the rail line.

The whole process needs to be reviewed. The transportation of fuel in Australia should be deregulated and proper market forces should prevail. To do that, we need legislative action to get rid of the Laidley agreement in order to give all operators access to fuel refineries so that they can have access to suitably qualified transport drivers and equipment to transport fuel. The government, in its response to the Industry Commission report, did not identify and would not address the issue of deregulation. Recommendation No. 3 of the Industry Commission report reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The Commonwealth Government should encourage the Australian Petroleum Agents and Distributors Association, the Transport Workers Union and the oil majors to accelerate the withdrawal of the Laidley Agreement by negotiation. Failing progress in this direction, the Government should consider legislation to eliminate these provisions in the agreement.
The government response which was put out by Minister Gear on 21 September this year—almost 18 months after he received the report—states:
The withdrawal of the Laidley Agreement is supported in principle. The Commonwealth believes withdrawal would be best achieved through the enterprise bargaining process.

But what happens to the enterprise bargaining process? We have seen what has happened in the last week as a result of the government's enterprise bargaining process. As soon as some of the mates do not like it, it all falls apart. It will not happen. There is no motivation for the government, as a result of that recommendation by the minister concerned, to see this happen.

PARA.TAB: We cannot deregulate. We cannot say that we must have open competition in one sector and then have the government saying that we are not going to have open competition in another sector and protecting that other sector from competition by saying, `No, we're not going to let anybody compete with the ACTU or those people who are involved in those union organised industries.' The government needs to be fair dinkum in that regard.

In conclusion, another point that raises its head in this whole debate about the cost of fuel—the difference in the cost of fuel is not apparent just between metropolitan and country areas—is the fact that, as of 1 August this year, the Commonwealth government collects 33.5c in excise from every litre of motor spirit sold. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleeland Mr P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The greyhound racing industry in Victoria is corrupt. It is rotten through and through. The time has long passed for the Victorian government to appoint a royal commission to inquire into all aspects of the greyhound racing industry and the dog breeding industry associated with it.

PARA.TAB: My interest in greyhound racing started when a number of my constituents approached me late last year concerned about a major dog breeding fraud. This fraud involved a dog known as Malawi Prince, owned by Mr Tony Lockett. The fraud was fairly simple: the owner of a bitch took her along to be mated with Malawi Prince for a fee of up to $1,500, but instead of being mated with Malawi Prince it turned out that the bitch was mated with a lesser sire, so an inferior dog was produced.

This is not a secret. It is known that this has occurred. DNA testing has now been conducted on a number of dogs allegedly bred from Malawi Prince, and it has been identified that the dogs could not have been bred with Malawi Prince as the sire. The only issue so far as this fraud in Victoria is concerned is just how many dogs are involved. My constituents estimate that up to 40 individual dogs involved in the breeding industry in Victoria could have been falsely alleged to have been bred with Malawi Prince as the sire.

This is very important, because the fraud upsets the whole breeding line of dogs in Victoria. But, worse than that, it is a fraud, a scam. A lot of money has been paid by reasonably earning people, and they have been ripped off. The problem they face is that it costs hundreds of dollars to have a DNA test done. Most of the people whom I represent are only wage earners, and some of them do dog racing and dog breeding as a hobby. They have enough trouble raising and breeding their dogs without being hit with a massive fee for DNA testing to see whether their dogs have been appropriately bred or not.

As a result of the information on that fraud, I got in touch with the relevant minister, Mr Tom Reynolds, in Victoria. I raised those allegations with him. He wrote back and told me that the police were investigating this dog breeding scam and that I would hear more about it. Shortly after that I received, anonymously, a document. This document will be called a scandal sheet. It has the most outrageous allegations contained in it. When I read it I thought that I could not possibly use any of this material, that it does not seem to be particularly fair.

The document alleges, among other things, that for a fee of up to $500 you can bribe the official in charge of selecting the racing boxes at dog meetings. It alleges that it is quite easy—you just pay $500 and choose the box from which you want to start your dog. It says that the practice is very common. It also alleges that the lure operator can be bribed to manipulate the speed of the lure, so manipulating the outcome of a particular race. It makes allegations of massive drug use, particularly with beta-blockers.

The document makes allegations of corruption among members of the Greyhound Racing Control Board and other officials of the greyhound industry in Victoria. For example, it says that a bookmaker removed a swab sample from a head steward's car and that that swab sample was taken from a dog owned by the very same bookmaker. It goes on and on making the most serious allegations.

Not only does it make those allegations but it also names the people involved. It is not my practice in this House to name people unless I have evidence that substantiates the allegations put to me. Most members understand where I stand on this issue. In the document, there was an allegation concerning Tom Reynolds, the Victorian minister who is in charge of dog racing in Victoria. I will quote from the document. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: For years—
Mr Reynolds—

raced greyhounds provided for him by the GRCB and Kevin Richards, who ensured an ongoing relationship, thus keeping Reynolds "in check". While stating publicly of not being a big punter (50 cents) was often seen at Warragul with a fistful of 100 dollar notes punting his dogs. Little did he realise that the only people to benefit from his gambling were Kevin Richards, working hand in hand with the bookmaker!
Reynolds continues to support the GRCB and its present members, even though they all consider him to be a dead set dill.
When I read that originally, I said, `That's pretty scandalous. There is obviously nothing in that. That's not true.' That was the case until I picked up the Herald-Sun of 17 November 1995. It said:
Sports Minister Tom Reynolds was given a lucrative lease of a greyhound, which won $15,715, through a government body he now regulates.

PARA.TAB: Mr Reynolds yesterday admitted the arrangement, in which he shared a lease with former Liberal Party state president Michael Kroger.
Under the deal with the dog's owners, the Greyhound Racing Control Board, he and Mr Kroger repaid 1 per cent of their winnings to the board.

SPEECH.PARA: That was the cost of him getting a lease of the dog from the board. The document alleges that this has been going on for a long time—ever since Mr Reynolds has been a member of parliament, and when he was shadow minister. As I said, I did not believe it. I thought it was scandalous. Yet here it is confirmed in the Herald-Sun of 17 November that the Victorian minister responsible for the control of the dog racing industry in Victoria has been party to an arrangement where he got, for one per cent of the winning cost, a lease of a dog. The article continued:
Trainers of the dog, Liberal Victory—
a good name: Liberal Victory—
estimated their costs to be about half of the winnings, leaving about $8000 profit for Mr Reynolds and Mr Kroger.

That is not a bad deal, is it? For no outlay at all, you pick up a cool eight grand, plus, if you know what is going on at the track, the gambling profits through the bookies—and, if this document is to be believed, they are all crooked as well. Who knows how much Mr Reynolds could have made out of what is, at the best, a deal he should never have entered into?

PARA.TAB: That concerned me. That report confirms much of what is involved in the document which I have said is a scandal sheet. It makes allegations about corrupt officials, corrupt breeding, corruption in politics and corruption amongst officials and bookmakers—corruption through this whole industry, which, it appears to me now, is absolutely rotten. It is confirmed.

What was the response of the Victorian Liberal government to this? We know what Mr Kennett usually says when he finds out that ministers tell lies—like Mr Baxter in parliament. He said on 3AW, `So what?' That is his response when his ministers are found doing things which in this parliament the opposition would draw attention to. Mr Kennett simply says, `So what?' Mr Reynolds simply said that he raised it after he had been minister for a few weeks, but there was nothing wrong with that. He said that the money won on the animal refinanced three other dogs he leased. Not a bad deal if you can get it!

On 18 November, the Herald-Sun published a report saying that the police were conducting four probes into the greyhound industry in Victoria, alleging around $2 million worth of racing rorts, including drugging of dogs. Suddenly this scandal sheet is not so scandalous. Suddenly the names and the allegations that are contained in this scandal sheet are not so scandalous; they may be true.

In Victoria the minister who is in charge of investigating the whole deal is part of a deal where he gets an unfair profit out of the system. You cannot expect on that basis to get a fair and proper investigation. In Victoria we have allegations, a minister who is deep in the middle of the allegations and a state Premier who does not care what his ministers do. Where do we go? The only answer, and the fairest answer, is for Mr Kennett to urgently introduce a royal commission with a very broad reference to inquire into all aspects of the dog racing industry in Victoria. Otherwise, obviously, dog racing in Victoria will be suspect; it will continue to be described as rotten and corrupt and the small owners of dogs—the little people out there who we hear the opposition talk about—will continue to be ripped off with dog breeding scams and drugging of their dogs in racing.

It is an outrageous set of affairs. I call on Mr Kennett and the Victorian Liberal Party to do something about it. Mr Reynolds should have the decency to retire from his ministerial position and Mr Kennett has no option but to call a royal commission.

TALK.START.PARA: —Together with many other Queenslanders, I was horrified to read a story in yesterday's Sunday Mail headlined `Police bungle drugs sting'. The story was about a Brisbane man who, working in cooperation with the Queensland Police Service's drug squad, had made chemicals available to criminals for the manufacture of amphetamines allegedly worth `millions of dollars'. These chemicals were sold to drug syndicates over two years as part of a covert police operation.

PARA.TAB: It is claimed that the operation did not result in any arrest and no drugs were seized. Instead, it is believed that the chemicals have been used for the illegal manufacture of amphetamines which have an estimated value of $6 million and which are now being sold on the Gold Coast.

As I said a minute ago, I was horrified to read this, as I am sure many Queensland parents were too. Today marks the beginning of what is referred to as `Schoolies Week' in Queensland, when many thousands of young school leavers celebrate the end of their high school education by holidaying on the Gold Coast. Whilst most of these young people are law abiding, the week has become notorious for rowdy, destructive—and self-destructive—behaviour by some. It is believed that the worst behaviour is, as often as not, committed by non-school leavers: young hooligans who come to the Gold Coast under cover of `Schoolies Week' to behave in a destructive and rowdy manner. In past years, drugs—notably amphetamines—have been very much part of this scene. Therefore, the suggestion that millions of dollars worth of drugs have been manufactured—courtesy of a failed police operation—in time for sale this week on the Gold Coast is one that must fill many parents with dread.

However, the Brisbane chemical manufacturer who supplied the chemicals for these drugs is now in hiding in fear of his life. The Sunday Mail story states that he owes $30,000 to a drug syndicate, a down payment for chemicals police had him make but would not then let him sell to it. It also claims that he is being held responsible by members of a drug syndicate for a recent police raid on the gang's premises. Further, New South Wales police have threatened to charge him for supplying chemicals, even though he had been given indemnity in the operation by Queensland police and a Queensland detective had indicated to him that there would be no charges from New South Wales if he kept quiet about this failed police operation.

This story should fill every member of the Australian parliament with apprehension. Recently the House of Representatives passed some legislation which has the effect of enabling members of the Australian Federal Police to become involved in illegal activities if they are part of a covert operation. Many people have misgivings about `legitimising' this type of police activity. Yesterday's Sunday Mail story would reinforce such apprehensions. It is one of many stories where police have become involved in this type of activity, to no good end result—namely, the arrest of people who run Australia's illegal drug trade.

Lest anyone seek consolation in the suggestion that, because it is the Queensland Police Service who have bungled this operation, the actions of other police forces should not be similarly critically scrutinised, the fact is that there is plenty of evidence that our various police forces are prone to either making the same types of errors or treating our citizens in a callously negligent manner.

Recently I was approached by a constituent who had voluntarily worked with the New South Wales police force in a similar type of operation. I wish to make it very clear that this constituent of mine has not himself engaged in any illegal activity before, during or since the incident I am referring to. He was a legitimate businessman who had never had any problems with the police in his life but who came by some information which, as a responsible citizen, he made available to the police. Thanks to his undercover work, undertaken under the supervision and direction of the New South Wales police, arrests were made in that case and trials are pending.

Parliament's sub judice convention precludes me from giving further details of the case lest the people involved be identified and the case prejudiced. However, I can say that as a consequence of those arrests my constituent lives in fear of his life, under severe financial duress, because he has had to abandon his business, his livelihood, as a direct consequence of the serious nature of the matter in which he assisted the police. All this has happened because he does not have recourse to the benefits of codified witness protection legislation or guidelines. They are non-existent in New South Wales.

Recently the House of Representatives enacted witness protection provisions. The act was also meant to be a model for state governments to follow, but very few have done anything about it. Indeed, one of my reasons for raising this issue is to urge the Minister for Justice (Mr Kerr) to take immediate action to persuade those states which do not have witness protection legislation to act on it quickly.

As things stand, without witness protection legislation state police forces can—and do, to my knowledge—treat ordinary citizens in an utterly unconscionable manner. There are now just too many stories of law-abiding citizens who have endangered their own lives in order to assist law enforcement agencies, only to find themselves destitute because they cannot pursue their previous livelihood from hiding—whether because cases are waiting to be heard in the courts or because police have bungled the operation—and because they have no entitlement to stop-gap financial support for them and their families. For example, my constituent has even had his car repossessed because he could not maintain the payments, and the New South Wales police—having used him to the hilt for their own purposes—are now just turning their backs on him and refusing to ensure that even the basics are provided for him and his family.

Quite apart from the financial penalty that citizens can suffer as a consequence of doing what they see as a duty to help the forces of law and order, there is an enormous psychological burden that has to be borne by them also. Undercover operations are extremely stressful. Members of the police force receive counselling and assistance for the stress and psychological effects they may suffer as a result of undercover operations. However, no such support is given to civilians, who are left to cope as best they can. It is beyond me to fathom the callousness of this attitude, particularly coming from those who experience the same stress themselves—albeit with the more comforting fall-back position of being able to take superannuated early retirement on the basis of the stresses of the job.

For these matters—the provision of financial and/or emotional support—to be at the whim of individual police officers is no way for a civilised society to behave. Maintenance of law and order is, without a doubt, the public issue that Australians feel to be the most important for governments to provide, and they are right to feel that way. The first responsibility of any national government is to maintain the security of the nation, that is, adequate defence. The second responsibility of a national government, and the first responsibility of all state governments, is to maintain the internal security of our society: the protection of the right of citizens to feel that they can live their lives without threat of physical harm for so long as they themselves are law abiding.

The matter does not, however, only rest with various agencies of law and order and any witness protection mechanism that may be put in place. There are other agencies of government which have a role to play. For example, in the case of the constituent I have referred to, a detailed complaint has been made to the New South Wales Ombudsman, which was a very proper course for my constituent to take. However, whilst the office of the ombudsman has indicated that it will deal with this case as expeditiously as possible, there are certain bureaucratic constraints on the ombudsman—which does not help anybody to pay the rent if they find themselves in a similarly unfortunate position. Ombudsmen need the ability to move swiftly where the damage a citizen is suffering is such that there are issues of immediacy, such as how to pay the rent, buy groceries and have reasonable access to proper medical and legal support. Present mechanisms simply do not permit this to happen.

When law-abiding citizens make an honest attempt to assist our agencies of law and order to carry out their responsibilities, they should at least know that they will receive not only reasonable protection from capricious behaviour by those very law and order agencies, but also adequate support in the event that their efforts to assist mean they can no longer support themselves. As I understand it, past efforts in New South Wales to codify witness protection have met with obstruction from the New South Wales Police Force itself. There are a number of probable reasons for this—some of them may be plausible; others could be sinister.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last year, the Australian Maritime Safety Authority detained 153 ships with serious safety deficiencies. This year up to October, AMSA has detained 203 ships. Some people might argue that this means that more defective ships are visiting Australian ports. On the contrary, however, it means that AMSA has been more vigilant and, dare I say it, better resourced and funded than in the past.

PARA.TAB: However welcome these substandard ship detentions are, there is a much more insidious practice on the Australian coastline, which no-one seems to care about or, apparently, Australian law is deficient to overcome. This is the maltreatment, the brutality, the abuse, the starvation wages, appalling food and the general lack of conditions that seafarers from many Third World countries are experiencing within Australian territorial waters.

Make no mistake, if these activities were committed onshore, people regardless of where they came from would be charged and, in many cases rightfully, thrown into gaol. Not only are these crimes being committed, but they are going without punishment, and they are permitted to continue going unpunished. I think there is an element of racism here because many of the seafarers concerned are from Third World countries.

I could go on about the many incidents I have heard about seafarers mysteriously disappearing or going overboard, and of seafarers being bashed and brutalised, through my close association with the Mission to the Seaman. Rarely are such incidents ever brought to the attention of the media in Australia. We are talking about bashings, disappearances and, indeed, murder.

I want to draw the attention of the House to an incident involving a Japanese owned but Panamanian registered vessel, Glory Cape, two weeks ago off the coast of Western Australia when the ship was at anchor off Dampier and the Indonesian crew were involved in a dispute with the Korean officials of the vessel over pay and working conditions.

A brawl erupted on the Glory Cape after two of the Indonesian crew, who were arguing for better working conditions, went to the captain on this. On the instructions of the Korean captain, Korean crew members took iron bars and bashed the Indonesian crew and bashed one crew member, the radio operator, to such an extent that he has now died. That is murder and that will go unpunished because this ship has now left Australian waters.

While the Glory Cape was alongside her berth in Karratha, the seven Indonesian crew approached the International Transport Federation's West Australian inspector, Norm Pickles, to negotiate with the vessel's operator, First Line Corp. of Seoul, through their agents in Australia, Burns Philp, to get them an ITF acceptable agreement.

Negotiations were set to begin after the vessel had been loaded and berthed. The master assured the ITF inspector that this is what would happen. Mr Pickles was later called by the radio operator who said that the master had ordered the engineers to start the engine.

Mr Pickles asked the radio officer to put the master on the phone, but the master was very agitated and he tried to assure Mr Pickles that the engines were only going on in the expectation of unfavourable weather. The master assured Mr Pickles that he had no intention of setting sail. However, allegedly due to pressure from the vessel's owners, the master decided to sail. It was at this point that the Indonesian crew confronted the master and the thuggery began.

Five of the crew jumped seven metres into the waters off Dampier and one, the radio operator, a 28-year-old Indonesian seafarer, died as a result of this thuggery or, as I would say, was murdered, which is all too common in territorial waters around the world and which is becoming too common around Australia.

For four hours the crew huddled together in treacherous, shark infested waters, before they were spotted by a Woodside Petroleum helicopter at 6.45 a.m.—and the master of the vessel did not even inform the authorities that people had gone overboard, which by international law you are supposed to do. The dead man was flown ashore by helicopter and the others, suffering hypothermia, were taken by boat to the hospital. The Glory Cape then was detained by AMSA while several breaches in safety standards were rectified. But one Indonesian crewman at this time had the gall to complain about conditions on the vessel and appeal to the authorities to intervene.

According to the West Australian representatives of the International Transport Federation, work records and overtime records indicated that the crew were being paid well below ILO levels and were working excessive overtime. Of the seven crew involved, four were earning $380 a month, two were paid $750 a month and the radio operator earned around $1,000 a month.

The ILO minimum monthly wage is set at $US780, while the International Transport Federation minimum is $1,100 per month. So, if you are a foreign seafarer working in conditions and being paid well below what is reasonable as identified by the standards of the ILO, which is the circumstance in this case, and you complain or ask for the assistance of the authorities, you are bashed and brutalised, you are forced to jump ship because you fear for your life, or you are killed.

As a country, Australia has led the charge to clean up ship standards. The House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure produced a report, Ships of shame, which was rightly lauded throughout the world. But, although we have cleaned up the ships, what have we done about the conditions of the crews? As I mentioned at the beginning of my remarks, AMSA has increased substandard ship detentions, and that is why this vessel, the Glory Cape, was detained. But, while we have led the charge to clean up the physical side of vessels, much more needs to be done to ensure that the pay and working conditions of crews on vessels are improved. It seems that Australian law is impotent when crews are abused and threatened.

Much of this could be changed if Australia were to ratify ILO convention 147. AMSA should be concerned with the condition of crews; it is as much a safety issue as defective conditions on board vessels. I understand that negotiations and consultations with the states are progressing well and, hopefully, ILO convention 147 will be ratified next year.

Every day foreign nationals are being bashed and abused on ships in Australian waters, and Australian authorities feel they are powerless to do anything about it. Of course, the foreign crews are often very reluctant to lay charges because they know that they or their families in their home countries will be victimised. It is time that these things were brought out in the open. Indeed, I understand the Indonesian government, through its consul in Western Australia, has raised these issues with the Australian authorities.

It is also important that the situation regarding Japanese fishing ships in Australian waters be examined and the arrangements that they have, especially the sham training schemes that are in existence. I would ask the minister to have a look at some of these sham training schemes.

There are too many ships like the Glory Cape around the Australian coastline. This is the sort of thing that we can expect if the ANL sale proceeds and the Australian coastline is even further opened up to foreign-flagged and foreign-crewed vessels. As Australians, we would not tolerate bashings, especially bashings leading to death on land, so why should we tolerate it at sea, especially in Australian territorial waters? It is a tragedy and a disgrace that cannot be tolerated any longer.

Apart from being detained for some time while some defects were rectified on the Glory Cape, the Glory Cape has left Australian waters. No charges will be brought against the captain or the Korean thugs who, acting on the captain's orders, bashed the Indonesian seafarers and, as I say, bashed them to such an extent that they feared for their lives and jumped overboard—the radio operator died. I believe that captain and the Korean crew acting on the captain's instructions were guilty of murder in Australian waters and that they should be charged.

This is not an isolated incident; it is happening every day. If foreign crews complain in ports in Australia, or if they contact the International Transport Federation, more than likely they will disappear. Foreign crews are being pushed overboard along the Australian coastline—ask anyone from the Missions to Seamen. This is one of the reasons I have always been opposed to giving up cabotage, and I have always been opposed to the further opening up of our territorial waters or our coastline to foreign crews. As I said, many of these people are reluctant to complain because, if they do, their families are victimised. They are placed on a black list, and they are in fear of their lives. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —In November 1995, certainly in South Australia, in Western Australia, in most of Victoria and in parts, but only parts, of New South Wales and Queensland, much of rural Australia is enjoying what promises to be a very good harvest in the face of rising prices. As the Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs (Mr Bilney) at the table would be aware, not only are the broadacre farmers enjoying a rather more profitable outlook but also his constituents and mine in the wine industry are looking forward to a very promising harvest.
—And barley.

—One could in fact say that this is something of an idyllic time to be in rural Australia as there are plenty of farmers going around listening to the grain running into the backs of their headers and smiling at the prospect of delivering into what are more and more promising grain markets—and barley markets, as the minister at the table interjected. You could say that rural Australia is the place to be. After all, at a superficial glance you would see nothing but plenty of fresh air, open space, what would be regarded as a generally less stressful lifestyle than in urban Australia, and all in all the right sort of environment in which to raise a family. It ought to be the healthiest section of the nation.

PARA.TAB: But a report, discussion paper No. 9, to the Australian National University done by the National Centre for Epidemiology and Population Health has indicated an astonishing figure that women in rural Australia are 90 per cent more likely to die from pneumonia or influenza—astonishing, given what one would expect to be the fresh air that characterises rural Australia—and 50 per cent more likely to die from diabetes or a car accident than are their counterparts in urban Australia.

I was prompted to raise these matters in this grievance debate by remarks made earlier today in a private member's motion by the member for Parkes (Mr Cobb), supported by the member for Riverina (Mr Hicks), reflecting on the absence of rural doctors and the need for the government to adopt a strategy to encourage doctors into rural practice. I noted that the motion had cross-party involvement in that the member for Hunter (Mr Fitzgibbon) was also involved. Ironically, it coincided with a question asked today by the member for Calare (Mr Simmons) to the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) in answer to which she announced a government initiative to encourage the appointment of more specialist medical officers into rural areas, that $2.1 million would be available for additional specialist services and that $140,000 was to be earmarked for one specific rural area.

I do not speak here simply to blacken the government's name by suggesting that there is a desperate need for additional medical practitioners in rural Australia, though there certainly is, but I was prompted to participate in this debate by one of the comments made by the member for Hunter, who, I thought, mischievously implied that until 1992 nothing had been done. If what the member for Hunter said was right, the government stands condemned for having been idle for a decade on this issue of what ought to happen in rural Australia. But let us ignore that for just a moment and focus on a real disadvantage that currently exists for rural people simply because of their inability to access the medical services that urban people have come to take for granted.

I freely acknowledge the member for Hunter's point that in 1992 something happened: in the 1992 budget a rural health curriculum was announced to enable a particular focus on the training of doctors for rural practice and as part of a general practice reform package there was a proposal to earmark $2.5 million specifically to recruit GPs into rural practices.

However, this came after a decade of inaction, and the fruits of these 1992 initiatives are still scarcely being seen. In fact, so desperate was the state of rural medical practices in my state of South Australia that the South Australian government stepped in just recently and announced a $50,000 rural health scholarship scheme which it intends to use specifically to encourage young men and women to take up medicine as a career. In order to assist them with the costs of being trained in an appropriate medical career as either a GP or a specialist, $5,000 will be made available to each of those young people over a three-year period—$15,000 in total—on the understanding that for every year that they are beneficiaries of that government input they will mirror a year in rural service.

TALK.START.PARA: —They have chopped $35 million out of the public system.

—The minister interjects and takes me away from the thrust of my remarks by suggesting that there has been some pruning of medical services in South Australia, a point I would not attempt to deny. I would merely point out to the minister that the pruning has been necessary because the South Australian government inherited a budget deficit such as no-one would want.

PARA.TAB: The reality remains that in rural Australia there is a desperate need for enhanced general practice and specialist services. Even the announcement made by the minister in question time today will not do enough to meet that need. In the face of drought and depressed prices a statement was made by the Rural Drug and Alcohol Issues Conference in Dubbo. The conference statement indicated:

SPEECH.PARA: Drug misuse, particularly alcohol, is having a devastating social and economic impact on rural Australia. In many rural communities, the level of alcohol misuse is well above the national average, and drug related harm, including accidents, violence and crime, are major sources of community concern.

Add to that a further revelation out of that conference that 36 per cent of men in rural areas in the face of drought and depressed prices were found to be aggressive with their families, 33 per cent experienced uncontrollable loss of temper and 75 per cent had never been checked for cancer. You have a situation which reveals a dramatic need for additional rural medical services, a need which is largely not being met.

PARA.TAB: In my own electorate this need is also reflected. I have here, for example, a comment from Dr David Rosenthal, a Renmark based doctor in the Riverland area of South Australia who is also the President of the Rural Doctors Association of Australia. Dr Rosenthal calculates that in order to meet the need for doctors in Renmark, in one of those idyllic areas of South Australia, the Riverland—

TALK.START.PARA: —I was born there.

—Where the minister was born. Mercifully for him there was a doctor present, I imagine. But in this idyllic area, within 2 1/2 hours of the city of Adelaide by a sealed road, in a large and progressive rural town, they are having difficulty meeting the need for rural practice. Dr Rosenthal calculates that Renmark alone could use an additional four GPs to meet the criteria for doctors that have been laid down by the member for Parkes in the statistics he brought to the House earlier today.

PARA.TAB: There is also the situation in Balaclava, one to 1 1/2 hours north of Adelaide. A physiotherapist practising in Balaclava has written to me expressing his concern about his capacity to continue his practice in that rural area. He may need to dissolve the practice. He has a real concern with the failure of South Australians and, I guess, Australians to be privately insured for medical health, which may well spell the end of the practice that he has so successfully cultivated.

It is easy to stand here and be critical. What I want to express to the minister and to the government is that a more rapid solution than we have seen is also in their hands and has been advocated by one of their own but not picked up and run in the debate here on the private member's motion or in response to the question asked today.

The member for Moreton (Mr Gibson) has advocated that the House ought to be looking at encouraging additional rural GPs by offering them additional computer facilities so that they can have on hand the sorts of specialist advice they must currently long for when they have a complicated case which they are forced as a lonely rural GP to deal with on their own. I would encourage the government to pick up the initiatives advocated by the member for Moreton and to this date largely ignored. Rural health continues to be a major issue concerning Australian rural families. The needs in this area will only be met by additional government initiatives. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in the grievance debate today to speak on the ongoing industrial dispute at Weipa, in my electorate. There was no doubt that industrial relations was a major issue in the 1993 federal election. There was no doubt that the coalition industrial relations policy was clearly rejected by the Australian people. CRA and their subsidiary Comalco clearly discarded that decision and began a campaign to take workers off awards and move them onto individual contracts. That was clearly designed to undermine the decision of the Australian people and the traditions of Australian industrial relations.
—That was under your system.

—The honourable member said that it was under our system. I would suggest to him that Mr Ralph and CRA very much hanker after your system, the system that John Howard wants to introduce into Australia. Small work areas in Weipa were the first subject of CRA's attempt to get workers to sign individual contracts. The kaolin plant was a good example of that. No choice was offered for new starts. One of the great myths that has been peddled by both CRA and the opposition is that somehow workers at Weipa have a choice. They do not have any choice. If you come to work at Weipa you get one choice—sign a CRA contract or you don't get a job. That is the choice—
—Your system.
—It is not our system. Our system is a system of both collective bargaining and the maintenance of the award safety net.

PARA.TAB: Certainly not only was there intimidation in regard to the signing of the contracts but also workers who were union activists were isolated and crane drivers were put in stores simply for the purpose of undermining collective bargaining and trade unionism. Clearly, workers were offered over-award payments. It is understandable that workers with heavy family commitments, especially workers with large families, were under enormous pressure by the company to sign up. The striking workers tell me that there was a great deal of coercion put on workers at Weipa to sign up. The fact that a lot of those workers who have signed individual contracts remain trade union members might indicate even to those people opposite that those workers still have a commitment to the trade union movement but may have just been coerced into signing a contract perhaps for financial gain but perhaps because they feared for their jobs.

Those opposite, because they mainly come from the southern states, from Sydney and Melbourne, do not understand the nature of a place like Weipa. They do not understand that it is not near other labour markets. They do not understand the pressure that can be put on workers who work at a site like Weipa and who are told to sign or they will be isolated by the company. That has been the situation at Weipa. If you are a family man and you are faced with that situation then you start to think: where else will I get a job?

Pressure has been put on workers. Some of those workers have signed the contract. There have been calls for the government to introduce legislative change, but it is difficult to see what legislative change could be introduced. We do not want to have a situation where over-award payments are somehow outlawed. What we want is a situation where the principle of equal pay for equal work is recognised and the international principle, the right for workers to collectively bargain, is also recognised. Both of those things have been denied by CRA. It is outrageous that CRA has stated that workers on awards are of less value than workers who have signed contracts.

The striking workers, by definition, are all long-term employees of Comalco. They have given years of service to Comalco. Ten years ago if you went to Weipa and criticised Comalco, all the workers would have quickly come to the defence of Comalco. Today, they simply want to exercise their right to collectively bargain; they want adequate reward for the long years of service that they have given to the company; and they want equal pay for equal work. John Howard wants to deny those principles—
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Rocher)—Order! The member will refer to members by their correct title.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry, Mr Deputy Speaker. The Leader of the Opposition wants to deny this as a principle. He would take away the award safety net and he does not even seem to want to come to the defence of the right to collectively bargain, despite the fact that this is enshrined in ILO conventions, because that is what this dispute is about. I am confident that, through the arbitration that will take place this week, we will have a resolution of the dispute. But I shudder to think of what the workers of both Weipa and the rest of Australia would face under a coalition government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smyth Mr B.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is appropriate to rise in the grievance debate this evening to speak on behalf of the students, the staff and the parents of Covenant College. Covenant College is an independent Christian college located in the suburb of Gordon in my electorate. It is a growing school; it serves a distinct need; and until last week it had recurrent funding for its growing secondary school.

PARA.TAB: Last week, just three weeks before the end of term, the school was advised that because the government had judged the school to be too small no recurrent funding would be forthcoming for next year. That has put great pressure on all the students, the staff and the teachers, but particularly on the students in the lead-up to the end-of-year exams. This funding was denied while the government has in its possession an interim report on the review of its own new schools policy. It is interesting because the rules have changed midstream and this school, Covenant College, is being judged. The report itself says:

SPEECH.PARA: Decisions should not disadvantage particular applicants in mid-process.
It further says:
. . . all schools should be put on the same financial basis as soon as possible.
Covenant College was denied recurrent funding because it was too small, yet the report simply says:
The present requirement for 25 students in each junior secondary year is too onerous.
It goes on to say:
Schools seeking to extend to secondary level and start-up secondary schools with planned extension by adding a new class each year should have four years to reach the total enrolment targets.

It is curious that, while the government has a report that outlines deficiencies in its own new schools policy, it continues to judge some—I say only some—schools on these old criteria while I am told that other schools are allowed to continue. It is interesting because the review has recommended changes to ease the burden on growing schools but, even before the government responds to the review, it withdraws funding from a junior secondary school that fits many of the problems highlighted in the McKinnon report.

PARA.TAB: The college was being judged on the criteria which the government knows it needs to change. I believe that the college would fare far more favourably under the revised criteria recommended in the McKinnon report. To add insult to injury, the school has been lobbying the minister for quite some time now to find out its status. It received this letter saying that funding had been denied on 9 November this year, which is very curious because written notification for recurrent funding closed on 31 October this year. So the poor old school does not have the advantage to even appeal this decision.

I attended a meeting at the school the other night. I admire their determination to continue their school and to continue to provide quality Christian independent education in the Tuggeranong Valley and I thank them for doing that in my electorate. But they cannot even get a meeting with the minister to discuss their future. He has denied them even that option. I find it an absolutely amazing thing that a minister would not even wish to talk to a school about their future.

I see the honourable member for Ballarat (Mr Ronaldson) is the shadow minister at the table. I thank him because he will speak with this school, advise it and assist it in any way that he can, as will I, in dealing with a government that, whilst it knows it has a flawed new schools policy and whilst it knows it has the McKinnon report which it has to answer, takes on—it will not even leave it for a little bit longer—a decent school, a good school. We have to ensure that that school may continue to provide education for the students of my electorate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities, I present the committee's report entitled Report on derivatives, together with the evidence received by the committee.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—In November 1994 members of the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities visited the Sydney Futures Exchange to observe its operations and meet informally with the executives of the exchange. The committee subsequently decided to conduct a public hearing at the Sydney Futures Exchange to discuss its operations.

PARA.TAB: Shortly before that scheduled hearing, Barings Bank crashed as a result of massive losses by its Singapore branch in derivatives trading. This incident gave additional and sharper focus to the committee's hearing. The committee subsequently decided that it should hold public hearings on the regulation of derivatives with the Australian Stock Exchange, the Australian Securities Commission and the Corporations and Securities Advisory Committee to discuss both the Barings crash and general issues relating to the regulation of derivatives in Australia.

Derivatives serve an important function in allowing businesses to manage their exposure risk by hedging. This means that businesses can buffer themselves against adverse movements in the markets and can plan future activity with greater certainty. However, speculative trading in derivatives carries with it the potential for both very large profits and losses.

In evidence to the committee at public hearings the Sydney Futures Exchange and the Australian Stock Exchange outlined in some detail the procedures and safeguards in place to detect excessive and potentially dangerous trading patterns in the markets they operate. They also outlined the powers they have to take action when they detect such problems. The committee asked each of the witnesses who appeared before it whether they could guarantee that a collapse like Barings could not occur in Australia. The ASX and the SFE told the committee that they could not guarantee that a major crash like the Barings crash could not occur in Australia. However, they said that the procedures in place minimise the possibility of that happening. They also assured the committee that should a similar event occur here the procedures in place would minimise its impact.

The committee also asked the witnesses about the adequacy of the Corporations Law and the review currently being conducted by the Companies and Securities Advisory Committee. In May 1994 the Australian Securities Commission published its report Over-the-counter derivatives markets. That report examined the nature and size of derivatives markets, and the participants and risks involved. The report recommended that there should be a review of the complex regulatory and law reform issues arising from increased activity in over-the-counter derivatives transactions. It also proposed changes to the regulatory framework for derivatives markets.

Following the release of the ASC report on over-the-counter derivatives the Companies and Securities Advisory Committee commenced its review of derivatives regulation. The Corporations and Securities Advisory Committee has subsequently published an international comparison of derivatives regulations and a discussion paper on the regulation of the OTC derivatives market. The discussion paper proposes a range of regulatory initiatives designed to enhance existing controls over the Australian OTC market.

The advisory committee is currently seeking submissions on its proposals and the issues raised in the discussion paper. The advisory committee intends to publish a further discussion paper on the regulation of exchange traded derivatives and the regulation of a possible secondary or tradeable OTC market. The committee will continue to monitor this review of the Corporations Law.

There have been some recent developments since the committee conducted its hearings. Both the Bank of England and Singapore reports on their investigations into Barings have become available. Although the committee has not had the opportunity to examine these reports in full, they bear out the main points made to the committee during its hearings. The Bank of England report, for example, says:

SPEECH.PARA: Barings' collapse was due to the unauthorised and ultimately catastrophic activities of, it appears, one individual that went undetected as a consequence of a failure of management and other internal controls of the most basic kind. Management failed at various levels and in a variety of ways . . . to institute a proper system of internal controls, to enforce accountability for all profits, risks and operations, and adequately to follow up on a number of warning signals over a prolonged period.

In March 1995 the Futures Industry Association held its annual international futures industry conference in Florida. During that meeting the FIA formed a global task force on financial integrity to examine the safeguards and control mechanisms that exist in the industry. That task force has since made 60 recommendations directed at regulators, exchanges, brokers and customers.

PARA.TAB: In May 1995 representatives of regulatory bodies from 16 countries, including the Australian Securities Commission, met at Windsor in the United Kingdom. The result was the Windsor declaration, which outlines measures aimed at strengthening the supervision of international futures markets.

Following the committee's hearings, the Sydney Futures Exchange reviewed its procedures in light of the Barings collapse. It has advised the committee that: the SFE has decided to require members of the exchange to report the details of the holders of every position daily; the SFE clearing house has decided to increase the minimum net tangible asset requirement for members from $2 million to $5 million; and the SFE will shortly be making a submission to the Companies and Securities Advisory Committee concerning changes which the exchange believes should be made to the Corporations Law in order to bring it into line with best international practice.

The SFE was, of course, involved in the Florida meeting of the Futures Industry Association. The SFE was also involved in the development of recommendations by the Futures Industry Association's global task force on financial integrity. The SFE has advised the committee that it meets all of the recommendations of that task force.

The corporations and securities committee is not the only committee to have examined derivatives. The House of Representatives Standing Committee on Banking, Finance and Public Administration has conducted public hearings on derivatives with the Reserve Bank and the Insurance and Superannuation Commission. It recently tabled its report on those hearings in this chamber.

Based on the evidence given during its hearings, the committee can see no reason for new legislative restraints of the use of derivatives at this stage, but will continue to monitor developments. Similarly, the committee saw no reason for restricting the development of new products provided that an appropriate regulatory regime is in place, active consideration is given to the need for suitable limitations on the level of exposure of individual users, and the nature of the product and the potential risks involved are adequately publicised.

The evidence given to the committee did not indicate that urgent changes to the Corporations Law were needed. However, it is clear to the committee that the comprehensive review of the Corporations Law being conducted by CASAC is appropriate and timely. In particular, the division of the regulation of markets into two separate chapters of the Corporations Law appears to be inappropriate.

The committee's hearings were stimulated by four main areas of concern: firstly, to ensure that the Corporations Law has kept up to date with developments and provides a suitable regulatory environment for derivatives trading; secondly, that regulators and market operators are aware of the full range of hazards involved in derivatives trading and are able to ensure, as far as possible, the overall integrity of the markets; thirdly, that market participants are aware of the hazards involved in trading these products; and, finally, that the superannuation savings of Australians are not placed at risk by derivatives trading.

It appears to the committee that the SFE, the ASX and the ASC are all actively reviewing the way in which the markets operate in Australia in the light of overseas experience and are seeking to effect best practice in Australia. The committee believes that the parliament should be kept informed on derivatives and has therefore recommended that the ASC include in its annual reports a synopsis of the types and volumes of derivatives being traded in Australia and recent regulatory developments.

The committee is of the view that the primary responsibility for ensuring that individual businesses do not fail as a result of losses on the derivatives markets rests with the management and directors of those firms. Page 3 of the committee's report lists examples of losses sustained by both Australian and overseas businesses. They should serve as a salutary warning for Australian businesses of the consequences of becoming involved in derivatives trading without having both an adequate understanding of the products and the necessary management and internal controls.

Although some efforts are being made to educate users of derivatives, the committee remains concerned that users of these products, including executives and directors of Australian companies, managed funds, trusts and individual investors, may not be sufficiently aware of the potential hazards of using derivatives. Further efforts to educate the users of these products are essential. The committee considers that more publicity needs to be given by the ASX, the SFE and the ASC to the risks involved in using derivatives and the need for corporations using these products to have adequate controls in place.

The committee's final concern is that the superannuation savings of Australian workers may be placed at risk through derivative trading by fund managers. The report of the House of Representatives banking committee, following its hearings with the ISC, has served to demonstrate that this issue has not yet been adequately addressed by the industry. The committee believes that the use of derivatives in the superannuation industry is an issue which must be closely monitored. In the committee's view, the most appropriate parliamentary body to consider this area in a comprehensive, ongoing way is the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Since the Barings Bank collapse and the considerable publicity given to the dealings of Mr Nick Leeson, and certainly since his apprehension in Germany and imminent transfer to Singapore as a result of charges being laid against him, derivatives and the mumbo jumbo associated with them have had a good deal of airing but sadly there has been very little understanding in the wider public of what is a widely accepted form of trading. People need to remember that, for all that so much money was lost in that instance, somebody made a profit on the deal; the money did not just disappear.

PARA.TAB: The nature of futures and commodity options trading, as the introduction to the report states, is one of the more impenetrable of humanity's concepts. It involves selling what one does not own and, as a rule, buying what one does not want. But at the same time it is a very important form by which you can hedge a commodity which you do own and may wish to sell at some uncertain future time in a market over which you have no control.

I believe this report, introductory though it may be—in that it is very difficult to cover the full ramifications of the subject—does serve to indicate to the public at large that the parliament is aware of the nuances of the derivatives trade and at the same time does not impose what I would see as new disciplines or restraints in restricting their future development and use. In Australia there have been many traders, some of whom have lost large sums of money on foreign exchange. The development of the derivatives instrument, particularly through the Sydney Futures Exchange, has enormous potential in future.

The lessons of the Barings Bank collapse we have attempted to identify to some degree. As the honourable member for Perth (Mr Stephen Smith), the chairman of the committee, has identified, there have already been quite a number of conferences nationally and internationally trying to identify ways by which there can be better communication and a better understanding of the futures, so that hopefully the Barings type collapse will not be repeated. It is inevitable that in commodities of this sort, where there is so little control, there are going to be losses. Indeed, I noted only last week that Westpac has been involved in some losses in a market that is not dissimilar, again through using an overseas agency.

From the parliament's point of view, there are three things that I think are important. The first is that we believe internationally, to the maximum, there should be communication between exchanges of a person, individual or corporation at any stage once they have passed what might be the reasonable limitations or operation of a particular trading unit. If that is done and communicated between international operators, there would not be the breaches that occurred in the Barings affair where demonstrably neither the Singapore nor Osaka exchanges traded information between each other, let alone with other trading organisations.

Secondly, there needs to be adequate supervision, and in Australia that needs to be done by the trading authorities. Following our discussions, I am satisfied that both the Sydney Stock Exchange and the Sydney Futures Exchange conduct that proper prudential supervision of those who operate in their markets. But there also needs to be a watch kept by the Australian Securities Commission. By doing that, we believe there is a capacity for the public to feel confident in the way in which futures trading is being processed.

We have recommended in the report that the ASC include in its annual reports to parliament a synopsis of the types and volumes of derivatives being traded in Australia and recent regulatory developments.
