That is with the specific intention of instructing the public at large on the nature of derivatives trading and, where new derivatives are developed—there is no doubt that they will be—there will be an understanding of what has happened in the derivatives market over the last 12 months. I believe that, by tabling the ASC's report with a reference to derivatives, there is a much better chance of people understanding a little of where the derivatives arise.

Thirdly, there should be no feeling by those engaged in the market that the legislature should just introduce a legislative restraint against the development of new instruments, because it is a particularly important way by which the market itself can be served. As markets change and as the volatility of exports and imports continues, in spite of—and perhaps even because of—the freeing of world trade, APEC, the consequences of the GATT resolutions and the establishment of the World Trade Organisation, it is important that there be new products so that people can enter into some greater certainty in their operations. That is ultimately, from the hedging point of view, one of the major functions of derivatives. There are speculators, but if there were no speculators there could not be essentially a hedging operation.

So education is necessary, the development of new products is necessary, proper regulatory supervision is necessary and communication between market operators is essential—market operators in the sense of the Sydney Futures Exchange, the Australian Stock Exchange and the like. This report deals with each of those. I believe that the report makes a worthwhile contribution towards a better understanding of where the Australian market is with respect to derivatives at this time and I trust that the recommendations can be adopted by the government.

Recommendation 4.11 deals with superannuation savings and derivatives trading. The committee has recommended that the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation might be an appropriate instrument to monitor this trading. I hope that does not mean that the ASC does not feel that it too can report should it believe it is necessary to comment. There are a number of instrumentalities operating in that field and there is some prudential supervision from the Australian Treasury. I believe that the ASC needs to take note, as well as the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation, of any area where they believe superannuation savings may be at risk. I commend the report to the parliament.

DEBATE.TITLE: SOCIAL SECURITY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (CARER PENSION AND OTHER MEASURES) BILL 1995Cognate bill:SOCIAL SECURITY AND VETERANS' AFFAIRS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1995

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 26 October, on motion by Mrs Crosio:
That the bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a joy to see the member for Ballarat (Mr Ronaldson) in the chamber. He was at the table when I started this speech more than three weeks ago, so it is as if we had not moved. On that occasion I dealt with one part of the bill, and that was to do with the mature age allowance. I was privileged to have a hand in those amendments.

PARA.TAB: The next issue I would like to address is carers. It is important to note that this government has done a great deal for carers. It has taken some time in historic terms to recognise the fact that so many people—husbands, wives or, a lot of the time, elder daughters—have stayed at home to look after the ill, the frail, the aged and the disabled; but now those carers are getting the kind of recognition they deserve. The carer pension is the main means by which we recognise those people, as well as training courses, respite and other measures.

This social security legislation makes three basic amendments to the provisions for carers. The first is to extend the carer payment for 14 weeks after the person being cared for enters an institution and the carer no longer has that person in their charge. This is designed to give carers time to adjust to no longer being in that caring role and, where required, to re-enter the labour market or to make appropriate arrangements to go onto other payments.

Former carers who register with the CES during that 14-week period will be able to exercise the jobs education and training program, JET, during the following 12 months. The JET program, as we all know, is a very successful program and is designed simply for sole parents. It has been very successful in getting people back into the work force and into training.

The second measure is to extend carer payments to those who are caring for people not currently on a Social Security or Veterans' Affairs pension. Until now, that has been a requirement. This is very important because there are a number of people—particularly disabled people—who, because of the assets test and other requirements, are not on the pension but are not by any means rich. So it has allowed their carers to access the carer pension. The third one lifts the requirement that a carer live on the same premises or in adjoining premises. This will allow more people to have access to a carer. Those carers, of course, still have to meet the normal requirements.

The next item in the report that I would like to allude to is extended deeming. I think previous speakers have talked about this and I have no doubt that others will as well, because it is something of a central core of this bill. It deals with the way managed investments and shares are assessed for pension purposes. The previous system of assessing the growth in those investments as income was very complicated. It involved a lot of different formulas and complications which a lot of older people found very difficult to understand and to come to terms with. They simply got a piece of paper from Social Security saying that their pension had dropped to a certain level because there had been a certain amount of growth in their investments, and so on. I think that just about every member of this House would have had complaints from people about it. I feel it was so often unfair. The new system of extended deeming will bring simplicity. We all know that it has been introduced as a result of wide consultations throughout the industry and amongst age care groups, peak bodies and so on.

John Barber was commissioned to do a report and make certain recommendations. On that basis the current legislation has arisen. What this system does initially is create a standard deeming rate of five per cent which will apply to the first $30,000 of financial investments for single people and to the first $50,000 for couples. Above these amounts, the standard deeming rate of seven per cent will apply.

It means that those who have earnings below that amount are able to keep it; it will not be taxed as far as Social Security is concerned. Pensioners will get a full pension under the income test where their only income is from financial investments worth less than $43,000 for single people and $74,000 for a pensioner couple. This is because a single pensioner can earn up to $2,444 a year and a pensioner couple can earn up to $4,264 without it affecting their pension. That means a great deal of freeing up. This has been well received by all the groups concerned. It means that some people will want to change their portfolio of investments. The financial information service at the Department of Social Security is ready to give them advice. Those FIS officers at DSS offices do a very good job in that regard.

The next issue I would like to talk about is the revised pensioner loans scheme and the advance payments scheme. Both these schemes allow people on pensions and other benefits to get a loan or advance payment for a special reason. We all know that when people are living on a tight budget and something goes wrong—the fridge breaks down, the roof leaks, the car needs major repairs and so on—that tight fortnightly benefit simply does not allow that job to be done when it needs to be done.

Under the pension scheme, a loan can be taken out against the pension and be repaid or recovered from the estate when the person is deceased. The revisions to that mean that the fortnightly rate of the loan will be increased to the maximum pension rate or a rate specified by the pensioner, whichever is lower. Participants will have to be entitled to some payment under either the income or the assets test and the assets over which the Commonwealth will place a caveat will be limited to real estate. There are other conditions as well which I will not go into in detail, because of limited time. But these loans do certainly give relief to people who do not have access to ready cash.

As far as the lump sum advances are concerned, these often apply to people who are on jobsearch allowance and need some cash in order to prepare themselves for a job. There are people who need tools, clothing or some other things to prepare themselves for work, as well as people who need money for those emergency payments that I mentioned. The changes here are that the maximum advance available would be the lesser of $500 or six per cent of one year's pension payments. The advances are repaid by deductions from ongoing fortnightly pensions over 13 fortnights. Those measures are an advance to help people on very limited social security benefits.

The earnings credits scheme is very important to people on jobsearch or newstart allowances. There are a lot of people who are looking for work but who are, at the same time, doing occasional part-time or casual work and gaining some work experience. All these people are allowed a certain amount of free cover each fortnight. They are allowed to do a certain amount of work and, after that, they progressively lose their benefits. Some fortnights some of those people may not use that free area; at other times they may exceed it. So the system of earnings credits allows them to accrue those amounts. If you go without using it for three weeks, you have three or four weeks up the next time around.

There are three changes to this scheme. The first is that the credit will accrue at a rate equal to the amount of the unused free area in any fortnight. Secondly, the maximum amount of the credit that can be used in any fortnight is limited to $100, regardless of the earnings amount; and the earnings credit balance will not be able to be used on return to full-time employment. In other words, it is only for the time that the person is on that benefit.

Flexibility in reporting for unemployed people is also very important. I am sure every member has had people complain about having to be at the CES on a certain day to hand in their form. I know the various Social Security officers can allow a certain discretion but this is now being freed up more so there can be variable reporting frequencies for people in particular situations. These include people who are currently being case managed. This system was brought in with Working Nation for the long-term unemployed. They have a case manager who is working directly with them, helping them to find training, work or work experience. Those people can be allowed more flexibility in their reporting time.

Customers undertaking certain kinds of activity can also be allowed more flexibility. These people include those in formal training, those doing short courses, those doing voluntary work and those who are in some way incapacitated. I think voluntary work is extremely important. It was one of the things I raised with the committee developing the green paper on employment, which eventually resulted in the white paper Working Nation. I have in my electorate quite a number of older people who find it difficult to find work—in fact, they know they are not going to find work, particularly locally—so they put themselves into voluntary work. There is a lot of voluntary work that can be done in the community with the aged, with children and so on. So those people will not have to report quite as frequently. I think that is important.

The third group to be allowed more flexibility is customers aged 50 years or over transferring from a pension who have been on a pension for at least 12 months. The carers I mentioned earlier would come within that category. If they cease to be carers and go back into the labour market, they can also have that flexibility in reporting. I think that is another important move.

The last issue I will talk about is that of labour market programs. Currently, trainee payments under labour market programs are not counted as income if the person is receiving social security payments. The exemptions here have been expanded to include a payment made to a trainee in part-time training or part-time work experience under a labour market program. The payment is made to cover expenses associated with participation in the training or work experience.

I think we need to do those things in order to encourage people to go into labour market programs which are going to lead them into work. We often hear people saying, `If I go into a labour market program and I have to travel and incur other expenses then it is not going to be worth my while.' I think we need to support those people and I think the labour market programs this government has instituted have done a great deal, particularly for young people—getting them into the work force, gaining confidence and self-esteem, and getting themselves in a position where they can take on a full-time traineeship or a permanent job. I commend the bills to the House. There are plenty of other things in them which have not been covered, but for me I think those are the main points.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nehl Mr G.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The content of these two social security bills is very important to a great many Australians. I think we should make the point right at the outset that a criticism we in the opposition have relates to the timing of the bills themselves. From the first reading to the commencement of the second reading debate there were only eight days. That did not leave very much time for the sort of consultation that should be undertaken, particularly with regard to the government's extended deeming proposals.

PARA.TAB: I totally support the amendment foreshadowed by the member for Berowra (Mr Ruddock)—in particular, the `failure to draft the bill to include detail as to the timing and regularity of valuation of financial investments under the extended deeming rules introduced in schedule 1 of the bill'. I will certainly come back to that in a little while.

It is absolutely important for the House to note and the people of Australia to be aware that some 207,000 pensioners will suffer a decrease in their pension if they do not rearrange their assets to meet or exceed the deeming rates. Two hundred and seven thousand Australian pensioners will suffer a decrease in their pensions unless they undertake, in some cases, very complicated efforts to rearrange their assets and their investments. It is also important that the House be aware that this legislation really fails to address the potentially adverse impact of the extended deeming rules on the holders of investments in friendly societies.

I believe the complexity of this social security law is such that what is intended to be simple and easy for ordinary people to understand is totally impossible for ordinary people to understand. The Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill contains 229 pages. The other bill contains 167 pages. These bills are very complex. In fact, they add to existing law which is already very complex.

I can foresee that very big difficulties will be happening daily for a great many Australians. Independent people have made comments about that. The Ombudsman has drawn attention to it, as has the Auditor-General. Of course, the welfare rights movement has voiced its concern over a long period of time about the complexity of the social security system. These bills have more than 40 amendments, some relating to extended deeming. To put them in so late in the session I think is totally inappropriate.

The situation needs to be understood very clearly. We in the coalition have pledged to repeal the unfair unrealised capital gains provisions and have criticised the government for the unfair nature of the provisions under which people's pensions go up and down on a fairly ad hoc basis according to changes in the share market. This has created an enormous amount of uncertainty and hardship for a great many people.

The reality is that we are having these changes because the government did not get the money they expected. Therefore, they are going to have to make a change. The new system of calculating the income involves income and financial investments at a deemed rate of five per cent up to $30,000 for single people and up to $50,000 for couples, and seven per cent thereafter. The mere fact of that will ensure that the government saves money out of the budget. In fact, it expects to save something like $70 million in both the social security and veterans' affairs areas.

How does a government save money in social security and veterans' affairs? It can save money only by removing people from entitlements. So the government is planning to harvest $70 million from the elderly of this nation. It is an absolute disgrace. Pensioners will lose their eligibility for fringe benefits or their eligibility for pensions or part pensions as a result of this measure. That is why the government will be saving something like $70 million.

The government has said all along that the new deeming rules are attractive because they will create certainty, but people's deeming rates will move up and down depending on the valuation of their assets. People will undoubtedly have great difficulty understanding why the deeming rates, which are fixed, are going to result in a change in the actual amount. The act, when it is amended, will not tell us how often that valuation is to take place. We on the coalition side expect that the valuation will occur at times of the government's choosing—to the best advantage of the government and not of the pensioners and allowance receivers of Australia.

At present, people are required to notify the department each time the value of their assets changes, and their pensions are adjusted accordingly. There are penalties involved if people fail to advise the department of a change that could lead to a debt. This matter of changes in valuation will be a particularly important one. There is still great uncertainty. There are no administrative arrangements in place. Certainly we in the coalition have not been advised of any. There is no proposal for any rules. It is all extraordinarily vague and uncertain indeed.

I will make brief reference to the issue of friendly society bonds. There have been a number of representations from friendly societies and from the umbrella organisation, the Australian Friendly Societies Association. They believe that provision should be made to treat prepaid investments, such as friendly society bonds, differently from products on which tax is not prepaid but on which the investor pays tax at their own marginal tax rate. They argued, quite reasonably and rationally I think, that returns from prepaid tax products would necessarily be lower as the tax has been paid prior to the distribution to the investment.

These organisations believe that their members will be adversely affected because these new extended deeming arrangements will be prejudicial to them. The association claims that there are something like 400,000 pensioners with total investments of $2.8 billion. So it is a very significant issue and one which should be addressed.

I will turn briefly to the earnings credit scheme. Mr Deputy Speaker, you will be fully aware that this is the scheme for people who only work a very short time but who might earn a significant amount in that period. The common example used is that of Father Christmases and Santa Clauses who get employment in the December period. They earn a fair bit at that time. The earnings credit scheme allows them to spread their income over a longer period.

These new amendments are designed to remove a number of people from eligibility for the full earnings credit to which they are now entitled. Again, the government is going to make savings of $93 million. But where will those savings come from? They will come out of the pockets of pensioners who are able to earn a bit in a prime period and who, under the old rules, could then average that out so that they would not lose their entitlements. But for the government to save $93 million means that the government will rip $93 million out of pensioners. I can never agree with that.

People need to understand that earnings credit scheme. I repeat that it provides an opportunity for people who have seasonal occupations with a very high level of income at a particular time to apply that credit over time so that their earnings—the normal allowance is $60 per fortnight—do not reach a level where their benefit is affected. That is a reasonable thing to do. That is what a caring and compassionate government would do. To be fair, this is what the present government has done in the past. All of a sudden, to try to balance the budget, it will rip $93 million off the elderly of Australia. I can never endorse that.

I want to touch briefly on the guardian allowance. The government announced in the budget that the guardian allowance would increase by $4 per fortnight as from September 1996. The May 1995 budget announced that guardians would receive an extra $4 per fortnight, or $2 per week—how generous!—but that the government will delay it for 16 months and not introduce it until September 1996. Examine the budget closely and all the provisions made by this government. It will spend $100 million on this or $40 million on that, but you always have to look at the date of commencement. Time and again, you will find that it is way down the track and that the amount is spread over three, four, five, six or eight years. Again, it is part of the pea and thimble trick that they are playing on the Australian people.

As far as the guardian allowance is concerned, ACOSS has been very active in saying that since 1973 the real value of the guardian allowance has dropped by 48 per cent. There has not been a real increase in the allowance since 1986. We are now getting an extra $2 per week from September 1996.

I am also very concerned about the changes in rent assistance. On the one hand, you have the announcement—everybody would say that it is great—that rent assistance is to be increased by $5 per fortnight for families with children. Bravo! Great! Families with children get an extra $5 per fortnight in rent assistance. On the other hand—this is not loudly trumpeted by the government—the rent assistance threshold will be increased by $5 per fortnight for everybody. That means that the threshold which their income has to meet will be raised before they will be eligible for rent assistance.

The overall impact of those changes is that the government gets a net saving of $16.9 million over 3 1/4 years. You have $5 million a year being saved out of changes to rent assistance. Again, it is one of those confidence tricks. The government is going to increase it, but it will also make savings out of it. I repeat that the only way that any government can make savings in social security and social welfare is to cut it off and to take it out of the pockets of the people concerned.

The impact of this on older pensioners is that about 310,000 recipients will lose $3.75 a week as a result of the increase in the threshold. The pensioners of Australia will lose $3.75 per week. There are 310,000 of them. That is the way that this current government is treating the pensioners and the elderly of Australia. It is an absolute disgrace.

I refer in particular to the carers pension. I have some constituents—I will not name them; I want to protect their privacy—who had great trouble with the funerals of the lady's parents-in-law, one of whom died on 19 November 1995 and the other on 14 January. They are hoping that they might get some form of ex gratia payment to help pay for the funeral costs. This woman writes about Tom:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . I was caring for him for almost twelve months, unfortunately, I was not officially on a Carers Pension.
When Margaret—
that is Tom's wife; these are her parents-in-law—

first took sick (Feb `95) and I was caring for her, her husband Tom and her 81 year old invalid mother, I went to Social Security to see if I was eligible for a carer's pension and I was given a folder full of information.
I am sure that she was. There would have been lots of paper. She continues:

It stated that to be eligible one had to be living with the person or on a property adjacent to. I clearly did not come into this category as I lived approximately 15 mins. drive away on dirt road, so I did not officially apply.

PARA.TAB: So we carried on regardless as this was our immediate family and they needed constant help.

SPEECH.PARA: The only income of this lady and her husband was social security. She continues:

PARA.TAB: From the onset of Margaret's illness I took care of Tom . . . and Edna . . . and Margaret herself.
Not only did I do the basic cleaning but nursing duties as well. Also driving them to hospital—looking after them in hospital as well as when they were at home.

Due to Tom's mental and physical disabilities (he'd suffered a stroke & had emphysema) absolutely everything had to be done for him . . . Because of his chronic emphysema he was on ventolin—he constantly ran out before our "shop" days . . .

SPEECH.PARA: These people live 45 minutes away from the nearest town on a dirt road. They cannot pop into town at the drop of a hat because they do not have the income. Her letter continues:

eventuating in me having to go to town 45 mins . . . for medication as he could not breathe freely without it, and due to his mental disability he did not manage it correctly. Twelve months of this obviously caused great financial stress . . .
I am sure it did—

which we have still not recovered from. On top of all this I have three children who have gone without many things so that we could afford all the extra running around we did every day on Social Security benefits.
That is their only income. She continues:

I could probably write out a daily itinerary of what was done by myself and my husband (their son) but I fear you may think I'm making myself out as a martyr, that I am not. The simple fact is—Tom . . . probably should have been in a nursing home . . .
I am sure that he should have been—

but because of what I did to care for him and Margaret and Gran (Edna . . . ), it was not done, also due to his mental illness he would not have gone. The only nursing duties performed by me for Tom were acquiring scripts and overseeing he took his medication and taking him to hospital approx every six weeks. As for Margaret, I had to pack a post-op wound for several weeks and from June 94 had to dress a large venous ulcer on Gran's leg. I have been on a Carer's Pension for looking after Gran (Edna . . . ) since Jan `95.

As well as that, in March 1994, Margaret was diagnosed with a very acute onset of lymphoma. She was treated locally for diagnostic tests until admitted to King George V Hospital. The letter continues:

PARA.TAB: During this time I took care of Tom and Edna while my husband looked after his mother in hospital in Sydney for 4 weeks. Then I went to Sydney to assist with post-op recovery until fit to return home. A chemotherapy program started. Weekly doctors visits—had emergency cholecystectomy—chemo continued then discovered lymphoma in cerebro-spinal fluid—sent to R.N.S. for radiotherapy program—I myself had cholecystectomy—1 week later I went down to support and care for her during radiotherapy program. Meanwhile my husband looked after the kids and his father and Gran. Also during this time Tom was admitted roughly every six weeks for about a week's stay each time—Sept—Oct `94 both Tom and Margaret's condition deteriorated so Edna came to live with us.

SPEECH.PARA: I guess it was after that time that she at least became entitled for the carers pension for looking after the grandmother. She continues:

Two weeks later Margaret died of complications—a lung clot . . . Tom was continued to be cared for by me and their son. All house duties were taken care of by me as well as medical help. Seven weeks later Tom died and Edna continues to live with us and we are still struggling to pay the funeral costs. Total Bill was just under $6,000 for the two of them. We still owe $2,250 and it is extremely difficult to keep making payments and tend to the needs of the three children—17 1/2 yrs, 12 yrs and 8 1/2 yrs.

This lady has contacted me, seen me, written to me and asked whether some form of ex gratia payment could be made. Of course the act will be amended so next year you can get the carers pension without having to live with or alongside the person. This family is in a state of disaster because that provision only starts next year. I do hope that when I write to the Minister for Social Security (Mr Baldwin) he will be able to take some form of favourable discretion to assist a family who is in desperate need.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLeay The Hon L.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been listening to the cognate debate on these social security bills with great interest. Some of the members opposite appear to have newly developed an interest in social welfare matters. I do not mean the member for Cowper (Mr Nehl), who has had an interest in these issues for quite some time, but a number of the opposition members who have spoken on this bill today, and earlier in the debate on this legislation, have been a bit far from this debate in years gone by.

PARA.TAB: Unfortunately, the shadow minister for social security, the member for Berowra (Mr Ruddock), has played his usual trick of proposing a nonsensical amendment while both he and the member for Fisher (Mr Slipper) continue to delay any progress in this area by proposing that the bill be referred to the Senate Community Affairs Legislation Committee for report. We have just heard a rather eloquent plea from the member for Cowper for this legislation to be enacted post haste, so I guess he should be talking to his own party and suggesting no good merit is to be achieved at all, except to delay the issue, by referring the matter to a Senate committee for a lengthy report which will probably improve the legislation not one jot.

The government in this instance is putting in place a piece of legislation that will help people like the person referred to by the member for Cowper. The legislation will enact some very important reforms to areas of the social security system. The majority of those measures were outlined in the May budget, so I am surprised that the member for Berowra and the member for Fisher in their earlier contributions were so uptight about having so little time to consider them. By the time we considered and passed the legislation at the snail's pace the member for Berowra wants us to, the people the member for Cowper referred to would not need some quick resolution by the Minister for Social Security because they probably would have passed on. For a lot of these reforms there is no time to lose. I would like to specifically speak about the provisions that relate to carers, as did the member for Cowper.

Some people who are caring for others who are ill and who at this time cannot get a carers pension will be dramatically helped by this legislation. The bill means that a person who cares for another person can qualify for a carers pension even if the person being cared for does not get social security or a veterans pension. The carers who are in this situation will be able to get a carers pension as long as the person they are caring for has an income of less than $61,020 and assets of less than $559,250. I think that is a very generous interpretation and will ensure that a lot of people who are caring for relations or friends will be able to get this pension. It will not matter if the carer does not live in the same house or next door. They will be able to get a carers pension whereas previously they were disqualified for living elsewhere.

It is now well known that carers are under enormous strain both emotionally and physically for the constant care and attention they give to the people they are helping. Respite care is now accepted as necessary for both carers and the people they are caring for. It is only sensible that carers have some break from the routine of caring, some life for themselves. If they can do this by not actually having to live in the same house as the person they are caring for, they should not be penalised by not being able to get the pension.

Importantly, this piece of legislation brings into the social security safety net those decent people in the community who are looking after someone who is not a relation, someone for whom they are just doing a very decent thing. It takes into account very much the role of neighbours and friends. It ensures that we see an expansion both of those people eligible to provide this care and of the payment to those who until now have been doing it.

For many years I have taken a great interest in aged care, since the beginning of the home and community care program. That program was subsequent to a report that I oversaw as the chairman of the House of Representatives expenditure committee, which was called In a home or at home. In those nine years or so, we have seen great advances in the quality of non-institutional care being provided for our elderly and others that require care. Care for the carers is yet another aspect of those advances.

Another forward thinking provision presented here is that carers will continue to receive the carers pension for another 14 weeks after the person they are caring for goes into a nursing home. As I briefly mentioned, with their own needs sometimes sacrificed for many years so they can care for someone else, carers often face problems of their own arising out of the care they are giving.

I will give a hypothetical example of a woman who has been caring for her parents, first her father and then her mother, for over a period of maybe 20 years. Caring for her parents has been the primary focus of her life for those years. She gets a carers pension but, unhappily, the day comes when her father has probably passed on and her mother must move into a nursing home for specialised care. For such a woman, probably aged in her late 50s herself, to face not only the emotional trauma of moving her mother into a nursing home but also the immediate withdrawal of her supporting income is a heartless action. The government recognises this situation and with this legislation will ensure that such carers will have a reasonable time to adjust to their changed circumstances before they have to start living their own lives again.

Together, these bills will achieve a great deal of positive reform to the social security safety net—increases in rent assistance and the guardian allowance, simplification of applications for family payment and child-care assistance, extension of data matching to continue to reduce the incidence of fraud and suspension rather than cancellation of pensions when pensioners leave Australia for fewer than 12 months. These are all sensible measures which will improve the quality and efficiency of welfare payments.

I might just mention the positive benefit that I see in the suspension of pensions rather than the cancellation of them when people leave the country for less than 12 months. I represent an electorate where nearly half the people who live there were born outside Australia. They often return to their country of origin for some time and find themselves in an invidious position when they return to Australia because they have to go and reapply for the pension. These people have worked in Australia for 20 or 30 years. This provision would make the situation more sensible for these people and less bureaucratic for the government. No doubt it would also result in cost savings.

In the debate on these bills earlier, the member for Fisher tried to tell us that we would be thrashed at the next election because the government have widened the gap between the rich and the poor. If he is saying that the opposition intend to do more than the government have done over the last 13 years, I suppose the government would be interested in hearing how the opposition would do this. If it is the case that the member for Fisher is speaking for the opposition, they should show the Australian people how they intend to outperform the government in the social welfare area. The reality is that all the opposition would do if they had a chance would be to slash funding in the welfare area.

About 10 years ago I remember participating in a debate on a bill in this House which provided an increase in social security and welfare payments, including the introduction of the carers pension. In that speech, I referred to a speech by the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) which he made to the National Press Club. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The main cause of the blow-out in government expenditure in recent years has taken place in the welfare area . . .

The member for Bennelong does not like it when we refer him back to some of the things he said in the past. But looking at people's track records in terms of what they have said and done in the past is the best way of knowing what they are going to do in the future, particularly when they are not willing to tell you on the record what they are going to do. That is what the present Leader of the Opposition said 10 years ago when we first introduced this pension. At that stage, he thought that the main cause of the blow-out in government expenditure was in the welfare area. He made those comments a few years after being Treasurer. That blow-out is something that he accused us of being responsible for. He said that the implication was that the government needed to do something to cut the welfare budget.

PARA.TAB: Are the opposition now saying that we are not doing enough in the welfare area and that they would do much more if they had a chance? I do not think that is so. So that they will have some idea of what the benchmark is, they should be reminded of some of the government's achievements. At present, the government spend almost $3 billion a year on aged care, which is 62 per cent more than the coalition government spent when the member for Bennelong was Treasurer. The government continue to maintain the age pension at 25 per cent of weekly earnings, and have done since 1990.

Between 1975 and 1983, under the member for Bennelong's government, the real value of unemployment benefits decreased by 18 per cent and age pensions decreased by two per cent. Spending on community care services has tripled under this government. All up, the government currently spend nearly $30 billion a year on the social wage. They spend $30 billion a year on that social security and social wage safety net, which includes health, housing, child care and education. That is an average of around $200 per week for a family with two children. That is the benchmark that the opposition would have to achieve if they seriously thought they could improve on the current situation that the government have implemented. I do not think that the opposition could match that benchmark. I am astounded that people on the other side could presume to criticise the government for what we have done in the welfare area.

If we are going to have a real debate on this issue, what we need is for the opposition to tell us what they intend to do. We do not want to hear the ridiculous proposal that they want to send the bills off to a Senate committee or that the government are moving too quickly. What we need to get from the opposition is some idea of where they stand. What would they do with the $30 billion a year that the government spend on the social wage? Does the member for Bennelong still believe what he said when we first introduced that carers pension at the National Press Club; that is, the budget blow-out problem was in the welfare area?

The opposition have to understand the point raised by the member for Cowper: there are a lot of people out there who need the support of the government to go about their daily lives. It is not so much that they need the support of the government, because all the government are doing is redistributing income from their fellow Australians. I believe this pension is a very good example of the type of social security system that the government want to see in Australia. It is a system that provides equity and assistance to help people care for others.

The opposition should be positive about this issue. They should help the government to get on with this provision. They should not hold up the legislation by threatening to move amendments or to send the bills off to a Senate committee. It will only ensure that it takes longer for this legislation to become law and that the benefits that could be paid to those decent people to whom the member for Cowper referred will be delayed even further. I commend the bills to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Mr R.D.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —A network of social support and social reform has become an obligation undertaken by all governments. It is part of our fabric of society and it has become an expectation of Australians that they be recognised and supported in times when earning a wage is not possible due to lack of employment, which has become quite common over the last 10 years or so under the Labor Party, illness, age, family commitments, and other `barriers'. Legislation and reforms in this area are therefore critical. I welcome the opportunity to discuss and debate the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Carer Pension and Other Measures) Bill and the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill this afternoon.

PARA.TAB: However, I would be remiss in representing my constituents of Cowan if I did not raise some concerns as to the manner of this legislation coming before the parliament. My fellow members of the House and I were initially given only eight days between the introduction of these bills and the second reading debate scheduled for the last week of sitting in October. In this time we were expected to digest, ponder and deliberate on what would best be described as complex, at worst, hugely difficult and, at times, convoluted pieces of legislation.

These bills introduce more than 40 amendments to the act, and all this is couched within a mere 406 pages of important explanatory text. Fortunately, the second reading debate was deferred until today. I say `fortunately' for one reason, and it is not that it has provided my colleagues with more time to respond or prepare for the debate. Rather, it has allowed adequate time to bring to light an issue of great importance that had been all but overlooked by the government in its impetuousness, rush and childlike zeal to get these changes through.

The issue concerns the gaining of vital feedback from the public—those people out there directly affected by the changes and the many organisations that represent differing groups on which these bills impact. But this is not my thinking alone. Our very own House of Representatives fact sheet, which was revised as of 1994, states in black and white:

SPEECH.PARA: This second reading debate is designed for one purpose—to consider the principles of the bill.

These principles can be appropriately considered only through consultation both within the party and among others and, of course, with adequate time. Yet here we are in the House today debating and trying to piece together not one but two bills to ensure the very best changes for the people of Australia without prejudice or favour. The same document also states:
The adjournment (between the first reading and the second reading speech) also provides the opportunity for public discussion and reaction.

I ask any reasonable person in the House today whether this could possibly happen in only eight days. I also ask whether this has taken place in the intervening three weeks between the last sitting when the bill was scheduled to be discussed and today.

PARA.TAB: Yet again, if I were a mere onlooker I might assume that the Labor government is not really open to receiving public comment nor in any way interested in the views of Australians. However, I must point out that the government was aware of at least one inadequacy in these bills. It did a very smart back step in relation to the wife pension. Actually, `back step' is not correct—the government put into place yet another face-saving decision and reverted to fulfilling a commitment in this regard made back in 1994. I suspect that this change of thinking was not so much a direct reaction to community lobbying but, rather, a reaction to strong pressure placed upon the government by a most concerned opposition.

As to the intricacies of the bills, without doubt the issues contained in these bills are of particular importance to my electorate and would be similarly important to other select electorates across Australia. However, boundaries aside, perhaps the most profound irony in these bills is that the people most disadvantaged from these proposed changes will be the traditional Labor voters, who I believe have been sold out majorly in these bills.

The people of my electorate of Cowan, representing Perth's northern corridor suburbs, will be profoundly affected by nearly all of the proposed changes. I represent a great number of pensioners, unemployed youth, youth, long-term unemployed and a reasonable number of people aged between 50 and 65. In addition, I represent a number of new suburbs comprising two-income families as well as a large number of other people using the services of child-care facilities. My electorate also has a mix of private dwellings, government housing and a significant proportion of rental properties. It is these good people and their representative groups who will be in the firing line of all these changes. These people deserve the very best of government support and rely on the government's judgment of fairness and equity in legislative reform.

It was with this in mind that, as I critically read and interpreted these bills, I became deeply concerned about several specific issues in their contents. From my interpretation, the main issue in the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill is the introduction of a new extended deeming regime and the resulting repeal of unrealised capital gains. Such a repeal can result in only one outcome: no longer will many people's pensions be certain; these will now be somewhat floated like the dollar and are therefore likely to unfairly and unpredictably fluctuate. This may result in a lower than expected income at any one point for many pensioners. More importantly, it takes away much needed certainty for these people to plan and prepare for their financial future.

Any change creates uncertainty. When you link change of this nature to people's income base, there is sure to be widespread concern—if not mild panic in many cases. I suspect that the government will try to tell us that this fluctuation in payments is a good thing and keeps investments in touch with the current market situation. But let us face it: this argument is just another government red herring. This is all very well when the government is playing with words and throwing around insults and rhetoric in this chamber, but when it comes to interfering in the lifestyle and future of Australian people, the government needs to take stock of its responsibility and carefully think about what such changes really mean.

The baseline is that the people need to know. Pensioners affected by this change have a right to know their financial position at any one point in time. I am sure I am not alone in thinking that this is both a reasonable and rational request. The pensioners of Australia have really been put through enough without the necessity for this to happen. Due to the speed of this legislation, many people will be caught on the back foot from this change, without sufficient time to understand, or be informed of, all changes and the actualities of what is to happen.

This change will not affect a small number of people; it will affect many hundreds of thousands of pensioners. Perhaps most importantly, of these people at least 207,000 pensioners will suffer directly through an actual decrease in their pension, unless they rearrange their assets to either meet or exceed these new deeming rates. Asking people to do this may be in the long term and in some cases necessary, even if unreasonable. Yet I ask: how long have pensioners to do this? The bill, as I see it, fails to include any detail as to the timing and regularity of the valuation of pensioners' financial investments and therefore leaves all those affected somewhat at a loss to adequately plan for their future.

As to why this change is being made, one has only to realise that the government did not receive the revenue expected from the previously determined test, and this has been the case since this test was introduced in 1992. In the three or so years since that time, there has been no steady rise in the value of investments. Therefore, the hidden revenue gains have not been realised. However, this is just one of the many issues to be discussed today.

So that I can present the views of my electorate on each issue, I have taken the liberty of using a slightly different approach in the House today. I will provide the House with the shortened title of each change, highlight the issues deemed important and, finally, give my summation on each of the points.

The first point I would like to raise is the earnings credit scheme. It is an important and valuable scheme in that it essentially encourages people to seek part-time work. Fine. It is a great initiative, one with across-the-board appeal. But—and there is always a but—overall this scheme is particularly underutilised at the moment. People do not understand how it works, and with the proposed changes it is even less likely to be understood or in fact used.

For those who can and do use the scheme, the changes will actually disadvantage those people who are willing to put in a few extra hours and earn a little bit more during a particular fortnight. It is not a great boost or incentive to those who have had the opportunity to earn an occasional extra dollar—and I stress `occasional'. It is very much like the Father Christmases who will be appearing in stores and shopping centres over the next couple of weeks prior to Christmas. Their only income is occasional. It happens to be once every year, so I guess they fall into this area.

As I read this particular set of changes, I felt that such a scheme would only widen the distinction between those on pensions and those on benefits, as this change affects only those Australians receiving allowances and not benefits. As for my overall assessment, it is a program underutilised at present; with changes, even less likely to be utilised. So I ask: what is the point?

The next point is the amalgamation of the jobsearch and newstart allowances. This is another initiative that looks great on paper yet is really another smokescreen to hide the real numbers of long-term unemployed in the queues for jobs. Already we have seen the government stop publishing youth unemployment figures by area, and this further change now provides an opportunity for figure fudging for the long-term unemployed as well. This figure fudging will come at a cost, albeit a somewhat hidden cost. For a change such as this, there need to be administrative changes in government in many areas—such as in staff training, computer programming, forms and other print information and direct mail-outs, and the list really goes on.

My overall assessment of this initiative is that it is an expensive smokescreen at best with little real value to anyone. I must say it is somewhat regressive, as this is how the system was back in 1991—some four years ago. The mature age allowance is yet another smokescreen designed to figure fudge the real numbers of those considered long-term unemployed. This will occur through the transfer of participants from the newstart program to this non-activity tested allowance. This would effectively stop some 20,000 people being listed in the unemployment statistics—not bad if you have something to hide.

As an aside to this point, my calculations of this change suggest that there is a real chance that many mature age beneficiaries may actually receive a reduced benefit. Overall, and in real terms, these mooted changes will make the system even more complex. My overall assessment of this particular change is that it is a smokescreen at best which will have effects on many people through a reduction of income. This may be considered a backward step.

Not only that; through this change we are saying that people who are 55—in particular 60 and above—and who have something to contribute to the community will no longer be considered to be contributing to the community. The change tries to hive them off any scheme by putting them into this mature age allowance. Therefore, we are saying, `Look, you have done your best; see you later.' What happens to these people over the next 30 years while they are living in this great Australia? We just put them on the shelf and say, `Thanks a lot for your efforts, but we do not want you anymore.' This scheme promotes that.

The next is the guardian allowance. It seems that the government has proven to be dishonest yet again. In the 1995-96 budget the government announced that the guardian allowance would be increased by $4 per fortnight—$2 per week—as of September 1996. Great, fine, beaut—all those sorts of adjectives. But this increase has been delayed until two months after next year's budget.

This begs the question as to why it was announced so early. Why was it not left to the appropriate time? Was it announced so early because of electioneering? Was it due to an overzealous spokesperson? Or was it perhaps due to a little factional pressure? Who knows? Yet another of life's mysteries under a Labor government!

However, my overall assessment of this amendment is that it really is part of a fairly mean trick played on the Australian people. First, an increase is announced and then deferred by more than 12 months. That is like parents saying to their children, `Hey, kids, I'll give you an increase in your pocket money, but you can't have it for another 12 months.' That is the way this government works—it announces something and then does not really instigate it. By the way, the government is undertaking all this coercion and these undercover deals over an increase of only $2 a week. That might sound mean-spirited and I think that is probably the case.

The next amendment concerns rent assistance. This is too important an issue for too many people, certainly in my electorate and, accordingly, is an area which I treat with respect and great personal interest. On the surface, I was pleased when I realised that under this proposed change some 190,000 families would be better off. I am not one to criticise for the sake of criticism, and for this benefit I would gladly say thank you to the Labor government. But—and there is always a `but'—when I looked a little more closely, I was appalled to learn that 8,700 recipients will lose rent assistance as a result of the increase in the threshold. A further 310,000—more than 300,000 Australians already designated as needing assistance and support to sustain a comparable lifestyle—will lose up to $3.75 as a result of the increase in the threshold. This amount may seem insignificant here in this House away from the average Australian, but to many people this is a great amount, a very significant amount.

By the way, the government also thinks that this amount is very significant and they have deferred a payment of $4 for the guardian allowance as being an unnecessary if not substantial amount to balance their blown-out budget. Yet here they are taking nearly the same amount of money away from rent assistance. It seems that they can take immediately without conscience, thinking that no-one will really feel the pinch, yet on the other hand hold back a very similar amount.

Obviously this amount of $4 must be considered by the government as a significant change and worthy of mentioning in not one but two budgets. This Labor government that consistently espouses support for low income earners is potentially taking away roofs over people's heads, albeit tile by tile. As for my own overall assessment of this amendment, this is yet further slow erosion of working people's disposable incomes.

I really have not discussed all the issues in these bills and the task to do so is fairly enormous. I must stress to the House yet again my concern that members and others have not been afforded the privilege to provide a true assessment of these bills because of the government's insistence and pushiness. So I look forward to the community backlash in this particular area.

Certainly my electorate of Cowan is reeling after 13 years of Labor government. The people in my electorate require a change and one of the changes that they are looking for is in this social area. Earlier I was listening to the member for Watson (Mr Leo McLeay) espousing the $30 billion a year we spend on what he calls the social wage. My own investigation indicates it is more like $42 billion. In fact last year, of the $120 billion we spent in Australia we only collected $108 billion, leaving us $12 billion or so short.

But of that $120 billion, 50 per cent was in two areas: $42 billion on social security and $17 billion or so on health. These are two areas that take a lot of money from the taxpayer and I am sure that they are two areas that the taxpayer of Australia will continue wanting to support.

However, over the last 13 years we have taken away people's self-worth and we have made them dependent upon the system. No greater evidence of this exists than in my own electorate where, daily, people come to see me for assistance to work through the bureaucracy of the department. Daily they complain about not receiving their appropriate benefits. Daily they complain about not having enough money to sustain themselves. Daily they come into my electorate office and complain about the Labor government's creation of this dependency.

Sure, they place a lot of significance on their social wage. There is support for people on low incomes. But who created these low income people we have in Australia? Who has driven a greater divide between the rich and the poor in Australia? None other than the Australian Labor Party. They have to provide for people on low incomes, as any wealthy society should. We should provide for the underprivileged who need some help in our community.

But in Australia we spend $42 billion on the social wage. A lot of those people, I think, would prefer to be earning a salary out there with employment. My own view is that we should look after those who need help in Australia, but we should also create opportunity and hope for them, and we cannot do that whilst we have a Labor government. I support my colleague the member for Berowra (Mr Ruddock) in his amendments and I look forward to further debate on this particular issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also would like to speak on the amendments in the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Carer Pension and Other Measures) Bill and related legislation, which come before the parliament as I think the 40th set of amendments to the social security legislation since the new so-called simplified legislation was brought into the House in 1991.

PARA.TAB: It is a matter of regret that these very complicated amendments to the act—some 40—have been brought into the parliament with the opposition having been given just on a week in which to respond. It is often difficult in those circumstances to make a complete assessment of who will benefit and who will lose from some of these measures. But it is already clear in the short time that this legislation has been available for public scrutiny that there are many losers from this particular range of measures.

One of the government's strategies lately has been to try to bring this sort of legislation in and out as quickly as possible in the hope that there will not be a full public awareness of some of the matters that are included in time for them to be subject to appropriate assessment.

Interestingly, these 40 amendments to the act will obviously make a wide range of changes but do nothing whatever to simplify what is a very complicated social security system. I have a great deal of sympathy for the comments of the previous speaker, the honourable member for Cowan (Mr Richard Evans), who spoke about the people who regularly come to his office with social security problems. I have to say that my own experience is exactly the same.

The system has become so unbelievably complicated that few can understand it. There is an urgent need to overhaul the entire social security system so that we have legislation that people can comprehend and find user friendly. Bear in mind that the sorts of people that use the social security system, the clients, are not generally trained lawyers. They are not the sorts of people that have outstanding expertise in dealing with government legislation and understanding the filling out of forms and all the other procedures associated with the social security arrangements.

It would benefit everybody if the system could be simpler and there was a clear understanding of what people were entitled to so that they could access it easily. In addition, if the system were simpler there would be fewer loopholes, fewer gaps that people so often fall through and fewer people suddenly finding they are ineligible for a benefit they have received for a long time; changes made to the system that affect them and which upset their whole lifestyle.

While we have an act which currently has 1,200 sections and over 300 definitions covering 27 different pensions and allowances—legislation that is regarded by many as being even more complicated than the notorious tax legislation—is it any wonder that this sort of confusion exists. The Welfare Rights Centre stated in a recent newsletter that there have been 39 amending bills with approximately 24,000 new clauses inserted into the act since the Social Security Act was introduced in 1991—24,000 clauses in a bit over four years! Is it any wonder people are aghast at the way in which this legislation operates?

The confusion does not just apply to the clients, although they are the ones who concern me the most; it is also a problem for the staff of the Department of Social Security. Frequently I come across occasions when clients say they were not told something by Social Security staff that was relevant and important to their case. Frankly, it does not surprise me that, on occasions, Social Security staff would neglect to give a client some important piece of information; they are dealing with a lot of people but, what is worse, they are dealing with complex legislation which frequently even they have difficulty in understanding.

When there is an announced change by the government, it is rarely honest in the way it makes its announcements. It always trumpets the good points about proposed changes to the legislation, but it is always very quiet about how many people will be disadvantaged. That is one of the themes of my comments during the debate on this particular legislation tonight—the number of people who will be disadvantaged, in spite of the fact that the government puts out media releases which give the impression that everybody is a winner. Of course, when the government expects to save money from a measure, there is no way everybody can be a winner, and there are plenty of examples of that in this legislation tonight.

I suppose one of the surprises of the 1995-96 federal budget, and one of the most important elements of this bill, was the decision to extend the deeming regime to cover a wide range of pensioners' financial investments. It includes, I guess, one welcome admission from the government, and that is that they got it all wrong in the appalling pensioner unrealised capital gains on shares issue. I have spoken about this matter in this House on many occasions, drawing attention to the real anomalies that were created by that system. There was an outcry in the community about it, and rightly so. Many pensioners have adjusted their affairs to try to take account of those provisions, only now to be told that the government will dump them altogether.

You could not have had any hint that the government was about to dump these procedures, particularly if you had listened to the former Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security, now the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Mr Sciacca. In this parliament he stood valiantly defending these measures, pointing out how great they were, what a wonderful thing the unrealised capital gains on shares test would be and of course that these gains should be counted in the income test. We never argued that they should not be included in the assets test as that was perfectly reasonable, but including them in the income test was in fact taking pensions off people for money they may never get, money which they certainly did not have to live on at the time. As far as the test was concerned, there was a clear inequity.

But the parliamentary secretary at the time went on radio and television and was in this parliament day after day defending those measures—I might note with a singular lack of support from his colleagues. Often he sat here alone—as is the current Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security (Mrs Crosio)—with no-one behind him to defend him on these matters because I suspect his colleagues knew, as well as everyone else, that this was a proposal that was full of inequity, a proposal that gave no fairness to the social security system whatever, and so should never have been introduced.

Nonetheless, the parliamentary secretary defended it vigorously until finally the announcement came in the budget that it was to be dropped and—I thought in an absolutely monumental piece of dexterity—a few days later we had the same Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security, who was by then Minister for Veterans' Affairs, boasting to the Sunday Mail in Brisbane that he was instrumental in bringing about the changes, that he was bringing in all the improvements to the system he had so vigorously defended for the previous year. I know that sometimes parliamentary secretaries have to defend causes they do not believe in but, if that was the case, the minister was a wonderful actor and certainly gave the impression that he believed very passionately in measures which he was quick to dump the next time around.

We now have a deeming provision, which will mean that a range of financial investments will be deemed to be earning income of five per cent or seven per cent, irrespective of the amount of earnings that they actually achieve. The extended deeming arrangements will mean that there will be a standard five per cent deeming rate for the first $30,000 of financial investments for single people and $50,000 for couples, and then above that a standard deeming rate of seven per cent will apply.

This measure has one considerable advantage and I acknowledge it freely: it is much simpler than the system that it replaces. It also has some element of fairness in that a wider range of investments are covered under the deeming provisions. But it still creates a whole series of inequities in itself. There is still a whole range of investments, including collections of French clocks and the like, that do not get counted. Certain real estate investments do not get counted. So it is still possible to have a capital gain and to have investments for which no income is counted.

The real problem that arises from any kind of fixed deeming arrangement of five per cent or seven per cent is that obviously it creates an incentive for pensioners to invest their money in measures that are likely to return the maximum possible gain. If you are looking for something that will have the highest interest rates, there is also the greatest risk. So, whilst those investments may return 10 or 12 per cent in good times, there may be other occasions when they return nothing at all. But that does not matter as far as the deeming provision is concerned; they will still be assumed to be earning five or seven per cent. So a poor pensioner with some bad investments will not only lose money on their investments and be out of pocket so far as the earning potential of the investments is concerned, but will lose out again because they will be deemed to be continuing to receive an income from those investments. They will be in double jeopardy: they will lose not only the income from their investments but also their pension entitlement. On the other hand, there may be good days when they earn 10 per cent, substantial amounts of extra money, but get to keep their pension. So there is a degree of anomaly.

The government argues that this measure is attractive because it creates certainty. There is some degree of additional certainty over the previous capital gains on shares system, but there is by no means absolute certainty, because the value of the investments will go up and down and therefore the deeming amount counted against them will vary from month to month. We do not know very much about what the valuation procedures will be. I hope pensioners will not be up for huge costs in establishing the value of any of their investments. But, whatever the valuation arrangements, they will clearly change from time to time and that change will be outside the control of the individual pensioner. So he will still face variations in the amount of pension entitlement depending on the valuation of those investments. So the quite laudable motives of achieving certainty and achieving simplicity are not completely achieved in these measures.

The measures themselves are quite interesting. I am not quite sure where the government got its idea to introduce this wider range of deeming provisions. It did commission, at great expense to the taxpayers, the Ageing Agendas report. Pensioners and organisations spent a great deal of time and effort to make submissions to that inquiry in the hope that it would lead to significant changes. But the report rejected the vast majority of the submissions, many of which were leading towards some kind of universal pension entitlement, and simplicity in the system. The report rejected that approach and the government has now rejected most of the recommendations of the Ageing Agendas report. These deeming provision changes are certainly not in accordance with what Ageing Agendas recommended. So that report was clearly a waste of money and a waste of effort on the part of all those people who put so much work into it.

I want to talk about the real effect of these new deeming arrangements. The government announced them as being of great benefit to pensioners. We were told not only that the system would be simpler and easier for people to understand but also that thousands of pensioners—hundreds of thousands even—would be better off financially as a result of these measures.

Where they did not level with the Australian people, and what they did not tell the pensioners, was that they expect to save $62.58 million in 1996-97 as a result of these measures and $65.02 million in 1997-98. Pensioners are going to be better off, we are told, but the government is going to save over $60 million a year. What they did not own up to and what has only come out with much more detailed scrutiny is that 270,000 pensioners and part pensioners are going to suffer a decrease in their pensions as a result of this measure—270,000 pensioners will be worse off. That should have been the banner headline if we had a truthful and honest government telling us what was happening as a result of these changes.

I have already had in my office one pensioner, who is astute and clearly aware of his own financial affairs, who has said to me that he will go from receiving a full pension to getting none at all as a result of this single measure. I acknowledge that in most circumstances the effects will not be that drastic. But 270,000 pensioners will be worse off as a result of these deeming provisions. That needs to be taken into account in any assessment of the merits of this proposal.

There are a number of other proposals as well, some of which, ironically, reverse or change decisions that the government made only a very brief period ago. The mature age allowance, which was to be axed on 30 June 1996, is to be extended but significant changes are to be made to those arrangements.

I would like to make some comments on the guardian allowance, which has to be the most mean-spirited announcement that a government has made in a budget in years. The government has announced that there will be a $4 per fortnight increase in the guardian allowance. It needs to be remembered that since 1973 the real value of the guardian allowance has dropped by 48 per cent. The value of the allowance has gone down by 48 per cent since 1973.

There has not been a real increase in the allowance since 1986. Now the government, with great fanfare, announces that there will be a $4 per fortnight increase. That seems pretty miserable and mean-spirited. But that is not all. The increase is not actually going to commence until September 1996—not until after the next budget, not until after the next election. Anybody who can remember the l-a-w tax cuts or anything of that nature would hardly be counting their $4. It has to get through another whole election, through another budget. Then, two months after the scheduled time of the next budget, the $4 per fortnight finally comes along. What a mean-spirited response to people who the government has acknowledged are needy. How much will this measure cost that it has to be delayed until 1996 before it can be introduced?

There is another measure of this nature. The government announced changes to the rent assistance arrangements, again giving the impression that it was being generous to people who are receiving rent assistance. We were told about the $5 per fortnight increase for families with children. But, again, when you start to read the fine print you find out that there are many losers. These increases in the rent assistance are actually going to save the government $16.9 million over 3 1/4 years. They are going to save $5.2 million a year from this rent assistance increase. That does not add up.

Once you look closely at the fine print you find that 190,000 families will receive up to $5 a fortnight extra, and that is to be welcomed. But 310,000 recipients will lose up to $3.70 as a result of the changes to the threshold arrangements and a further 8,700 will lose their entitlement to rent assistance altogether. So there are many more losers than there are winners. ACOSS has calculated that 135,000 recipients will benefit from the changes, the average change in weekly income a measly $2.40. But 365,600 recipients will lose as a result of these changes.

Those are the sorts of changes that are associated with this legislation. It adds 40 further amendments to an already unduly complicated piece of legislation. It is high time the government looked seriously at the effect of these measures.

This legislation was delayed because the government abandoned its decision to withdraw wives pensions from many people who had been given an assurance in the previous budget that their wives pension would not be taken from them. There were to be no new grants of wives pensions after 1 July 1995. Then the government announced in the last budget that it was going to take the wives pension off many of the people who already received it. Finally, after widespread public criticism, the government backed down on these matters. But that has created an anomaly, too. You are left with people who once had an entitlement to a wives pension but who, because of the refusal to grant a new entitlement, will not be able to renew them. That needs to be addressed as well. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bradford Mr J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to have the opportunity to support the opposition amendments to this social security legislation and particularly the amendment moved by the member for Berowra (Mr Ruddock) to the second reading of the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill, which reads:

PARA.TAB: That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words: "whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House is of the opinion that the Government should be condemned for:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)its cavalier treatment of the House by providing only 8 days between the introduction of the bill and its second reading . . .
(2)its failure to draft the bill to include details as to the timing and regularity of valuation of financial investments under the . . . Bill;
(3)failing to advise Australians adequately that it estimates that the extended deeming rules will result in 207,000 pensioners suffering a decrease in their pension . . .
(4)its failure to adequately assist investors of the Meridian Investment Trust . . . and
(5)failing to address the potentially adverse impact of the extended deeming rules on the holders of investments in friendly societies".

This amendment deserves serious consideration by the government, for it raises a number of issues which have clearly not been adequately addressed in this legislation. One wonders whether the government, in rushing to bring this legislation before the House as it did—and the amendment makes the point that inadequate notice was given of its intentions—has simply overlooked or failed to understand some of the consequences of this legislation for a number of people. Many times in the course of this government we have heard it talk about unintended consequences. Surely we must ask whether there are unintended consequences in this legislation. The government must answer the questions that this amendment poses.

PARA.TAB: The member for Wide Bay (Mr Truss), who spoke before me, made the point clearly that there are substantial losers under this legislation. The government simply cannot have it both ways. It cannot attempt to make a case out for the benefits of this legislation for pensioners at large when clearly there are losers—and there are losers simply because the government projects savings. If the government were to come in here and tell the truth up-front about its legislation, then that would not be a valid objection. But the fact is it does not do that. It attempts at every opportunity to gild the lily and tell us about the benefits. But there is clearly a substantial downside in this legislation for pensioners.
