The amendment that we have moved refers to the 207,000 pensioners who will suffer a decrease in their pension if they do not rearrange their assets to meet or exceed the deeming rates.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Newell)—Order! I might remind the member for McPherson that the amendment has not been moved yet. He can continue his remarks in the context of foreshadowing the amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take your point, but there has been a gap of some weeks since the legislation was introduced. I do not recall when, but I understand that the shadow minister, the member for Berowra, intended to move that amendment. I have the amendment here. I understood that it had been moved. If it has not been moved, then at some stage it is going to be moved. So I take your point.
—Better late than never.

—Yes, it is certainly better late than never. The fact is that there are 207,000 pensioners who will suffer a decrease in their pension if they do not rearrange their affairs. Those few words are important because what we have had from this government over the years has been an attempt on many occasions to force pensioners to rearrange their affairs. The whole process of taking into account unrealised capital gains on shares as income was an attempt to force pensioners to rearrange their affairs. That effectively forced pensioners to sell their shares. The former parliamentary secretary and now Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Sciacca) admitted that—here in the parliament when we confronted him with the proposition of how they were to survive if they lost their pension—the answer was to sell their shares, rearrange their affairs.

PARA.TAB: This legislation is a further attack on some of my aged constituents. It is a further attempt to force them to rearrange their affairs. What is the one thing that aged people are entitled to amongst all of their other entitlements? Surely it is certainty in retirement; surely it is the right that they have earned to have an enjoyable, relaxed and worry free retirement. Yet the one thing that this government has delivered constantly to aged people—whether they be pensioners, part pensioners or totally self-funded retirees—is uncertainty. This is just simply another step in the process of creating a climate of uncertainty. Why? The answer apparently is to save a few million dollars, $60 million-odd a year, to create uncertainty for 207,000 part pensioners.

We heard in the parliament today that the government proposes to give Vietnam $55 million to build a bridge. I do not want to get embroiled in an argument about the pros and cons of foreign aid but I want the people listening to know, and I want to be able to tell my constituents, that, on the one hand, the government is trying to save $60 million by taking away some of their pensions but, on the other hand, it is prepared to spend $55 million building a bridge somewhere in Vietnam. It is no wonder that average Australians are concerned when they hear of that sort of connection, because most of them believe that charity begins at home. I suspect that the 207,000 pensioners who are losing pension from this particular legislation would be quite entitled to believe that to be the case. The government is desperate to save money to balance its budget—which, of course, it has not been able to do. In its desperation, the government is prepared to engage in this ultimately penny-pinching exercise to force 207,000 pensioners once again—goodness knows how many times the pensioners have had to do it—to rearrange their affairs.

I am pleased that the government has backed down on that totally unacceptable system of taking into account unrealised capital gains on shares. The member for Wide Bay, who spoke before me, and I constantly berated the government over that totally inequitable, unfair and unreasonable attack on pensioners. I am not yet convinced that the deeming is going to be satisfactory, although at least it seems to have the merit of being easier to calculate and easier to understand for most people.

In the end, I still believe that deeming is flawed. While I am quite happy to accept the concept of adequately targeting benefits, and we on this side understand the importance of doing that, I am not sure in the end that deeming—it is, in a sense, ad hoc in the effect that it has—is going to be entirely fair to everybody. That is a substantial concern that I have about the proposal. Also, many secure and desirable investments may not be able to deliver the returns equal to or more than the deeming rates that are proposed. The deeming rates will change as prevailing interest rates move up and down. This will make it more difficult for pensioners to make long-term decisions about their retirement incomes. They need to make long-term decisions if they want to have certainty in retirement years.

The other aspect of that particular question and the question that the government really needs to answer is that no provision has been made in this legislation—there appears to be no answer available when you ask the question—as to how assets are to be valued and at what point they are to be valued. Surely we on this side of the House are entitled to know that. Surely those who are going to be affected by this legislation are entitled to know that.

Another matter addressed in the foreshadowed amendment is the particular problem of deeming for friendly societies which offer tax paid investments. As I recall, it was not so long ago that this government was encouraging people to go into those sorts of investments. Now we have what amounts to an horrific retrospective change in the treatment of those particular investments for a large number of people; in fact, 400,000 pensioners have a total investment of $2.8 billion in friendly societies. They may not all be affected—it is not entirely certain how they will be affected—but the problem has been raised by the friendly societies. It is a valid concern and it needs to be addressed.

The government does not even seem to be aware of the problem. I hope that we on this side, the pensioners who are affected and the friendly societies which have flagged the concern quite openly will get some response from the government. At its very worst, it will force a very large number of pensioners to withdraw their funds from friendly societies or to rearrange their funds within friendly societies, which may cause serious liquidity problems for the various institutions concerned. I do not know whether the government is worried about that, but it ought to be because it is a question that has not been answered. We want to know exactly what the government intends to do about that particular problem, because it is a problem that needs to be solved.

The other issue that needs to be addressed—in fact, it has partially been addressed since this legislation was introduced—is the treatment of Meridian Investment Trust holders. We all know that these people were the original investors in Estate Mortgage management, which collapsed. They received their Meridian shares in exchange for very much diminished investments that they had in Estate Mortgage management. They were then faced with a change which effectively said that the value of their investment had increased—and so it had but from a very low base. Very few of them—in fact, none of them—would have got back to anywhere near their original investments.

Here was a double whammy for these people under the current legislation. They were to be extremely badly affected by the taking into account of unrealised capital gains on their investments, when they were still substantially worse off as a result of their original investment in Estate Mortgage management. The government has apparently come back with a half-baked response. It does not go nearly as far as I believe it should. It agrees to make some ex gratia payment which in some small way may compensate holders of Meridian Investment Trust, but it does not go nearly far enough.

The shadow minister, the member for Berowra, stated our belief that these investments should be treated in such a way that full account be taken of the fact that these people had lost a considerable amount of money. We on this side of the House are not at all satisfied with the government's response. The government was dragged screaming into a response because the legislation, when it was originally introduced, did nothing to assist those people at all.

The government has taken 12 years to adjust the affairs of pensioners and it still appears to have got it wrong on many occasions. The people most adversely affected by these latest changes are self-funded retirees and part pensioners. These people have done the right thing. They have saved and have substantially provided for their retirement. They have made investments on the basis of the best advice they could get and on the basis of the current law. However, these people will be adversely affected by this legislation.

In my view—and I believe it is the view that is widely shared in the community—this is just another attack on people who deserve to have some security and who should be able to enjoy their retirement. I challenge the government to take up the issues that have been raised by a number of us in this debate and to seriously answer the questions that we have asked. At the moment those questions remain unanswered.
Debate (on motion by Mr Pyne) adjourned.
Motion (by Mrs Crosio) proposed:
That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abbott Mr A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This government has a penchant for saying one thing and meaning another. Recently, the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) assured the Mayor of Manly that there would `be no commercial development of North Head' in my electorate. Understandably, this gave the impression to everyone in the district that only public facilities would be allowed on North Head and that the public land would remain in public hands.

PARA.TAB: But at the hearing of evidence before the Joint Committee on Public Works a couple of weeks ago it became very clear that just about the only development that has been ruled out on North Head is the construction of a brand new shopping complex. In May of this year the government announced that it was going to close down the School of Artillery on North Head and move it to Puckapunyal. The government said that when the army left North Head it was government policy to sell the land on the open market. Quite rightly, this gave way to fears of high-rise buildings on some of the last undeveloped headlands around Sydney Harbour. It gave rise to fears of Club Med and Mirage Balmoral on North Head.

Ever since then, this government has been trying to reassure people that it would not do what it said it would do. In evidence to the public works committee a couple of weeks ago Brigadier McCann, a good officer—an officer who like all military men tells the truth—gave the lie to the protestations of the Minister for Defence. Brigadier McCann said:

SPEECH.PARA: In terms of the meaning of `no commercial development of North Head', this was seen to mean no new construction for commercial purposes of the land occupied by the School of Artillery.
He said that this definition:

. . . could involve limited building alterations to enable the re-use of that land, including potential for low scale, medium density redevelopment. . . was an option to be further considered by the planning committee.

In other words, existing construction can be used for virtually anything. It can be used for a hotel. It can be used—why not?—for a Club Med on North Head. This is the spectre that faces the people of Manly. According to the evidence presented by Brigadier McCann we could also be faced with a whole series of dual occupancy redevelopments. That means hundreds more people living on North Head and thousands more cars using this area.

PARA.TAB: It means that one of the last unspoiled headlands around Sydney Harbour is faced with environmental vandalism. The government's assurance that North Head land was safe in the hands of the Minister for Defence is about as believable as an assurance that the industrial relations system and industrial peace is safe in the hands of Dangerman, Laurie Brereton; about as believable as an assurance that truth is safe in the hands of the minister for memory loss.

However, that is not all. Barely a day after the opening of a monument to the defence of Sydney in the grounds of the artillery museum of North Head—an opening attended by 1,400 people, including the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Sciacca) and the Governor of New South Wales—we had the revelation that not only was the government wanting to move the School of Artillery, but it wants to move the artillery museum as well. Obviously the monument will remain, but the whole context will be changed if the artillery museum goes.

On Sunday, 1,400 people in my electorate were saying to this government, `Please reconsider.' We have to ask ourselves why is there this indecent haste to privatise Sydney Harbour foreshore land. What deals have been done to drive this government to do this? Why on earth does the government want to vacate this land on North Head? Let us face it: how can Sydney be defended from Puckapunyal? Surely if there ever is any conflict in our region the city of Sydney will need to be defended, and it will need to be defended on site.

I ask: what secret deals have been done? I wonder if there a secret deal between the state government and the federal government. Has federal Labor and state Labor cooked up the same kind of deal for North Head as they have cooked up for the Sydney showground?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier today petitions were presented to the House on behalf of 2,130 constituents relating to the re-establishment of a Medicare office in the suburb of Toukley. The petitions came from people right across the Wyong shire. They illustrate the anger and frustration of people at the decision of the Health Insurance Commission to close down the Medicare office on 25 August. Those petitions have the support of the general community including pharmacists, doctors and health professionals. The petitions tabled today read:

SPEECH.PARA: The petition of certain electors of the Division of Shortland draws to the attention of the House that residents of Toukley, Norah Head and Noraville have been seriously disadvantaged by the closure of the Toukley Medicare/Medibank office.

The petitions call on the Health Insurance Commission to re-establish Medicare-Medibank at Toukley. I know that those petitions will go forward to the Minister for Human Services and Health for consideration by her, but I want to say to the House and to the minister that my constituents want to see a relocation of that office of Medicare-Medibank in Toukley. I totally and absolutely support them.

PARA.TAB: On 25 August 1995 Toukley Medicare-Medibank was closed by the Health Insurance Commission and relocated at the Lake Haven shopping centre. Last Wednesday, 16 November 1995, we had discussions at Toukley with officers of the Health Insurance Commission; with a representative of the medical practitioners in the Toukley area; with Nan Wenden, the president of the senior citizens club in Toukley—a club which has 5,000 members; with Mr Bill Simmington, the president of the Toukley Chamber of Commerce; and with Mr Rob King who is one of the leading pharmacists in Toukley and who was representing all the other pharmacists.

At that discussion it was clear that the Health Insurance Commission had made a decision to close the Toukley office and relocate it to the Lake Haven shopping centre, some five or six kilometres distant. The decision was based on information relating to population numbers and not in relation to the convenience of service offered to people of that area. The decision was based on postcode areas. Those involved had not looked at travel patterns and they had not looked at the complex of services.

As I said in this House on 26 September, Toukley has the largest medical service complex in the Wyong shire. A couple of hundred metres away from that was the Medicare office. Surrounding those two offices—the Medicare office and the medical service centre—are seven different pharmacies. Here we have an absolutely convenient set of services to meet the needs of an ageing community, to meet the needs of people who have difficulty with public transport services, and to meet those needs as conveniently as possible. People would go to the medical services, then across to Medicare to get their rebate, and then to the pharmacies to get their pharmaceuticals. It worked very well.

This decision has been made without proper consideration of the interests of the people who use Medicare and medical services. It is causing great disruption and a great deal of anger among the people of the area. That is why we had the discussion last week to try to convince the people of the Health Insurance Commission that they had made a wrong decision. I think they have made a wrong decision. I read their signals that way. Their response was that they had budgetary problems, they made a decision and they cannot relocate.

I heard what they said and our delegation heard what they said. But I say through you, Mr Speaker, and through this chamber to the minister, that what they have done is an affront to the people that I represent. It is a disruption to the convenience they had. It has made it much more difficult for people to get to their services and attend to their medical needs. I want the minister to direct the Health Insurance Commission to relocate a Medicare presence in Toukley. There are a number of ways to do this, but primarily to relocate a cash payment service.

Whatever they do, we want some kind of service re-established at Toukley to meet the needs of the people who live in that area and in recognition that there are some 30 general practitioners, 60 health professionals, 16 specialists and seven pharmacists, all within a matter of a few hundred metres, providing for the medical care needs of all the people in that region. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Filing Mr P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Following on from this afternoon's events, I would like to comment on today's West Australian editorial and put it in context with the statement by Senator Crichton-Browne on 15 November when he tabled his now notorious document, supposedly the defence against his expelling from the Liberal Party of Western Australia. Under the editorial heading `Senate shamed by MP's conduct' it is stated:

SPEECH.PARA: If Senator Noel Crichton-Browne is to be remembered for anything in WA's political history, it'll be for his single-minded determination to exercise power in the Liberal Party and his appetite for vengeance after he lost it.
Later in the same editorial it is stated:

Senator Crichton-Browne was a shadowy figure to most Western Australians before the internal bickering of the Liberal Party erupted into public feuding this year. He was revealed to them as a manipulative in-fighter who represented much that is wrong in the Liberal Party.

Those are very apt comments. I mentioned earlier that on 15 November he sought leave to table, and was successful, a document in which a number of assertions were made which are false, misleading or just plain wrong. This document was designed to be his defence to the charges that were laid against him in order to expel him from the party. It is ironic indeed that he has been hanged for the wrong offences. However, in his repetitive and self-seeking document, the senator alleged that he was innocent of interfering in the Moore, Curtin and Stirling preselections. I find this interpretation of recent history in the party highly interesting because, throughout the party's 20 years of internal civil war, the common thread has been the senator and his political activities.

PARA.TAB: In this document the senator refers to a meeting that was held at which he, the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), the member for Stirling (Mr Cameron) and I were present. He says in his report:

SPEECH.PARA: When Cameron and Filing were confronted by myself and John Howard in the Leader's office about claims made by them to the leader that I was seeking to undermine their preselection, much to their embarrassment neither could give one name.

The purpose of that meeting, which was organised at our request, was for us to give the leader, in front of Senator Crichton-Browne, the reasons why we thought he ought not to be selected as the leader's representative on the state council, state executive and state management committee of the Western Australian Liberal Party. It was organised in full agreement with us. During that meeting the member for Stirling and I put forward the case, which we believed to represent the will of the vast majority of the members of the House of Representatives from the Western Australian Liberal Party, that Senator Crichton-Browne ought not to be the Leader of the Opposition's representative, that he would be a divisive and unwelcome influence and that his representation would not be conducive to the best interests of the leader.

PARA.TAB: During that meeting, the senator did ask for examples of any particular individual attempts or efforts that he had made to interfere with preselections. I gave him a pretty big one to bite on and that was the fact that during that afternoon I had received a copy of the minutes of the then state executive meeting in which there was mention of an expulsion, censure or suspension motion against me. That particular document was an effort to undermine my standing in the Western Australian Liberal Party, immediately preceding the Moore preselection.

Those minutes were false, they were not authorised and they were put out by the state president, Dr Honey, a protege of the senator, contrary to the recommendation of the then state director, Mr Hook. I can tell you that those fraudulent minutes, which happened to have been leaked to the West Australian, found themselves being reported upon in that newspaper and they had been circulated as official minutes of the state executive of the Liberal Party. When I pressed Senator Crichton-Browne at that meeting about those minutes, about this blatant attempt to undermine my standing in the party, the senator, who had been at the meeting mentioned, for which these false minutes were supposedly a record, said that he must have been temporarily distracted when this matter was being discussed because he could not recall them.

He says that he took no part in interfering in the preselections. I can tell you that last August I had a meeting, or a conversation, with the member for Wanneroo, a person who has admitted to several indiscretions in relation to his relationship with Dr Bradshaw, previously a mayor of the city of Wanneroo. He told me that he had received a telephone call from Senator Crichton-Browne in which Senator Crichton-Browne said that I had been getting far too much influence in the branches of the Moore division and that he—Smith—ought to sort it out or he would get a kick up the backside.

Smith, a compromised member—a vulnerable member of parliament—obviously followed those instructions from Senator Crichton-Browne because from that point onwards my fortunes in the division deteriorated considerably. That is the modus operandi of the senator. He operates by proxy, or he certainly used to in the days when he was able to operate openly, instead of operating in his own name or in his own right. Hence these things that occurred in the Liberal Party in Western Australia often operated behind the scenes with the string-pulling coming from Senator Crichton-Browne's office in Canberra or Perth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Henzell Ms M.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to update the House on the continuing struggle of meatworkers in Rockhampton to get justice. I am delighted to do so following the intervention of the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Brereton) in this dispute and representations made by the Commonwealth before the AIRC. We are looking to a much more positive position. On 9 November, the full bench made the following statement:

SPEECH.PARA: On the basis of the evidence presented by Australia Meat Holdings Pty Limited . . . in support of its application for the approval of the enterprise flexibility agreement . . . the Full Bench has concerns about a number of matters. These relate to:
1.Consultation with employees during the negotiations for the agreement . . .
2.The steps taken:

PARA.TAB: -to inform employees about the terms of the agreement . . .
-to explain to the employees the effects of those terms . . . and
-to inform employees about the consequences of the approval of the EFA by the Commission . . .

SPEECH.PARA: 3.The genuine agreement by the employees to be bound by the agreement . . . and
4.The opportunity given to the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union . . . to take part in the negotiations for the agreement . . .

The current proceedings are still in place. This statement has arisen as a result of evidence heard before the full bench, simply from Australia Meat Holdings. In fact, it was their witnesses that formed the basis of the commission's concerns—the sorts of issues that the union has been endeavouring to place before the commission over a number of months. The union has been the subject of vilification by AMH. I have been the subject of misleading statements by Mr Hughes in the media. It is at least reassuring that the commission has expressed those concerns.

PARA.TAB: I was outside AMH meatworks in Rockhampton the morning that this EFA agreement was to be voted on. I was very surprised to see some very young people going through the gate. They looked as though they were going through the gate for the first time; they certainly did not have a driver's licence because their mum or dad was dropping them off at work. It would appear to be the case that the process by which AMH recruited new employees onto the plant meant that when the EFA agreement was voted on—after what, it has become very clear, was a flawed process that has not met the guidelines of our legislation—many of the people who voted had little experience in the industry and little understanding of the implications. I would therefore be very optimistic that when the commission makes its judgment those factors will be taken into consideration.

When Minister Collins was in my electorate subsequently, in the last couple of weeks, he had an opportunity to speak with various people who understood what was happening at AMH. Although they were not directly involved, they knew the situation. They indicated that from their point of view it was not a reasonable basis for an enterprise bargaining agreement, that AMH had behaved quite reprehensibly in its whole strategic management of the process—and the government was criticised for not coming in sooner.

The struggles of that work force and the representations made by the AMIEU have been absolutely essential. It is important that our legislation be seen to support those workers and that agreements that do not have due process and do not involve fair and reasonable bargaining in good faith should be struck out by the commission—I certainly hope they will be. It is very important that all players in the industry start bargaining in good faith and that cattle producers realise that slamming meat workers to try to solve the problem is a very blinkered view.

I refer people to the chief of South Burnett Meatworks, David Woolrych, who indicated that industrial changes would account for only 13 per cent of the problem in the industry and that the industry had to look to its marketing and to a range of issues apart from industrial workplace reform, although that was important. Meat workers know it is important. They are prepared to engage in it, but they are not going to find themselves in situations that are unsafe, where people are not being able to see their families and, effectively, have to work excessive hours for no money to meet the targets of the company. That is the sort of thing AMH are wanting to do and it does not meet the sorts of concerns mentioned in the Fellows Medlock report.

I think we will see at places like Consolidated Meats in Rockhampton that Tancreds, the new company at Lakes Creek, will do a much better job. They are consulting with their employees and are prepared to work constructively to get an enterprise bargaining agreement in place. I think we will see at Lakes Creek a much better option and I hope AMH will take cognisance of that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Any time of the year is a good time of the year in Canberra, particularly in November. One of the reasons is that the Tuggeranong Community Festival, of which I am the patron, is held for about seven days. It started on the previous Saturday and ended on Sunday. I must say it has been a tremendous success. Events included such things as the Kambah Pony Club jumping day, the Tuggeranong Community Festival fun day, fireworks and the Australian premiere of the movie Babe. I think that is a credit to the festival organisers.

PARA.TAB: Things like this do not just happen. I would like to thank all the sponsors who backed the festival, including the Valley View newspaper; WIN Television; FM106; the Tuggeranong Hyperdome; Canberra Milk; Tuggeranong Valley Rugby Union and Amateur Sports Club; ACTEW Corporation; ACT Emergency Services Bureau; ACT Government's Cultural Council and other departments; Longlife, which sponsored some of the youth centre events; Panther Publishing; Monaro Publishing; and the Chronicle newspaper for sponsoring the `Pirates of Tuggeranong' theatre production.

It was a good year because there were a lot more exhibits, the exhibits were more varied and more people participated. I would like to thank the people who came along. The committee needs acknowledgment: Chairman, Steve Whan; Secretary, Jenny Fowler; Treasurer, Ray Harding; David Smythe; Ashleigh Lightman; John Hargraves; Joan Brice; Bob Brice; Stan Bromley; Annette Ellis; Alan Castles; Dominic Mico; Larry Lawrence; Lisa Kelly; Paul Osborne; Andrew Whitecross; Bill Thompson; Graeme Quarry and all the others associated with the festival. From the people of Tuggeranong, thank you for your efforts.

This year we have got a little more sophisticated down in Tuggeranong and we have added some awards to the festival. The first was a perpetual trophy in honour of Fred Daly and this was supplied by the Canberra Labor Club. We had a debate between two junior groups from the valley. It was good to see that Lake Tuggeranong College won the debate.

The other award we started this year was a perpetual trophy for the best float in the street parade. I am quite pleased to say that ACT Emergency Services Bureau won that award. The bureau includes the ACT Fire Brigade, the ACT Ambulance Service, the ACT Emergency Services and the ACT Volunteer Bushfire Service. Over the years that the festival has been going these groups have often provided staffing for checkpoints, street barriers and so on so that all the festivities could go on. So it was great to see ACT Emergency Services Bureau win.

Also recognised were some of the other floats such as the Valley View farm float and the Rotary Trash and Treasure float. HMAS Harman provided a patrol boat, a group of Harley Davidson riders turned up and ethnic groups from our local Philippine and Laotian community provided some colourful and spectacular scenes.

A great week was had by all. One of my particularly favourite parts yesterday was the MS fun run-walk around Lake Tuggeranong. It is an important walk because it is a family event. Not only does it promote health and fitness but it also brings to people's minds those who suffer from MS and the fact that we should support them. One of the great efforts of the day was that of a young lady called Linda, who has MS and who completed the walk in a very creditable time. Everybody was surprised but also very pleased on her behalf.

It is great to be patron of a community based event such as this. It shows that part of my electorate, the Tuggeranong Valley, has grown up. With it has grown the Tuggeranong Community Festival. I offer my thanks to all those who organise it and run it on behalf of a great community.

TALK.START.PARA: —In spite of the appearance of some level of democracy in the country of Chile, it is still encumbered by many residual aspects of a militaristic regime. The former dictator, General Pinochet, is still in effective control through control of a significant block of votes in the Senate and the military is still very much intertwined with many forms of economic activity. It is still all powerful in the overall society of Chile. There are still hundreds of political prisoners in Chile and widespread human rights abuses; and torture is still commonly used.

PARA.TAB: Recently I met with a human rights activist from a Chilean human rights body known as the Organizacion de Defensa Popular. The name of this person is Daniel Sanchez San Juan. As part of discussions about the general situation in Chile I had a lengthy discussion with him about the situation of his parents, both of whom are in gaol in Chile. In particular, I would like to provide to the House details of the situation of his mother. These details originate from an Amnesty International report. His mother, Maria Cristina San Juan Avila, is serving a life sentence in the San Miguel men's prison in Santiago for `unlawful terrorist association' and also for allegedly having been an accessory to the kidnap of Christian Edwards, the son of the owner of the El Mercurio newspaper in Santiago. Mr Edwards was kidnapped in September 1991 and released in February 1992.

In March 1992 Maria Cristina San Juan Avila was arrested with both her husband and another son, who was 16 years old at the time. She was blindfolded, handcuffed and placed on a chair for about two days. She was given no food and was not allowed to sleep. She was beaten on occasions and it was threatened that her son would be harmed if she did not confess to participating in the kidnapping. She was given a drugged drink to make her drowsy and forced to repeat details of the alleged kidnapping after the interrogator who was confronting her.

She was then forced to sign pieces of paper that she was not allowed to read. They, of course, were subsequently used against her. Both she and her husband were sentenced to life imprisonment and their son was later freed. She is now suffering from a variety of quite serious health disorders and illnesses, including the chronic blood disorder lupus erythematosus; Takayazu's disease, which is also a blood disease; chronic gastritis; bronchitis; and conjunctivitis. In the first year of her imprisonment she was allowed only one medical consultation with a non-specialist. She has subsequently been treated a couple of times in the prison hospital.

This is a true picture of the supposedly new democracy in Chile where human rights abuses and torture are still quite prevalent and where people are in effect imprisoned for their beliefs and treated as political prisoners as they were in the past in Chile. The military is still very much de facto in control and the power of civilian politicians is weak.

Australia has very substantial economic interests in Chile, including through companies like BHP, and it would be wise for us to take very serious stock of the role Australian companies do play in the Chilean economy because the links between the military and various activities in Chile, particularly in the mining industry, are quite extensive and quite important.

I call on the Chilean government to take much more vigorous steps to improve the human rights situation there. I acknowledge that they have improved it significantly since the ending of the dictatorship several years ago, but a lot more remains to be done. The human rights abuses, the random use of torture by the military and failure to employ proper legal processes where people have access to proper defence, proper rights to put their cases and genuine trial by their peers certainly needs to be dealt with.

I ask the House to give serious consideration to these issues, which are particularly important for what is becoming a major economic trading partner with Australia. We should be putting more pressure on Chile to clean up its act in this area and look after some of the problems I have raised in relation to prisoners such as Maria Cristina San Juan Avila and to make a common cause with organisations like the Organizacion de Defensa Popular.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like many members who hold marginal seats, I have been conducting a series of local public meetings in my electorate of Wentworth in the last month by sending some thousands of invitations to people's mail boxes, asking people to attend a local church hall or scout hall to meet their MP and make their concerns known. In doing this and in meeting the electors, many for the first time, I have come across a word that seems to roll off the tongue very often of women voters. That is the word `alienation'.

PARA.TAB: A lot of people talk about feeling alienated from the institutions in Australia and the degree of cynicism they show towards those institutions astounds me. They feel alienated from all sorts of institutions—one of the tiers of government, the banks, large corporations, even trade unions or, especially in my electorate these days, telecommunications carriers. They are Optus and Telstra.

The electors feel that, in making decisions about works to be carried out or plans for the future, these institutions, particularly these carriers, pay them not the slightest attention. The starkest example of this must be the proposed installation of coaxial cables above ground by the carrier Optus.

Only about six weeks ago Optus wrote to the three councils in Wentworth—Waverley, Randwick and Woollahra—saying that they proposed to install this broadband cable by stringing it from electricity poles above ground, where the electricity cables are already above ground. This is to provide a network for services such as pay TV and local telephone calls—very much the information superhighway.

There is no doubt that the Optus network will add to competition in this field—I welcome this—but there is great concern in the electorate that above-ground installation will be most unsightly. The obvious preference is for it to be installed underground, where the Telstra cable goes at the moment.

I am stunned to learn that, under the telecommunications code, the carriers in effect have unrestricted power to carry out their works in spite of public objection. It seems that, where there is significant public concern, the power to refer the proposed erection of these cables to the department of the environment lies with the carrier. It seems unbelievable that a carrier would refer itself to a department of government that could then somehow frustrate its proposed plans.

When I approached Optus about this, they made the point that the cable they proposed to erect is somehow different from the Telstra cable that already lies underground and that, whilst it seems reasonable for them to in some cases share the Telstra cable, which apparently has enormous capacity and would allow another carrier to provide services on it, the Optus cable is another generation ahead and that therefore they should be given the understanding of the electorate to be allowed to string it up above ground.

I approached Telstra about this and first of all asked them whether they would provide me with some information about the diameter of the ducts they have already under the streets. They said that this was an enormous engineering task and that what I was asking was unreasonable. But my good friend the technical director of the Woollahra Council, who, by sheer coincidence, used to work for Optus, told me that whenever the council wanted to carry out works in the street and excavate part of the footpath, in order to discover where the Telstra duct is, and indeed what its diameter is, all they need do is go to a building in the city and look up a register to find it there immediately. This would seem to suggest that the response I had from Telstra could best be characterised as obstinate or stonewalling.

With limited time available to me tonight, and perhaps with another opportunity this week to continue to discuss this issue of some urgency in Wentworth, I would like to say very bluntly to Telstra and Optus that the electorate, through me, requires their utmost cooperation. Otherwise, they will incur the wrath of the electorate. That may do some damage or put in peril their own commercial prospects in Wentworth when they seek to provide the services they are so eloquent in describing on the information superhighway.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are very few more conservative people in the world than Geoffrey Miller QC, undoubtedly one of Western Australia's most eminent QCs, so when Geoffrey Miller gives an opinion it has to be considered and taken seriously. With respect to a recent court case, Geoffrey Miller QC has given an opinion that the crown witness committed perjury. There is no doubt that in the crown's case this particular witness, who was a policewoman, led to the conviction of three other police officers.

PARA.TAB: We have had a situation in Western Australia lately, arising out of the royal commission into government business dealings—a royal commission which was set up with extremely wide ranging terms; a royal commission that was set up specifically to exonerate certain people—of a feeding frenzy. It was virtually impossible for a policeman or a politician to, in my view, get a fair trial.

These policemen went to gaol over the evidence of this policewoman. I believe we now have a situation where we must really give it thorough consideration. The police commissioner, Mr Falconer, has decided that he will call in the Federal Police to review the evidence. Frankly, I do not think this is good enough. I see no reason why the Federal Police should be any better than any other police force. The evidence is, in fact, that they are not. I think what really should have happened there was a judicial inquiry. Whatever the Federal Police say, it will simply not be enough and we need to go further than that.

You have had in Western Australia an enormous demoralisation of the police force. I do not think the Western Australian police force is by nature corrupt, although there is no doubt that throughout Australia the crazy situation we have with respect to illegal drugs is promoting enormous corruption. If you were to legalise the use of these drugs and control and tax them, you would do away with 85 per cent—maybe more—of the corruption that exists in police forces. I think that is something we as a parliament have to consider, and consider very seriously.

The situation in Western Australia, however, is that an appointment by the then Labor minister for police, an appointment he now admits may have been a mistake, elevated a Mr Ayton to deputy commissioner. Mr Ayton was certainly not the choice of the great mass of the police force. He had, in my view, created an image for himself by simply attacking policemen. What that has led to, of course, is total demoralisation of the police force throughout Western Australia.

I have a situation in my electorate where police officers say to me, `I have five years to go to retirement. I sit on this seat and I do nothing. They can call me lazy, but they can't sack you for that.' It is a very dangerous and unsatisfactory state of affairs. I think what is happening in Western Australia is simply out of all balance. There has to be some recognition that police in country areas do a very good job and are in fact performing the functions which should properly be performed by the social welfare industry. These are being done basically by the police force.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lieberman The Hon L.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 22 August 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) In which States were Aboriginal (a) men and (b) women entitled to vote on 1 January 1901.
(2) Did the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 deny Aboriginal persons the right to vote at federal elections unless they were entitled to vote at assembly elections in their State of residence.
(3) In what years and to what extent have federal laws subsequently (a) permitted and (b) required Aboriginal persons to vote at federal elections.
(4) Is he able to say whether any State or Territory law still distinguishes between the rights and obligations of (a) Aboriginal and (b) other Australians to vote at State or Territory elections.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1)(a) On 1 January 1901 there was no legal restriction on the right of Aboriginal men to vote in State elections in New South Wales, Tasmania, South Australia or Victoria.

In Western Australia, section 15 of the Constitution Acts Amendment Act, 1899 (WA), as in force on that date, precluded every `aboriginal native of Australia' from registration as an elector for Legislative Council elections except in respect of a `freehold qualification'—that is, unless the person possessed a freehold estate to the value of one hundred pounds. Under section 26 of that Act, an `aboriginal native of Australia' was entitled to register to vote in Legislative Assembly elections only in respect of a freehold qualification to the value of fifty pounds.

In Queensland, an `aboriginal native of Australia' was entitled to be entered on the electoral roll only in respect of a freehold qualification to the value of one hundred pounds (section 6 of The Elections Act of 1885).

(1)(b) On 1 January 1901, South Australia and Western Australia were the only States in which Aboriginal women were entitled to vote in State elections. As noted above, Aboriginal people in Western Australia were subject to certain restrictions in relation to registration as electors.
(2) When the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 was originally enacted, subsection 39(5) provided as follows:

`39(5) No aboriginal native of Australia, Asia, Africa or the Islands of the Pacific (except New Zealand) shall be entitled to have his name placed on or retained on any roll or to vote at any Senate election or House of Representatives election unless so entitled under section forty-one of the Constitution.'
Section 41 of the Constitution provided (and still provides) as follows:

`41. No adult person who has or acquires a right to vote at elections for the more numerous House of the Parliament of a State shall, while the right continues, be prevented by any law of the Commonwealth from voting at elections for either House of the Parliament of the Commonwealth.

(The High Court held in The Queen v Pearson; Ex parte Sipka (1983) 152 CLR 254 that the right to vote in section 41 was that possessed under a State law when the federal franchise was established by the Commonwealth Franchise Act 1902, and that section 41 does not confer a right to vote in a federal election on any person who from time to time has the right to vote at a State election).
(3) In 1949, the Commonwealth franchise was extended by virtue of section 3 of the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1949 to each `aboriginal native of Australia' who—

`(aa)(i) is entitled under the law of the State in which he resides to be enrolled as an elector of that State and, upon enrolment, to vote at elections for the more numerous House of the Parliament of that State (or, if there is only one House of Parliament of that State, for that House); or
(ii) is or has been a member of the Defence Force.'

As well as extending the federal franchise to Aboriginal members or former members of the Defence Force, this provision extended the scope of the federal franchise such that any Aboriginal person who had a right to vote at State elections at the time the amendment took effect (and thereafter) would also have a right to vote in federal elections. (As noted above, the effect of subsection 39(5) of the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918, at the time that Act was enacted, was that only persons who had the right to vote in State elections at the time the federal franchise was established had a right to vote in federal elections).
By virtue of section 2 of the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1962, the Commonwealth franchise was extended to all Aboriginal persons in 1962.

Under section 3 of the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1962, enrolment and voting was not compulsory for Aboriginal persons, as it was for other electors. Enrolment and voting in federal elections became compulsory for Aboriginal persons in 1983 by virtue of section 28 of the Commonwealth Electoral Legislation Amendment Act 1983.
(4) There are no State or Territory laws that distinguish between the rights and obligations of Aboriginal and other Australians to vote at State or Territory elections.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Family Services, upon notice, on 22 August 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Which local government areas will receive additional child care places within each service category under the 1995-96 Commonwealth-State National Child Care Strategy.
(2) Will the (a) Hornsby, (b) Ku-ring-gai and (c) Warringah, NSW, local government areas receive additional places; if so, on what basis have their needs been assessed.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Family Services has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The following local government areas in NSW have been approved under the 1992-96 National Child Care Strategy as high need areas for new community based long day care places and for further investigation during 1995/96 regarding sites and sponsors.

The following local government areas in NSW have been approved under the 1992-96 National Child Care Strategy (joint Commonwealth/State) and the Commonwealth New Growth Strategy as high need areas for new family day care places and for further investigation during 1995/96 regarding sponsors.

The following local government areas in NSW have been approved under the 1992-96 National Child Care Strategy as high need areas for new outside school hours care places and for further investigation during 1995/96 regarding sites and sponsors.
(2) Yes. See Question (1).
The identification of high need areas is based on statistical and qualitative information related to:
0-4 year, 0-2 year and 5-12 year target populations (from the 1991 ABS Census), and estimates and projections (to take account of population growth and decline since 1991);
data on the nature and timeframe of new housing releases, and recent dwelling unit commencements;

data on employment centres, `natural labour markets' and usage of long day care services by workers and commuters (as opposed to local residents), to take account of increased demand due to `journey to work' patterns;
information about local and regional employment characteristics, to assess the need for extended hours of care;
populations of children with additional needs (numbers of Aboriginal & Torres Strait Islander children, children of non-English speaking background, and children with disabilities) by local area;
information about the socio-economic status of families by local area, such as the prevalence of sole parent families;
the number, type, `mix' and distribution of existing child care services;
waiting list and vacancies data from existing services; and
information about recent supply trends and experiences.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Family Services, upon notice, on 22 August 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Are (a) privately owned child care centres and (b) non-government not-for-profit child care organisations, such as KU Children's Services, ineligible for operating and capital subsidies; if so, why.
(2) Is she able to confirm that local government authorities receiving capital and operating subsidies do not return a surplus on the financial operation of their child care services.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Family Services has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (1)(a) Yes.

(b) No, providing these organisations are approved under a national child care growth strategy. Operational and capital funding is provided to services in high need areas, generally where the private sector has been slow to invest. Services established with this funding are subject to tight planning controls and high cost requirements such as baby place provision and longer operating hours.

(2) Yes. Any funds accumulated in a particular year are carried forward as provisions for e.g. staff on-costs, maintenance and equipment replacement or are incorporated into the Budget for the following year.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Kailash Satyarthi and Harry Wu: Australian Representations

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 24 August 1995:

PARA.TAB: Have Australian diplomats undertaken action in relation to the imprisonment by Indian authorities of Kailash Satyarthi, Chair of the South Asian Coalition on Child Servitude; if so, what action; if not, does Australia support the imprisonment of Satyarthi, Harry Wu and others for claimed slander against manufacturers in appearances in documentaries or for supposedly treasonable offences.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: The Australian Government is committed to the protection and promotion of core labour standards in the region as part of its overall human rights diplomacy. Australia is active in promoting support for freedom of expression, freedom of association and the activities of non-governmental organisations and individuals in civil society. Officers of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade monitor human rights in regional countries, including the situation with respect to core labour standards and the situations of advocates of workers' rights. The Australian Government makes representations on cases where it is clear that the human rights of workers' advocates have been violated and will continue to do so wherever appropriate.

Kailash Satyarthi, the Chairperson of the South Asian Coalition on Child Servitude, was arrested by police in Haryana State, India, on 1 June following a case filed by a carpets export firm, Sheena Exports. The arrest appears to have been based on allegations that Satyarthi was disrupting the company from carrying out its business. This apparently followed his appearance in a German television documentary where he alleged that Sheena Exports employed child labour in making carpets. Apparently, the allegations led to the cancellation of an order for carpets by Swedish-based Ikea. Following advice of Mr Satyarthi's arrest, the Australian High Commission in New Delhi sought information on his situation and made enquiries about the legal basis on which he had been detained. Mr Satyarthi was released from detention on 2 June and his arrest order was stayed, initially to 6 June and then indefinitely. His case was stood over on 5 July with the next date for it to be heard by court not decided.

The Australian High Commission in New Delhi has advised Mr Satyarthi of Australian interest in his case and asked him to keep the High Commission informed of developments. The High Commission continues to monitor his case. The Australian High Commissions in India and Pakistan have been monitoring the situation of labour and children's advocates who have been subject to detention or harassment. Representations have been made on behalf of campaigners against exploitative child labour, including members of the Bonded Labour Liberation Front and their families as well as Pakistani journalist Zafar Yab Ahmed.

Harry Wu, a well-known campaigner against abuses of human rights in China, particularly forced prison labour, was arrested on 19 June at a border post in the far-west Chinese region of Xinjiang. He was charged with offences relating to espionage, illegally obtaining state secrets and deceptive activities. On 30 June, the Australian Embassy in Beijing made representations to the Chinese Ministry of Foreign Affairs and urged upon the Chinese Government a speedy resolution to Mr Wu's case. Throughout the period of Mr Wu's detention and trial, officers of the Beijing Embassy monitored the situation closely and maintained close contact with other diplomatic missions with an interest in Mr Wu's case.

On 5 July, I issued a press release in which I expressed grave concern at the detention of Harry Wu, whom I had met on two occasions during his visits to Australia and for whom I have the highest admiration and respect. In both the representations made by the Embassy and in my press release, the Chinese authorities were urged to look leniently on any allegations against Mr Wu. Harry Wu was expelled from China on August 25 after having been sentenced to 15 year's imprisonment for spying and other related charges. Mr Wu's expulsion from China was widely regarded as the most positive outcome in the circumstances.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 28 August 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Further to the answer to question No. 2334 (Hansard, 22 August 1995, page 147), in what manner did Ms Lynn Ralph disclose her interest in the NRMA to the Australian Securities Commission (ASC).
(2) Did the ASC consider the proposed NRMA float; if so, (a) by what means and (b) did the matter come before Ms Ralph in her capacity as Deputy Chair of the ASC.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) I am advised that Ms Ralph disclosed her interest in writing to the Chairman of the ASC in accordance with section 124 of the Australian Securities Commission Act 1989.

In addition, I am advised that her interest was well known to all ASC staff with any involvement in matters relating to the NRMA and had been actively discussed in the public arena at the time of her appointment to the ASC.

(2)(a) I am advised that the ASC registered the NRMA prospectus on 23 August 1994. It was registered in accordance with section 1020A of the Corporations Law which requires the ASC to register a prospectus within 14 days of being lodged unless it appears that the prospectus does not comply with the Corporations Law or the ASC forms the opinion that the prospectus contains a false or misleading statement or that there is a material omission.

Prior to registration, I am advised that senior executives of the NRMA and solicitors advising the NRMA group sought discussions with and provided background information to officers of the ASC Regional Office in New South Wales.

I am further advised that formal applications for relief from various provisions of the Law were subsequently made by solicitors advising the issuers. The substantive effect of those applications was to permit the announcement of and debate about restructuring prior to registration of the prospectus. Relief was also sought to enable voting, election and application forms to be sent to persons at various stages of the restructuring which were not physically attached to the registered prospectus.

I am advised that as required by the Law, the ASC considered the applications. It granted the relief subject to conditions in formal instruments which were published in the Gazette and recorded in the ASC Digest.

(b) I am advised that Ms Ralph has had no involvement whatsoever in any ASC deliberations or decisions about matters relating to the NRMA. All operational matters, including those relating to the NRMA prospectus, are handled in ASC Regional Offices and would not, in the ordinary course of events, have come before Ms Ralph as Deputy Chairman.

I am further advised that Ms Ralph's interest was fully disclosed and both she and ASC staff involved in matters relating to the NRMA prospectus were at all times careful to exclude her from deliberations and decision-making.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Legal Aid: Family Court of Australia

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 30 August 1995:

PARA.TAB: What options for legal representation are available to a person appearing before the Family Court of Australia who cannot afford private legal representation but, in handling his or her own case, causes the court hearing to be aborted because of the unprofessional handling of his or her case.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: A person who cannot afford the cost of private legal representation is able to make application for legal aid in respect of proceedings before the Family Court of Australia.

Primary responsibility for the provision of legal aid, including for family law matters, rests with State or Territory Legal Aid Commissions, each of which receives substantial funding from the Commonwealth to enable it to discharge the responsibility for the delivery of legal aid throughout Australia. Each Commission has issued guidelines which set out in detail when legal aid may be available. Generally speaking legal aid is available subject to a means test as well as whether the application before the court has merit. Where a hearing is aborted because of poor handling by an unrepresented party, any further application will be subject to the means and merit tests. Copies of the guidelines can be readily obtained from Commissions.

As well, the Attorney-General is responsible for the provision of financial assistance under a number of statutory and non-statutory Schemes. These include the Public Interest and Test Cases Schemes, which are administered by Legal Aid and Family Services a Division of the Attorney-General's Department. Under the Public Interest Scheme, it is possible for assistance to be provided in respect of family law proceedings where a question arises under a law of the Commonwealth the resolution of which by the courts is, in the opinion of the Attorney-General, of public importance. `Test cases' are those brought for the purpose of resolving an important question arising under Commonwealth law that, in the opinion of the Attorney-General, affects the rights of a section of the public which is, or a group of persons who are, for the most part, socially or economically disadvantaged.

In any event, a person who may not be eligible for a grant of legal aid in respect of proceedings would be able to obtain legal advice from any Legal Aid Commission or Community Legal Centre in respect of their rights and obligations under the Family Law Act 1975. This advice function is usually provided without charge or for a nominal charge.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Working Solution: report of the strategic review of the Commonwealth Disability Services Program

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Human Services and Health, upon notice, on 18 September 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has her attention been drawn to a response prepared to a report prepared by Professor Baume and Kathleen Kay entitled Working Solution: report of the strategic review of the Commonwealth Disability Services Program.
(2) What is meant by the term "fair wages" used in the response.
(3) How do "fair wages" relate to productivity or award based wages.
(4) What factors are considered when determining whether a wage is fair or not.

(5) Did the report referred to in part (1) and a draft discussion paper entitled Issues for assessing productivity based wages in business services both make recommendations based on the payment of wages at full or pro-rata award rates.
(6) Does the response refer to "fair wages" on page 1 and productivity based wages elsewhere; if so, in the context of the recommendations referred to in part (5), why.

(7) Was the concept of "fair wages" recommended by the Productivity Wages Working Group with the support of the Australian Council for the Rehabilitation of the Disabled, Australian Council of Trade Unions, Disabled Peoples International (Australia) and National Council on Intellectual Disability.
(8) Were any recommendations regarding productivity or award-based wages not accepted for inclusion in the response; if so, (a) what recommendations and (b) why were they not accepted.
(9) Does page 2 of the response refer to a new requirement for services to pay productivity based wages; if so, what is the requirement.

(10) Does the response attempt to reconcile the Government's commitment to ensuring that persons with disabilities have fair and equitable access to the Disability Services Program with the fact that the Program is capped; if so, how.
(11) What sum has been allocated in 1995-96 for consultancy projects in relation to the Disability Services Program.
(12) With respect to each consultancy referred to in part (11), (a) who will conduct it, (b) what are the terms of reference and (c) was it let to tender; if so, on what basis was the tender awarded.
(13) Are other agencies working with her Department to develop an independent assessment mechanism for access to the Disability Services Program; if so, which agencies.

(14) What is the (a) name, (b) address, (c) type of service, (d) annual capital and recurrent grants received by and (e) annual target placement of each disability service which receives an annual grant per client greater than $13,000.
(15) Will any grant referred to in part (14) be renegotiated in 1996-97; if so, (a) in respect of which services and (b) on what basis.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The response is a statement released by me outlining the Government's responses of the Working Solution report.
(2) A fair wage is one which reflects the individual's productive capacity against a relevant award or agreement and which entitles individuals to appropriate industrial protection and rights.
(3) Fair wages, as described in the answer to part (2), encompass productivity based wages.
(4) See answer to part (2).
(5) Yes.
(6) See answer to part (3).

(7) The Wages Working Group was established to work through how to implement a supported wages system based on productivity based wages. All members support the payment of fair wages to people with a disability.
(8) All recommendations of the Working Solution report relating to wages (32-34) have been accepted. However, the target dates have been extended to facilitate implementation.
(9) Page 7 states that all services are required to pay award-based productivity wages by 1999.

(10) The response includes a number of reforms which will ensure more equitable access to employment services funded by the Disability Services Program. Access and individual program support will be based on assessed relative need for specialist employment support.
(11) Total commitment for consultancies for 1995-96 so far is $457,640.

(i) CSDA: PRINCIPAL CONSULTANT
Taking into account the aims and objectives of the CSDA, the Consultant is to:
Evaluate the impact of the CSDA;
Report to Ministers on the outcomes of the CSDA and implications for future agreements in this sector;
Report on issues which need to be addressed in framing any future arrangements in this area; and
take recommendations on future strategic directions for the provision of disability services.
In evaluating the CSDA the Consultant, drawing as appropriate on the work of the consultants engaged for the component studies of the evaluation of the CSDA, is to:
Establish and analyse the context of disability policy and service delivery in each jurisdiction at the onset of the CSDA implementation;

Identify the major strategic decisions and actions taken by Commonwealth, State and Territory Governments, individually and collectively, which were significantly affected by the implementation of the CSDA. These include decisions and actions in relation to planning, structures, service systems and funding;

Evaluate the overall effect (intended and unintended), across all jurisdictions, of CSDA actions and decisions (described in (ii) above) on people with disabilities in general, on particular groups of people with disabilities and on service providers;
Evaluate the actions taken and their effect against the overall intent of the CSDA. This should include examining:

TAB.TAB: the extent to which the CSDA has contributed to a government and service provider focus on better outcomes for people with disabilities;
the extent to which the CSDA has contributed to the development of streamlined and cost-efficient administrative arrangements, including clear service provider requirements;

PARA.TAB: the extent to which the CSDA has resulted in simplified and appropriate consumer access arrangements to specialised and generic services and better planned and integrated service delivery models; and
to what extent the CSDA has facilitated a shift away from direct service provision by the Commonwealth and States.
Assess the effectiveness of the provisions of the CSDA pertaining to funding, in adequately meeting the need for services provided under the CSDA.
Assess the effectiveness of the provisions of the CSDA in ensuring accountability for the use of resources.
Evaluate the provisions of the CSDA as an initial framework for rationalisation of administrative arrangements (particularly in relation to the provision of disability services).
(ii) CSDA: COMMUNITY CONSULTATIONS
The Consultant will:
Develop a strategy for public consultation on key issues for the evaluation of the CSDA that:
in a cost effective manner, informs and provides access to people and organisations in Australia wishing to provide comments;
ensures that the views of a full range of interest groups are obtained;
ensures that the views of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, of people from a non-English speaking background, and of people from rural and remote areas are obtained; and
is structured to facilitate access to the full range of community views.

Develop and distribute in suitable form, papers on key issues and, working in co-operation with the Principal Consultant, organise and conduct public consultations on the issues in all State and Territory capital cities and selected regional or other centres.
Provide a facility to accept and incorporate both written and telephoned comments on the issues.

Keep other CSDA evaluation consultants informed on the progress and results of community consultations (especially the Principal Consultant and those consultants engaged for the Implementation and Linkages studies).
Report to the DSSC on the consultations.
Assist the Principal Consultant in compilation of Interim and Final Reports for the Evaluation.
(iii) CSDA: COSTS STUDY
Phase 1:
Map current practices and developments in unit costing of service provision in disability support services;
Identify and analyse critical issues involved in the development and implementation of unit costs of service provision for disability services;
Examine, analyse, and report on issues critical to the development of national approaches to unit costs of service provision in the disability sector;
Identify and explain variables which might be key determinants of variability in costs of service provision;
Phase 2:

For a sample of service providers (to be specified) covering all service types (as specified in the CSDA Minimum Data Set), undertake a study of the total costs of providing disability support services, the components of these costs, the variation in costs between service providers and between States, and the reasons for these variations;
Investigate direct and indirect costs for specified service providers across all service types;
Evaluate key determinants of variability in costs for the service providers included in the study; and
Develop a model for average costs of service types that could be implemented across all State jurisdictions using standard definitions.
(iv) CSDA DEMAND STUDY
The Institute will:

Examine and analyse available date on demand for accommodation support, respite, day programs and other support services for people with a disability, and develop a national perspective of need for these services;
Collate and analyse the current criteria for eligibility and priority of access to services as defined by each State and the Commonwealth;
Examine and report on the availability of various types of support services under the CSDA as defined by individual States;

Identify and analyse the number of people with a disability who would significantly benefit from accommodation support, respite, day programs and other support services under the CSDA but who cannot access services under the CSDA;
Categorise data by State and by broad target groups where practicable, including primary disability type, age, ethnicity, sex.
(v) CSDA: LINKAGES STUDY
The Consultant will:

Identify and describe the essential support needs of people with a disability, particularly in the areas of accommodation support, employment, and community and family support with reference to broad disability type and stage of onset;

Map service provision under the CSDA in each State and Territory with special examination of key service system entry and transition points for example, preschool to school, school to vocational and other post-school options, work to retirement including accommodation;
Identify and examine the interfaces between the CSDA and other government funded programs providing support to people with a disability
at the key service system entry and transition points;
including access priorities, eligibility criteria and availability of services;
Identify where disability support can most efficiently and effectively be provided (ie points at which intervention is of most benefit);

Highlight best practice models and innovative measures to facilitate strong links between services within the scope of the CSDA and other government funded programs providing disability support, to promote and enhance opportunities for people with a disability to participate in the community;
Attend meetings as requested, and provide progress reports as requested.
(iv) CSDA: IMPLEMENTATION STUDY
The Consultant will:
Establish the context of disability policy and service delivery in each jurisdiction at the implementation of the CSDA. In doing so:
identify the level of funding provided by governments for services within the scope of the CSDA at the time of implementation in each State and Territory; and
identify any inconsistencies in the funding data and categorisation of services, to ensure consistency of data across jurisdictions.
Record the major strategic decisions and actions taken by Commonwealth, State and Territory Governments, individually and collectively, following implementation of the CSDA.
These include decisions and actions in relation to legislation, planning, structures, service systems, changes in funding and quantum and quality of service provision.

Evaluate the overall effect (intended and unintended), across all jurisdictions of those actions on people with disabilities in general, on particular classes of people with disabilities and on the service providers;
Evaluate the actions taken and their effect against the overall intent of the CSDA, including:

to what extent the CSDA has facilitated a shift away from direct service provision by the Commonwealth and States;
the impact of the CSDA on the process of institutional reform;
the extent to which the CSDA has contributed to the development of streamlined and cost-efficient administrative arrangements, including clear service provider requirements;
the effectiveness of the provisions of the CSDA pertaining to funding, in adequately meeting the need for services provided under the CSDA; and
the effectiveness of the provisions of the CSDA in ensuring accountability for the use of resources.
(vii) CSDA: EQUIPMENT STUDY

Prepare a Progress Report and Final Report for the DSSC on these Terms of Reference.
(viii) PSYCHIATRIC DISABILITY

provide participants with a detailed understanding of the national Psychiatric Disability and Employment Training Package No. 2;
ensure participants are given the skills and strategies to deliver the Training Package to DSP service providers;
ensure that the training is delivered consistently across Australia but with a capacity to adapt to local conditions;
ensure participants are given strategies to enable them to select appropriate consumers and to fully integrate them into the delivery of Module 1.
(ix) EDUCATIONAL RESOURCE CDS

inform members of the Australian Public Service about the existence of the Strategy and to explain its relevance to their work
inform members of the Australian Public Service about the types of access issues they may be required in regard to people with a disability
convince members of the Australian Public Service that good customer services includes meeting the needs of people with a disability
attract attention the fact that special information, resources and training materials are available to assist public servants to implement the Strategy's recommendations

(xi) ADVOCACY SERVICES

To develop a framework which can be used to recognise and assess the effectiveness of these services. The framework will be used by the community, people with a disability, their supporters and government.
(xii) TRAINING PREPARATION
Deliver Training to funded Disability Services Program on the responsibilities of management committees.

Consultancy (i)—The selection of the CSDA Principal Consultant was through direct engagement of a recognised and pre-eminent expert.
