TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications and the Arts, upon notice, on 18 September 1995:

PARA.TAB: Is it a fact that digital mobile telephone users must change their telephone numbers if they swap networks; if so, (a) why and (b) will it be possible eventually to swap networks but retain numbers; if not, why not.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: It is currently the case that a digital mobile telephone user will be allocated with a new telephone number if he or she swaps to another network.

The reason for this is that each of the carriers operates its own mobile telephone network. The telephone network uses the prefix of the dialled number to determine whether the called customer is on Telstra MobileNet, Optus Mobile or Vodafone. Each time a call is made the call must be routed to the correct network to be connected to the called number.

Under the Telecommunications Act 1991, AUSTEL is responsible for the management of numbering for telecommunications. AUSTEL is currently working on the development of a policy on number portability, which is the ability to swap carriers without changing numbers. AUSTEL's Numbering Advisory Committee (NAC), which comprises carriers, industry, consumer and Government representatives is working on this issue and will provide advice to AUSTEL members.
The NAC is also examining technical solutions for number portability, including for digital mobile services.

Preliminary work suggests that while it would be technically feasible to provide number portability for digital mobile services, any solution is likely to require a considerable amount of resources. For example, one option is to create a central database which contains up-to-date information on which numbers belong to which network.

The decision whether to introduce number portability, where it is technically feasible, will also depend on whether it is cost effective, produces benefits both to competition and consumers and does not conflict with the general retention of geographic information in numbers.

The Government's Telecommunications Policy Principles, announced in August this year, included an imperative in Principle 32 which states that "To enhance competition, current arrangements continue or new provisions be implemented, including for . . . equal access for customers to competing carriers . . . ; number portability (where cost justified); [and] access to numbers . . . "

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Human Services and Health, upon notice, on 20 September 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) What offers for (a) basic infrastructure, (b) additional infrastructure and (c) project development funding have been or will be made under the first tri-annual funding arrangements to each Australian division of general practice in each State and Territory.
(2) What is the (a) current and (b) estimated or potential general practitioner membership of each Australian division of general practice.
(3) What is the basis of the infrastructure funding provided to Australian divisions of general practice.

(4) Insofar as the funding formula is related to resident per capita population in each division of general practice, what provision has been made for special health needs of Australians in those divisions whose areas may have relatively low resident populations such as in rural or inner urban areas.
(5) What projects have been funded in each State and Territory by (a) topic, (b) funding category and (c) quantum of project grant.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) A table of basic infrastructure, additional infrastructure and project development funding has been provided to the honourable member and is available from the Table Office.

(2) A table of the current and the estimated or potential general practitioner membership for each Australian division of general practice has been provided to the honourable member and is available from the Table Office.

(3) Infrastructure funding provided to divisions of general practice is based on the size of the population (determined by the latest census data available to the Department) within defined division boundaries. Population figures are based on 1991 census data.
The formula for calculating division infrastructure is:
$35,000 + $0.66 x population, up to a maximum of $265,000.

In addition, a rural loading up to $50,000 is provided to those divisions in rural or remote areas of Australia, depending on the size and remoteness of the area covered by the division. The amount each division receives is determined by a formula based on the Rural and Remote Area (RARA) classification scheme.
A higher level of infrastructure funding is also available to those divisions meeting the following criteria:
the division has approved projects worth at least 75 per cent of their current infrastructure funds;

both infrastructure and project reporting requirements have been met by the division during the previous grant year. A division which has not provided the required reports within 2 months of the due date would not meet this criteria unless there were substantial mitigating circumstances;
At least 30 per cent of GPs who are potentially members of the division have made a formal application to join;
the division is soundly managed and accountable to its membership, through an active board of directors or management committee;

previous infrastructure funding has been fully utilised, ie at least 80 percent of 1993-94 infrastructure funding has been spent (or a pro rata amount in the event that the grant year is not yet complete);
overall progress to date has been satisfactory;
a high level of community liaison being required and/or undertaken by a division;

a division may have an exceptionally high workload because of the nature of the population in the area. For example an abnormally large transient population or an unusually high proportion of the local population being from non-English speaking backgrounds;
a high level of existing project activity (eg well over 75 per cent of the value of current infrastructure funds);
a high level of activity funded from existing infrastructure funds; and
the division's achievements to date.

The criteria are designed to identify divisions which are active, well managed, have established a sound relationship with their potential members and are capable of taking on the additional work that goes with additional expenditure.

Each division will also receive over the next two years an amount of $50,000 per annum for a project development officer to assist the division to develop projects which meet with the needs of the local area and the division's strategic plan.
(4) The following provisions have been made for the special health needs of Australians in those divisions with rural or inner city populations.
Rural loadings

The Department provides divisions with a rural or remote area population with rural loadings. The factors considered in determining the size of a divisions's rural loading include the division's distance from capital cities or major urban areas, the size of and distance between population centres and the population density. Each area in Australia is categorised into one of several categories based on the RARA (Rural and Remote Area) classification scheme. The rural loadings are intended to be used for either divisional infrastructure as long as spending is directed towards communications and travel support for members from rural or remote areas in the divisions or for specific projects which benefit GPs from rural or remote areas, eg establishing a satellite network.

Divisions with rural and remote area populations are provided with assistance from Rural Divisions Coordinating Units. These have been set up in Queensland, New South Wales, Victoria, South Australia, Western Australia and Tasmania. The Northern Territory receives assistance from the South Australian Rural Divisions Co-ordinating Unit.
Special purpose grants

Special purpose grant funding is provided for projects which address the national health goals and targets and priority issues identified by the Divisions Strategy Group, a body responsible for overseeing the policy and management aspects of the Divisions and Project Grants Program. Its membership comprises the Department, rural and urban divisions, the Australian Medical Association, the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners and consumers. This category of grants allows projects to be funded whichotherwise may be unable to achieve widespread divisional support if required to compete against other local projects, eg a few rural GPs might identify a priority area for the local rural community and weighed against other competing divisional projects it may not receive the appropriate support except for the availability of special purpose grant funding. This type of funding is available to divisions for projects which include:
the health needs of Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islanders;
the health of people of non English speaking cultures; and
the national health goals and target areas, specifically, mental health issues, cancers, injury and cardiovascular disease.
Seeding grants

Seeding grants of up to $20,000 per project are available to assist in the development of certain large scale or special purpose projects. The types of projects for which this level of assistance is available include:
projects which focus on identified national health goals and targets, eg mental health, cardiovascular disease, cancers and injury prevention;
locum support and after hours cover in rural and remote areas; and
information management projects of national significance. One such project has been the satellite network project in NSW.
Consumer liaison funding
Project funding is available to assist divisions to cater for the needs of the special population groups covered by the division.

(5) A table of projects that have been funded in each State and Territory by topic, category and quantum of project grant has been provided to the honourable member and is available from the Table Office.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Assistant Treasurer, upon notice, on 26 September 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Did the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) send a tax refund totalling $569 744.54 to a person who had earned $28 322 in 1994-95; if so, was the refunded sum correct.
(2) As at 20 September 1995, how many tax returns had been posted in which the ATO had erroneously overstated the sum to be refunded.
(3) What was the average overstated payment referred to in part (2).
(4) What was the cause of the error in each case referred to in part (2).
(5) What was the average length of time between the incorrect and correct cheques being sent.
(6) What procedures have been implemented to prevent a recurrence.
(7) Were any incorrect cheques banked or cashed intentionally or otherwise; if so, what action has the ATO taken in response.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The ATO sent a tax refund of $569 766.54 to a person who had earned $28 322 on 20 July 1995. This refund was one of a very small number of erroneous refunds which issued in mid July due to a combination of system and manual errors. These erroneous large refund cases in July attracted extensive media coverage.
(2) As at 20 September 1995, 12 refunds from a total of over 3,500,000 returns had issued erroneously. These 12 erroneous cases all relate to the original error that occurred in July 1995.
(3) The average overstated payment referred to in part (2) is $423,969.

(4) All incorrect refunds were due to a combination of computer system errors and human errors. Both elements relate to the incorrect multiplication of credits from the Prescribed Payment and Reportable Payment Systems.

In all cases ATO systems perform supplementary checks and controls that detect potential errors of this nature and the process requires manual intervention for the notice to issue. In these 12 cases the manual processes failed to stop the issue of the incorrect refunds.

(5) The average length of time between the issuing of the incorrect and correct cheques was 43 days. This period takes into account the time taken to retrieve the incorrect cheques and the issuing of replacement cheques.

(6) The ATO's system already includes necessary controls and checks to identify these potential situations. Further regular reports have been introduced to determine that reported error situations are correctly acted upon by staff.
An education campaign has been conducted to further emphasise the controls and checks within the system and the actions required by staff.
(7) No incorrect cheques were banked or cashed. All erroneous cheques have been cancelled.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Indonesian Development Military Transport Aircraft Flight

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 26 September 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Did an Indonesian developmental military transport aircraft receive approval about 23 January 1993 to fly to, land and return from Port Hedland, WA, airport.

(2) Did military intelligence receive advice from witnesses that the aircraft traversed a significant area of outback Western Australia and also landed at Karratha, Wittenoom and a number of stations.
(3) Did the aircraft depart Australian air space without clearance from Customs.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes. The Department of Transport advises that the aircraft was a CN235-100 aircraft operated by the manufacturer Pt. Industri Pesawat Terbang Nusantara, and was in the Port Hedland area to conduct a developmental test program for high temperature and desert operations.

(2) The Intelligence Warrant Officer of the Pilbara Regiment was advised by a witness that the Indonesian aircraft had landed at Wittenoom. Flights in the Port Hedland and Hamersley/Wittenoom areas (including the reported Wittenoom landing) were reported to the Land Headquarters. Local enquiries could not confirm if any illegal activity or deviation from flight plan had occurred.

(3) The Australian Customs Service advises that a CN235-100 aircraft arrived in Port Hedland on 19 January 1993 and departed on 2 February 1993. Completed arrival and departure documentation was received for this aircraft and outwards Customs clearance was given in accordance with normal procedures.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Agricultural and Horticultural Research and Development

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 26 September 1995:

PARA.TAB: Will the Government continue to provide matching funds for voluntary or other levies raised in the community for agricultural and horticultural research and development; if so, how; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beddall The Hon D.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: A Task Force was established in June this year to undertake the second phase of the budget review of rural research (commissioned by the Expenditure Review Committee of Cabinet in 1993). The Task Force was made up of representatives of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy, the Department of Finance and the Treasury.

This phase of the review examined the funding and evaluation procedures of the rural research and development corporations. It was asked to take account of the Industry Commission's report on research and development that was publicly released on 8 June.
Opportunities were provided for stakeholders to provide their views to the Task Force at meetings

ANSWER.PARA: held in most capital cities in early July. The Task Force has reported on the second phase of the budget review of rural research.

PARA.TAB: The Government is very conscious and supportive of the outstanding success of the rural Research and Development Corporations. It is also aware of the potential for dramatic changes in funding to destabilise the foundations of this model. In a recent speech to the NFF National Agricultural Research Strategy Conference in Canberra, the Minister, Senator Collins stated that the Government would seek to retain the incentive for RDCs to continue their good work.

The maintenance of funding support for rural research, and the continued provision of incentives for industry to contribute to this important activity will be the central issues in the Government's consideration of future funding arrangements. The Government's response to the Task Force's evaluation and to the Industry Commission report will be announced in the forthcoming Innovation Statement.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: North West Shelf, Liquefied Petroleum Gas

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Resources, upon notice, on 17 October 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) At what price is liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) from the North West Shelf gas project sold to export markets.
(2) How does the price referred to in part (1) relate to the world parity price for oil.
(3) At what price is North West Shelf LPG sold to Australian domestic consumers.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Production of LPG from the LPG facilities at the North West Shelf project is expected to commence later this year. To date, no prices for exports of LPG have been established. LPG export prices are expected to be competitive with world prices. Actual prices will be a confidential matter between the sellers and buyers.

Since the Government deregulated the LPG market in January 1991 the price of LPG sold to export markets by local producers in South Australia and Victoria has reflected overseas market prices, currently estimated to be around $A210 per tonne.
(2) Saudi Arabia, the world's largest supplier of LPG, sets monthly prices which are "marker" or "reference" prices for many of the world's LPG producers.

Crude oil prices are one of several components of the Saudi LPG price. From October 1994, the posted price for Saudi LPG has been set monthly on the basis of current and predicted market trends. Its elements include spot LPG sales, petroleum product prices (including kerosene and naphtha), LNG prices, Arab Light crude oil prices and prevailing conditions in international LPG markets.

World LPG prices fluctuate. The Prices Surveillance Authority, which monitors world and local LPG prices, has observed that increasing demand from China and India, coupled with seasonal influences from the Northern Hemisphere, can cause international LPG prices to fluctuate by as much as $A100 per tonne over a 12 month period.

(3) Natural gas transported by pipeline to Perth includes some LPG produced from the North West Shelf project. LPG is extracted in Perth by Wesfarmers LPG Pty Ltd and is sold to domestic consumers. Some of the LPG is exported. Domestic prices are believed to be based generally on the world price for LPG with costs being added for transportation, extraction (liquefaction), storage, road transport, and wholesale and retail margins. However, LPG prices at various stages of the production and distribution chain are confidential, based on commercial arrangements between the parties involved.

Information about LPG pricing in Western Australia has been made available by the Prices Surveillance Authority in its report "Inquiry into the LPG Declaration in Western Australia", published in December 1994. An information paper on LPG pricing published by the Prices Surveillance Authority in October 1995 gives an insight into the pricing of LPG in Australia.

PARA.TAB: Did he state that real wages have increased for individual workers since 1983; if so, will he provide details to support the statement.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: Yes, real average weekly total earnings for full-time adults have increased by 7 per cent since 1983. This figure is calculated using original data for average weekly total earnings for full-time adults (ABS Cat. No. 6302.0), June quarter 1995 on June quarter 1983, deflated by the Consumer Price Index.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 26 October 1995:

PARA.TAB: Did the Minister's Department or its agencies make payments to Elonpark Pty Ltd in any year between 1984-85 and 1994-95; if so, (a) what sum was paid in each year and (b) for what purposes was it paid.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: In respect of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, Office of National Assessments, Economic Planning Advisory Commission, Public Service Commission, Office of the Commonwealth Ombudsman, Merit Protection and Review Agency and Office of the Official Secretary to the Governor-General:
The information you have sought prior to 1988-89 is not available as expenditure records have been destroyed, as permitted under the Archives Act 1983.
No payments have been made to Elonpark Pty Ltd in respect of the years 1988-89 to 1994-95.
In respect of the Office of the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security:
No payments have been made to Elonpark Pty Ltd in respect of the years 1984-85 to 1994-95.
In respect of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC):

From the date of inception of ATSIC in March 1990 to November 1992, ATSIC did not have a centralised computer accounts system. It is not practicable to search records for the period from the commencement of ATSIC, that is March 1990 to November 1992.
No payments have been made to Elonpark Pty Ltd in respect of the period November 1992 to 1994-95.
In respect of the Torres Strait Regional Authority:
The Torres Strait Regional Authority was created in 1994-95 and no payments have been made to Elonpark Pty Ltd in 1994-95.
In respect of the Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies:
The information sought prior to 1986-87 is not available as detailed expenditure records are incomplete.
No payments have been made to Elonpark Pty Ltd in respect of the years 1986-87 to 1994-95.
